entries.notes: â€œYou can feel a lot of motion and energy,â€ Caroline Polachek tells Apple Music of her second solo studio album. â€œAnd chaos. I definitely leaned into that chaos.â€ Written and recorded during a pandemic and in stolen moments while Polachek toured with Dua Lipa in 2022, Desire, I Want to Turn Into You is Polachekâ€™s self-described â€œmaximalistâ€ album, and it weaponises everything in her kaleidoscopic arsenal. â€œI set out with an interest in making a more uptempo record,â€ she says. â€œSongs like â€˜Bunny Is a Riderâ€™, â€˜Welcome to My Islandâ€™ and â€˜Smokeâ€™ came onto the plate first and felt more hot-blooded and urgent than anything Iâ€™d done before. But of course, life happened, the pandemic happened, I evolved as a person, and I canâ€™t really deny that a lunar, wistful side of my writing can never be kept out of the house. So it ended up being quite a wide constellation of songs.â€ Polachek cites artists including Massive Attack, SOPHIE, Donna Lewis, Enya, Madonna, The Beach Boys, Timbaland, Suzanne Vega, Ennio Morricone and Matia Bazar as inspirations, but this broad church only really hints at Desireâ€¦â€™s palette. Across its 12 songs we get trip-hop, bagpipes, Spanish guitars, psychedelic folk, â€™60s reverb, spoken word, breakbeats, a childrenâ€™s choir and actual Didoâ€”all anchored by Polachekâ€™s unteachable way around a hook and disregard for low-hanging pop hits. This is imperial-era Caroline Polachek. â€œThe albumâ€™s medium is feeling,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s about character and movement and dynamics, while dealing with catharsis and vitality. It refuses literal interpretation on purpose.â€ Read on for Polachekâ€™s track-by-track guide. â€œWelcome to My Islandâ€ â€œâ€˜Welcome to My Islandâ€™ was the first song written on this album. And it definitely sets the tone. The opening, which is this minute-long non-lyrical wail, came out of a feeling of a frustration with the tidiness of lyrics and wanting to just express something kind of more primal and urgent. The song is also very funny. We snap right down from that Tarzan moment down to this bitchy, bratty spoken verse that really becomes the main personality of this song. Itâ€™s really about ego at its coreâ€”about being trapped in your own head and forcing everyone else in there with you, rather than capitulating or compromising. In that sense, it's both commanding and totally pathetic. The bridge addresses my father [James Polachek died in 2020 from COVID-19], who never really approved of my music. He wanted me to be making stuff that was more political, intellectual and radical. But also, at the same time, he wasnâ€™t good at living his own life. The song establishes that there is a recognition of my own stupidity and flaws on this album, that itâ€™s funny and also that we're not holding back at allâ€”weâ€™re going in at a hundred percent.â€ â€œPretty in Possibleâ€ â€œIf â€˜Welcome to My Islandâ€™ is the insane overture, â€˜Pretty in Possibleâ€™ finds me at street level, just daydreaming. I wanted to do something with as little structure as possible where you just enter a song vocally and just flow and there's no discernible verses or choruses. Itâ€™s actually a surprisingly difficult memo to stick to because it's so easy to get into these little patterns and want to bring them back. I managed to refuse the repetition of stuffâ€”except for, of course, the opening vocals, which are a nod to Suzanne Vega, definitely. Itâ€™s my favourite song on the album, mostly because I got to be so free inside of it. Itâ€™s a very simple song, outside a beautiful string section inspired by Massive Attackâ€™s â€˜Unfinished Sympathyâ€™. Those dark, dense strings give this song a sadness and depth that come out of nowhere. These orchestral swells at the end of songs became a compositional motif on the album.â€ â€œBunny Is a Riderâ€ â€œA spicy little summer song about being unavailable, which includes my favourite bassline of the albumâ€”this quite minimal funk bassline. Structurally on this one, I really wanted it to flow without people having a sense of the traditional dynamics between verses and choruses. Timbaland was a massive influence on that songâ€”especially around how the beat essentially doesn't change the whole song. You just enter it and flow. â€˜Bunny Is a Riderâ€™ was a set of words that just flowed out without me thinking too much about it. And the next thing I know, we made â€˜Bunny Is a Riderâ€™ thongs. I love getting occasional Instagram tags of people in their â€˜Bunny Is a Riderâ€™ thongs. An endless source of happiness for me.â€ â€œSunsetâ€ â€œThis was a song I began writing with Sega Bodega in 2020. It sounded completely nothing like the others. It had a folk feel, it was gypsy Spanish, Italian, Greek feel to it. It completely made me look at the album differentlyâ€”and start to see a visual world for them that was a bit more folk, but living very much in the swirl of city life, having this connection to a secret, underground level of antiquity and the universalities of art. It was written right around a month or two after Ennio Morricone passed away, so I'd been thinking a lot about this epic tone of his work, and about how sunsets are the biggest film clichÃ©s in spaghetti westerns. We were laughing about how it felt really flamenco and Spanishâ€”not knowing that a few months later, I was going to find myself kicked out of the UK because I'd overstayed my visa without realising it, and so I moved my sessions with Sega to Barcelona. It felt like the song had been a bit of a premonition that that chapter-writing was going to happen. We ended up getting this incredible Spanish guitarist, Marc Lopez, to play the part.â€ â€œCrude Drawing of an Angelâ€ â€œâ€˜Crude Drawing of an Angelâ€™ was born, in some ways, out of me thinking about jokingly having invented the word â€˜scornyâ€™â€”which is scary and horny at the same time. I have a playlist of scorny music that I'm still working on and I realised that it was a tone that I'd never actually explored. I was also reading John Berger's book on drawing [2005â€™s Berger on Drawing] and thinking about trace-leaving as a form of drawing, and as an extremely beautiful way of looking at sensuality. This song is set in a hotel room in which the word â€˜drawingâ€™ takes on six different meanings. It imagines watching someone wake up, not realising they're being observed, whilst drawing them, knowing that's probably the last time you're going to see them.â€ â€œI Believeâ€ â€œâ€˜I Believeâ€™ is a real dedication to a tone. I was in Italy midway through the pandemic and heard this song called â€˜Ti Sentoâ€™ by Matia Bazar at a house party that blew my mind. It was the way she was singing that blew me awayâ€”that she was pushing her voice absolutely to the limit, and underneath were these incredible key changes where every chorus would completely catch you off guard. But she would kind of propel herself right through the centre of it. And it got me thinking about the archetype of the diva vocallyâ€”about how really it's very womanly that itâ€™s a woman's voice and not a girl's voice. That thereâ€™s a sense of authority and a sense of passion and also an acknowledgement of either your power to heal or your power to destroy. At the same time, I was processing the loss of my friend SOPHIE and was thinking about her actually as a form of diva archetype; a lot of our shared taste in music, especially â€™80s music, kind of lined up with a lot of those attitudes. So I wanted to dedicate these lyrics to her.â€ â€œFly to Youâ€ (feat. Grimes and Dido) â€œA very simple song at its core. It's about this sense of resolution that can come with finally seeing someone after being separated from them for a while. And when a lot of misunderstanding and distrust can seep in with that distance, the kind of miraculous feeling of clearing that murk to find that sort of miraculous resolution and clarity. And so in this song, Grimes, Dido and I kind of find our different version of that. But more so than anything literal, this song is really about beauty, I think, about all of us just leaning into this kind of euphoric, forward-flowing movement in our singing and flying over these crystalline tiny drum and bass breaks that are accompanied by these big Ibiza guitar solos and kind of Nintendo flutes, and finding this place where very detailed electronic music and very pure singing can meet in the middle. And I think it's something that, it's a kind of feeling that all of us have done different versions of in our music and now we get to together.â€ â€œBlood and Butterâ€ â€œThis was written as a bit of a challenge between me and Danny L Harle where we tried to contain an entire song to two chords, which of course we do fail at, but only just. Itâ€™s a pastoral, it's a psychedelic folk song. It imagines itself set in England in the summer, in June. It's also a love letter to a lot of the music I listened to growing upâ€”these very trance-like, mantra-like songs, like Donna Lewisâ€™ â€˜I Love You Always Foreverâ€™, a lot of Madonnaâ€™s Ray of Light album, Savage Gardenâ€”that really pulsing, tantric electronic music that has a quite sweet and folksy edge to it. The solo is played by a hugely talented and brilliant bagpipe player named Brighde Chaimbeul, whose album The Reeling I'd found in 2022 and became quite obsessed with.â€ â€œHopedrunk Everaskingâ€ â€œI couldn't really decide if this song needed to be about death or about being deeply, deeply in love. I then had this revelation around the idea of tunnelling, this idea of retreating into the tunnel, which I think I feel sometimes when I'm very deeply in love. The feeling of wanting to retreat from the rest of the world and block the whole rest of the world out just to be around someone and go into this place that only they and I know. And then simultaneously in my very few relationships with losing someone, I did feel some this sense of retreat, of someone going into their own body and away from the world. And the song feels so deeply primal to me. The melody and chords of it were written with Danny L Harle, ironically during the Dua Lipa tourâ€”when I had never been in more of a pop atmosphere in my entire life.â€ â€œButterfly Netâ€ â€œâ€˜Butterfly Netâ€™ is maybe the most narrative storyteller moment on the whole album. And also, palette-wise, deviates from the more hybrid electronic palette that we've been in to go fully into this 1960s drum reverb band atmosphere. I'm playing an organ solo. I was listening to a lot of â€™60s Italian music, and the way they use reverbs as a holder of the voice and space and very minimal arrangements to such incredible effect. It's set in three parts, which was somewhat inspired by this triptych of songs called â€˜Chansons de Bilitisâ€™ by Claude Debussy that I had learned to sing with my opera teacher. I really liked that structure of the finding someone falling in love, the deepening of it, and then the tragedy at the end. It uses the metaphor of the butterfly net to speak about the inability to keep memories, to keep love, to keep the feeling of someone's presence. The children's choir [London's Trinity Choir] we hear on â€˜Billionsâ€™ comes in againâ€”they get their beautiful feature at the end where their voices actually become the stand-in for the light of the world being onto me.â€ â€œSmokeâ€ â€œIt was, most importantly, the first song for the album written with a breakbeat, which inspired me to carry on down that path. Itâ€™s about catharsis. The opening line is about pretending that something isn't catastrophic when it obviously is. It's about denial. It's about pretending that the situation or your feelings for someone aren't tectonic, but of course they are. And then, of course, in the chorus, everything pours right out. But tonally it feels like I'm at home base with â€˜Smokeâ€™. It has links to songs like [2019â€™s] â€˜Pangâ€™, which, for me, have this windswept feeling of being quite out of control, but are also very soulful and carried by the music. We're getting a much more nocturnal, clattery, chaotic picture.â€ â€œBillionsâ€ â€œâ€˜Billionsâ€™ is last for all the same reasons that 'Welcome to My Islandâ€™ is first. It dissolves into total selflessness, whereas the album opens with total selfishness. The Beach Boysâ€™ â€˜Surfâ€™s Upâ€™ is one of my favourite songs of all time. I cannot listen to it without sobbing. But the non-linear, spiritual, tumbling, open quality of that song was something that I wanted to bring into the song. But 'Billions' is really about pure sensuality, about all agenda falling away and just the gorgeous sensuality of existing in this world that's so full of abundance, and so full of contradictions, humour and eroticism. Itâ€™s a cheeky sailboat trip through all these feelings. You know that feeling of when you're driving a car to the beach, that first moment when you turn the corner and see the ocean spreading out in front of you? That's what I wanted the ending of this album to feel like: The song goes very quiet all of a sudden, and then you see the water and the children's choir comes in.â€
entries.title: Desire, I Want to Turn Into You

entries.notes:
Stunning new album where Four Tet uses many samples of Madlib to compose a delicious mix of beautiful tracks. The first new interesting record of 2021! Fragments of sounds, it is nothing more but every fragment is right on track.

From Pitchfork: â€œSound Ancestors, his new album, is a rare entry in his vast catalog to be billed straightforwardly as a Madlib solo release, not a collaboration with a rapper, or a record by one of several fictitious jazz players and ensembles heâ€™s invented, or an entry in an arcane thematic series. But it, too, is a joint effort, this time with Kieran Hebden, the electronic producer better known as Four Tet, who curated, edited, and arranged its 16 tracks from a body of hundreds of recordings that Madlib sent him over a period of two years. Their process reminds me of 2003â€™s Shades of Blue, which Madlib created by raiding the vaults of Blue Note Records, sometimes chopping the original jazz recordings intricately and sometimes letting them unfold for long stretches without much apparent editing. Now, Madlib is the one opening his archives, and Four Tet is the one listening and assembling.â€
entries.title: Sound Ancestors

entries.notes: Again, a fantastic EP. Both Storm and Startschot are phenomenal songs.
entries.title: Blauwe Regen - EP

entries.notes: Fantasy worlds, ethereal vocals and shuddering breakbeatsâ€”this is the immersive dance-floor soundscape of London-based producer and singer yunÃ¨ pinku. Honing her bedroom production skills during the coronavirus pandemic, pinkuâ€™s 2022 debut EP Bluff combined garage 2-step with bright rave synths and gossamer vocal melody, winning fans from Charli XCX to crate diggersâ€™ favourite Joy Orbison. Now expanding her soundworld to include collaborations with the likes of Shygirl and Nia Archives producer Jakwob, pinkuâ€™s next set, BABYLON IX, is a masterwork in percussively charged, escapist songwriting. â€œItâ€™s an allusion to Babylon and Cloud Nineâ€”these inaccessible realms that exist in our heads and in stories,â€ pinku tells Apple Music. â€œI wanted to produce a sonic world full of contrasts and deep imagination.â€ From the opening synth ambience of â€œTrinityâ€ to the â€™90s trance bass of â€œSportsâ€ and the euphoric melodies of â€œFai Fighterâ€, listening to BABYLON IX is certainly an exercise in imagining another world of heat, movement and communal self-expression. â€œItâ€™s some of the most honest music Iâ€™ve made,â€ pinku says. Read on for her in-depth thoughts on the EP, track by track. â€œTrinityâ€ â€œI made most of this EP in summer 2022, and there was one day when I was shut in a dark studio while the sun was out and nothing seemed to be working for me creatively. I had this nitpicking, negative inner voice going on, so I was playing around with the settings on a keyboard instead and as I pressed something, this synth sound suddenly took over the whole room. I really liked how it washed over everything, and it gave me the idea for the beginning of this. The song became about how the bad part of my brain, that critical voice, is actually where my creativity comes from.â€ â€œHeartbeatâ€ â€œI was working with the producer Oli Bayston and we were playing around with modular set-ups and getting a bit more experimental with the music production. â€˜Heartbeatâ€™ came pretty seamlessly out of that process of trying new sounds out. It was only after I had finished it I realised what that song was really about and connected with it. This is a track that explores when you are projecting onto other people the things that either you love or donâ€™t like about yourself.â€ â€œSportsâ€ â€œThis was made with a producer called Jakwob, who works a lot with Nia Archives. We did a couple of sessions together and fit really well sonically, as we listen to a lot of the same music. We were riffing in the studio and started coming up with the vocal chops that are the basis of this track. I then added lyrics based on these notes Iâ€™d had floating around in my phone, all about getting mad at someone for prioritising the TV or their phone over the reality of life.â€ â€œBlush Cutâ€ â€œI was working with Oli Bayston again and trying out some ideas at his house. His cat wouldnâ€™t stop purring on the mic, so at the beginning of the track you can hear this repeated sound beneath the keys, but itâ€™s actually just his cat purring, which we thought made a cute start! The rest of the song lyrically is about shaking off ideas of religious shame, since I wasnâ€™t aware of the amount of Catholic guilt that had been stuck in my head.â€ â€œNight Lightâ€ â€œThis is probably the most â€˜storytellingâ€™ song on the album. I was interested in the fantasy realms we create for ourselvesâ€”both digitally and in our imaginationsâ€”and so I wrote â€˜Night Lightâ€™ as an AI love story between a robot that gets Stockholm syndrome for the person who made it. The catch comes in the fact that the person the robot loves is also the person who can eventually turn it off.â€ â€œFai Fighterâ€ â€œâ€˜Fai Fighterâ€™ and â€˜Trinityâ€™ were both made in the same two days and they were the tracks that kicked everything off for the project. Making the production for â€˜Fai Fighterâ€™ was really fun. Normally the way I work is with headphones but I was in a studio with a great sound system, so I could play the music out loud and it allowed for this huge, punchy sound. The track is written from the perspective of a character who is the most powerful, confident version of yourselfâ€”a fighter.â€
entries.title: BABYLON IX - EP

entries.notes:
From Pitchfork:

â€œRachika Nayar doesnâ€™t just spew out a little fog before her live show, she stretches the venueâ€™s fire code to its limit. Before the guitarist walks onstage, the entire performance space is clouded, red exit signs barely visible, until you can barely see your hand in front of your face. The effect on the audience is immediate: Conversations dull to a whisper and friends drift carefully towards each other to reunite before the music starts, tiptoeing across a shadowy maze of bodies as they take on a heightened awareness of their own.

Itâ€™s the perfect environment to experience Nayarâ€™s music. Interviewed on the heels of her 2021 debut, Our Hands Against the Dusk, she championed the â€œtotally obliteratingâ€ power of a raveâ€™s atmosphere, and spoke of her desire to create a similar environment, ones that â€œsimultaneously takes you out of yourself, and submerges you deep within yourself.â€ Our Hands did this by constructing misty ambient labyrinths out of processed guitar, revealing Nayarâ€™s ability to sculpt the instrumentâ€™s earthy twang into unpredictable alien timbres and shift them back to familiar shapes at a momentâ€™s notice. When Nayar debuted tracks from her astonishing second album, Heaven Come Crashing, at the Brooklyn venue Public Records, strobes flashed violently and unexpected floods of drums crashed into the crowd. Egos melted away as the crowd breathed in a wave of ecstatic release.

Heaven Come Crashing injects the ambient wash of Nayarâ€™s past work with flashes of dancefloor emotionality, striking a balance between reflective contemplation and the ego-melting thrills of a warehouse party. On the stunning title track, she traces the arc of her musical transformation in miniature. Slices of granulated guitar gently refract into the frame, and for a few seconds, the song could be a holdover from the swooning sentimentality of Our Hands. But she soldiers on, backed by unearthly guest vocals from fellow guitarist and songwriter Maria BC that swell from airy wisps into a supercharged choir. Suddenly, a trap door unhinges and youâ€™re ripped into a punishingly beautiful beat drop. Itâ€™s a scene of catharsis surrounded by a squealing guitar solo and the cascading cymbal crashes of a drumâ€™nâ€™bass beat. â€œHeaven Come Crashingâ€ lifts you up with shameless melodrama and pure affirmation: It was all worth it.

Nayar deploys these moments of tension and release with the sixth sense of a veteran after-hours DJ, keenly aware that floor-filling emotional highs are earned through careful pacing. â€œTetramorph,â€ the albumâ€™s longest and most satisfying song, weaves through a series of false stops and starts that perfectly read the pulse of the crowd. Chattering hi-hats come in at full volume, emerging from pin-drop silence in a quick hit of stimulation. They fizzle out but the effects cling to your body, propping you up as you navigate a maze of buzzing drones that build into a waltzing post-rock climax. The effect is startling, but as Nayar rocks out in the coda, you easily recall every part of the meticulously arranged journey, awe-struck at how seamlessly she blended it all together.

Other tracks use compositional sleight-of-hand to leave you dangling off the edge of a cliff, ending on deliciously maddening chords that make you lean into the speaker, trying to manifest a neat resolution by sheer force of imagination. â€œThe Price of Serenityâ€ rides dueling motifsâ€”a steadily rising clean piano arpeggio and a squelching synthesizer leadâ€”to a crunchy four-on-the-floor stomp, disguising a jarring left turn into oblivion with a pulse-pounding bass drum stutter. In a show of supreme confidence, she resurrects the formula on the next track, â€œOur Wretched Fate,â€ crashing from nocturnal ecstasy into sober daylight in half the time. Unexpected power surges back into your feet, only for the house lights to come up.

In this metamorphosis from ambient composer to dancefloor mystic, Nayar meets her mirror image in UK producer Loraine James. Where Nayar has folded her impressionistic collages into body-breaking narrative arcs, James has done the opposite, smoothing out the gritty IDM of 2021â€™s Reflection to reemerge this year with ambient side-project Whatever the Weather. But although they take new form, traces of the past and beloved compositional tools linger. Just as James canâ€™t help but blow the dust off her drum machine, Nayar uses her guitar for soothing interludes that provide a dynamic counterpoint to Heaven Come Crashingâ€™s barn-burning anthems.

Nayarâ€™s new guitar experiments light the path with flickering details. A rhythm that sounds as if it were tapped out on her thigh, off-the-cuff, gives â€œGayatriâ€ a strange kind of propulsion. And the combination of bass synth and the brief glimmer of a corresponding lead line roots the searching motif of â€œDeath & Limerenceâ€ in the assurance of a heaven-bound trajectory. Itâ€™s a dazzling recalibration, lifting Nayar up and over the darkness of her previous work. The answers arenâ€™t quite pieced together, but the questions grow deeper and more satisfying.â€

After seven weeks, number one again as it is such an interesting ambient album.
entries.title: Heaven Come Crashing

entries.notes: Part of why it feels strange calling The Necks â€œjazzâ€ is that theyâ€™ve always put individual expression second to the dynamic of the group. Collecting four 20-minute improvisations used to open practice sessions, Travel is a great introduction both in its digestibility (typical Necks albums are usually a single track running about an hour long) and in how it captures the bandâ€™s peculiar, meditative intensity, which can range from churchlike (â€œBloodstreamâ€) to threatening and noir (â€œSignalâ€). That the other two tracks draw their names from active verbsâ€”â€œFormingâ€ and â€œImprintingâ€â€”tells you where the Australian groupâ€™s collective head is at: process, process, process.
entries.title: Travel

Rediscovered this album in 2023!


DJ/producer Teneil Throssell calls her debut album under the alias HAAi â€œa hyperactive journey that feels like a real reflection of who I am.â€ While that description rings true in some of her frantic breakbeats and other concussive blasts, Throssell also excels at downtempo softness and many subtle textures in between those poles. Formerly the guitarist/vocalist for Sydney, Australia, shoegaze trio Dark Bells, she relocated to London and made a name for herself as a DJ thanks to meticulous crate-digging and trippy flourishes she adds to her sets. Both qualities shine on this album, with lead single â€œBodies of Waterâ€ memorably contrasting Throssellâ€™s slow, dreamy vocals with crackling techno motifs. Baby, Weâ€™re Ascending also boasts high-profile collaborators, from ambient keyboardist/composer Jon Hopkins on the radiant title track to Hot Chipâ€™s Alexis Taylor on the string-swept â€œBiggest Mood Everâ€. Meanwhile, spoken-word poet Kai-Isaiah Jamal and singer Obi Franky hold hypnotic sway over assorted slippery contours on â€œHuman Soundâ€.
entries.title: Baby, We're Ascending

entries.title: I Love You Jennifer B

entries.notes: It has nearly become a clichÃ© unto itself for so many albums released in 2021 and 2022: an accomplished work of art that perfectly articulates themes of isolation and desperation and fatalism, only for the artists to reveal that the songs that express these ideas most acutely were written before the pandemic. â€œIt was already sort of all in the world,â€ Arcade Fireâ€™s Win Butler tells Apple Musicâ€™s Zane Lowe. â€œIn order to write music, you have to have this antenna up that kind of picks up little signals from the future and signals from the past. And so I think a lot of times we're just getting these like aftershocks of things that are about to happen.â€ WE is 10 tracks, but really more like five songs, taking into account various parts and chapters that give the album its epic scope, capturing the joy-in-the-face-of-peril spirit of their beloved 2004 debut Funeral, only with the peril a bit heightened. The songs that Butler and his wife RÃ©gine Chassagne started in their backyard New Orleans studio prior to March 2020 form a narrative that opens in a state of despair and winds up in an unlikely place of hope and optimism, with all the exuberance that marks the bandâ€™s most memorable songs. Like all Arcade Fire albums, WE is a family affair, featuring not just Butler, Chassagne and Butlerâ€™s younger brother Willâ€”who has since left the group, amicablyâ€”but Butlerâ€™s mom, a harpist, as well as guest vocals from Peter Gabriel. Read on as Butler expounds on a few key moments from WE. â€œEnd of the Empire I-IIIâ€ â€œIt's easy to interpret everything as being about the present, and I think there's an element of that, but I think you're trying to pick up on smoke signals. To me, the end of the empire isn't about now, it's about the future. It's about what's coming. I'm still waiting to wake up and check my phone and see the stock market has finally crashed. I mean, it's just an inevitability. This stuff is so cyclical, and it's like we're just printing money and pretending everything's okay. My grandfather lived through the Depression and was a musician in World War II and lived through some pretty intense stuff, and so I think this generation is up to the task as well. We have an eight-year-old, and the tools that he has compared to the tools that I had at that age are incredible.â€ â€œEnd of the Empire IV (Sagittarius A)â€ â€œâ€˜End of the Empireâ€™ is four parts; we had the first three parts and it was already six and a half minutes. For some reason I just knew that there was a fourth part to it, and I had this index card that said, â€˜Sagittarius Aâ€™, which is a black hole in the middle of our solar system. I just had the card on my wall and I would just walk by it. As soon as I was vaccinated and was able to travel, I went with my son to go visit my parents because I hadn't seen them in a long time. I went back to their house in Maine and I brought my 4-track and I put it in the basement of their house and ran a bunch of cables up to the top floor. I felt like I was 15. It was exactly like the shit I was doing when I was 15. I was like, 'Mom, I'm working on this song.' We would play 'Sagittarius A' together. There were a couple other songs that I did these 4-track recordings of playing it with her, and it sort of helped me to work through it and to just figure out what it is.â€ â€œThe Lightning IIâ€ â€œWhat was in my head when I was singing that song was all the Haitians at the border trying to get into the US who had taken a boat from Haiti to Brazil and then walked or taken a train all the way to the Mexican border. Just to find a better life for your familyâ€”imagine what it would take, the bravery. The governor of Texas can honestly...I don't hate a lot of people, but I hate that motherfucker. I don't even believe in hell, but if there's a hell, that motherfucker's going there. Just to meet people with the absolute absence of compassion, these fake fucking Christians. That's not necessarily what the song's about, but that was what was in my head: What does it mean to not quit and to reach the end and then to be turned back, and you still can't quit because you still have your family, so then you get sent back to where you started and you still can't give up because it's still your life and it's still your family and you're still fighting for survival.â€ â€œUnconditional I (Lookout Kid)â€ â€œI was really just thinking about my son and the world that he's facing and how I was a very depressed kid, particularly in high school. I was trying to imagine the way that I'm wired, just chemically, having to deal with that now, not to mention 10 years from now, whenever the fuck he's going to be dealing with it. He's going to need to have a thick skin and to just really be able to take a hit and have some fortitude. And basically just the idea of unconditional love, which is this impossible thing to achieve. But we do it naturally, somehow. And it's something that I think we naturally have with our kids, but I think it's something that we're supposed to have for people that we're not related to as well.â€ â€œWEâ€ â€œI think the journey of the record, the first half is: Imagine this character's like, 'Get me the F out of here, get me off this planet, get me out of my own skin, get me away from myself. I don't want to be here.' It's anxiety and it's depression and it's heaviness, it's the weight of the world. And he looks at this black hole like, 'Well, maybe if I could get through that black hole, that would be far enough away.' And when he gets there, he finds that it's himself and it's everyone he ever loved and the lives of his ancestors. There's nothing to escape, because it's all the same thing anyway. Stories and films are always building towards this big conclusion and then the credits roll. And to me, the sentiment is, 'Let's just fucking do it again, with all of itâ€”all the pain, all the loneliness, all the sadness, all the heartbreak. I just want to do it over and over again. Just run it back.â€

entries.notes:
Absurdly impressive album from this Welshman. Took him 10 years according to the reviews, while in the meantime working on album for FKA twigs and the likes.
This album is innovative in so many ways; the use of electronics in an almost classical music kind of way. Famous number are of cours Joy Squad (already discovered in mixes from Jamie XX and others) and Black Rainbow but all tracks on this album have their own beauty.

From Pitchfork:
â€œArriving a full 10 years after his debut single, Welsh producer Lewis Robertsâ€™ first album is a bravura display of brain-bending editing thatâ€™s more concerned with big feelings.â€

Another review:
â€œWelsh producer Lewis Roberts â€“ aka Koreless â€“ released his debut single a decade ago. There have been a couple more singles and even a couple of EPs since â€“ but this is his debut full-length album. A lot of time has been taken refining his sound, as when he arrived on the scene, the result is a project that has its own distinct sound but takes from many forms, not just dub/dance/ambient/techno/house worlds but also contemporary classical.

They say you canâ€™t be all things to all people but I wonder if Agor is an argument very nearly against that â€“ thereâ€™s all sorts here for sure. Opener, Yonder, is barely ever with us, some ambient thumps signaling an arrival. But when it folds over into Black Rainbow we have a kind of clipped techno, that has no actual driving pulse but is all forward momentum. Itâ€™s like Oneohtrix Point Never and John Hopkins wrestling over control of how best to steer and shape an Omni Trio remix. And thatâ€™s a place Iâ€™m very happy to be.

But then another result. Primes is barely a minute long and seems to exist to palette-cleanse as much as anything.

Across the last decade Roberts has earned income and honed skills producing for acts on the pop part of the dance spectrum or at the dance end of the pop spectrum, or however you might say it, people like FKA Twiggs â€“ itâ€™s not just been an earner, itâ€™s been how he has shaped his sound and ideas. Though thereâ€™s no pop remnants here â€“ instead we get â€œserious composerâ€ mode after our intro notes.

White Picket Fence features a wordless soprano voice fitting in and around the debris of a broken techno track. Itâ€™s exhilarating, and again the music rolls over into Act(s), a soft comedown ahead of the next new wave of music â€“ the more playful Joy Squad. Guest vocals are chopped and diced and sprinkled across this song and also Frozen and Shellshock before the very soundtrack-y Hance, our final reset before this brief albumâ€™s longest track, a closing piece of cut-up collage called Strangers.
Itâ€™s sound-art but thereâ€™s always the feeling of forward movement. Itâ€™s dance music but no one would ever actually â€˜danceâ€™ to it. Itâ€™s as serious as Michael Nyman or Philip Glass or Steve Reich but more likely to be embraced by fans of Aphex Twin and Daniel Lopatin and Jenny Hval. I think itâ€™s mesmeric, absolutely wonderful.â€
entries.title: Agor

entries.notes: In 2017, Ctrlâ€”a 14-track project rife with songs about love, sex, self-doubt and heartbreakâ€”became one of the most influential albums in R&B. Ctrl was the soundtrack for many people in their twenties, highlighting the growing pains of young adulthood. SZAâ€™s vulnerability and raw honesty, coupled with ultra-relatable lyrics full of diary-like ruminations and conversations from friend group chats, are what made her debut so impactful. Where Ctrl reflected SZAâ€™s journey towards finding self-love and acceptance, her long-awaited sophomore LP SOS finds the St. Louis-born singer-songwriter dealing with some of the same topics of love and relationships from a more self-assured place. She ditches the uncertainties of her romantic entanglements to save herselfâ€”most of the time. On the soulful and gritty album opener â€œSOSâ€, SZA reintroduces herself and says precisely whatâ€™s on her mind after a night of crying over a lost relationship: â€œI talk bullshit a lot/No more fuck shit, Iâ€™m done,â€ she swaggers. This isnâ€™t the only song that shows her weariness towards relationships that no longer serve her; see also â€œSmoking on My Ex Packâ€ and â€œFarâ€. She finds the confidence to know that she doesnâ€™t need to depend on a man to find happiness on â€œConceitedâ€ and â€œForgivelessâ€. However, not every song on the project is about moving on and leaving her past relationships behind her; SZA still has a penchant for making wrong decisions that may not end well for her (â€œToo Lateâ€, â€œF2Fâ€) and questions her worth in some instances (â€œSpecialâ€). The album sketches the ebbs and flows of emotions, with strength in one moment but deep regret and sadness the next. Thereâ€™s growth between her debut and sophomore album, not just lyrically but sonically as well, blending a mix of her beloved lo-fi beats and sharing space with grunge- and punk-inspired songs without any of it sounding out of place. On the Phoebe Bridgers collaboration â€œGhost in the Machineâ€, the duo take a deeper look at the realities of stardom, looking for a bit of humanity within their day-to-day interactions. The track is not only progressive in its use of strings and acoustic guitars but haunting in its vocal performance. Throughout the journey of SOS, there are moments of clarity and tenderness where SZA goes through the discomfort of healing while trying to find the deeper meaning within the trials and tribulations she endures. She embraces this new level of confidence in her life, where she isnâ€™t looking for anyone to save her from the depth of her emotions but instead is at peace with where sheâ€™s at in life.
entries.title: SOS

entries.notes: Listen to the fourth album by Scotland-born, LA-based Ross Birchard and youâ€™re liable to feel a little overwhelmed. Sugar rush or religious epiphany? The elation of a good roller coaster or the nausea that sets in when the ride loses control? Birchard likes it all, and by the fistful. Nearly a decade out from his public christening as a producer for Kanye West (â€œMercyâ€, â€œBlood on the Leavesâ€) and half of the jock-jam festival phenomenon TNGHT (with Lunice), heâ€™s become the kind of musician it seems like he wanted to be all along: bright, weird, funky, funny and guided by an optimism so irrepressible you wonder if, deep down, he feels a little sad. â€œStumpâ€ is the most beautiful music that didnâ€™t make Blade Runner. â€œBicstanâ€ is Aphex Twin for a seven-year-oldâ€™s birthday party. He can balance tracks as abstract as â€œKpipeâ€ with ones as direct as â€œ3 Sheets to the Windâ€, and the soulful lag of American rap (â€œRedeemâ€) with the momentum of UK bass (â€œRain Shadowâ€, â€œIs It Supposedâ€), not to mention whatever neon-halo hybrid â€œBeholdâ€ is. This is opera for people raised on anime. And as easy as it is to imagine listening in a big, sweaty room, he knows that most of us will end up taking it in alone on headphonesâ€”and he wants us to have fun.

entries.title: For Those I Love

entries.notes: Brittney Parksâ€™ Athena was one of the more interesting albums of 2019. Natural Brown Prom Queen is better. Not only does Parksâ€”aka the LA-based singer, songwriter and violinist Sudan Archivesâ€”sound more idiosyncratic, but sheâ€™s able to wield her idiosyncrasies with more power and purpose. Itâ€™s catchy but not exactly pop (â€œHome Makerâ€), embodied but not exactly R&B (â€œCiaraâ€), weird without ever being confrontational (â€œItâ€™s Already Doneâ€), and it rides the line between live sound and electronic manipulation like it didnâ€™t exist. She wants to practice self-care (â€œSelfish Soulâ€), but she also just wants to â€œhave my titties outâ€ (â€œNBPQ [Topless]â€), and over the course of 55 minutes, she makes you wonder if those arenâ€™t at least sometimes the same thing. And the albumâ€™s sheer variety isnâ€™t so much an expression of what Parks wants to try as the multitudes she already contains.
entries.title: Natural Brown Prom Queen

entries.notes: In early 2021, Tom and Ed Russell were working on a mix for the iconic London club fabric. They knew they wanted a particular tune included, but simply couldnâ€™t find the track anywhere or remember its name. Faced with a deadline and an endless dig through disc logs, the pair changed their approach: They would themselves write the song they could hear. The track became June 2021 single â€œSo U Knoâ€â€”an insidious, addictive banger thatâ€™s a cornerstone of the Russellsâ€™ debut album as Overmono. Itâ€™s an anecdote that reveals a great deal about the brothersâ€™ practical mindset and prodigious abilities. Veterans of the UK dance scene (Tom, the elder Russell, released techno as Truss, while Ed put out drum â€™nâ€™ bass as Tessela), the Welsh-raised producers combine for something special here. Good Lies is an extraordinary electronic record: a genre-defying set glistening with purpose, poise and dance-floor delirium. â€œThe main anchor for the album isnâ€™t genre-based, itâ€™s an emotional place,â€ Ed tells Apple Music. â€œItâ€™s a particular emotional sense that we try and achieve with a lot of our musicâ€”depending on what mood youâ€™re in on that day, you could interpret that state in a few different ways.â€ Tom is able to pinpoint the origins to that â€œemotional ambiguityâ€. â€œI think our formative experiences of partying in the Welsh countryside had a massive impact on us,â€ he says. â€œWhen you have the sun going down and the sun coming up, and those emotions of somewhere between euphoria, slight sadness that the nightâ€™s coming an end but a real sense of optimism that youâ€™re going into a new day. These sorts of weird crossover points are what we try and find in how we put our music together.â€ Read on for the brothersâ€™ track-by-track guide. â€œFeelings Plainâ€ Ed Russell: â€œIt was originally going to close the album. We wanted to see if we could make a sort of plainsong piece of musicâ€”13th-century church music, where someone would be singing one note over and over and then someone else joins in, and everyoneâ€™s singing these cyclical things. But when it all comes together, they start cycling differently and you get this big wash of voices. But we wanted to try and do a sort of R&B take on plainsongâ€”it was one of the songs that had a more conceptual start to it.â€ Tom Russell: â€œIt was the furthest weâ€™d gotten in terms of direct new avenues that we might explore. Itâ€™s a bold statement of intent to start.â€ â€œArla Fearnâ€ ER: â€œWhen did you first write this bassline, Tom?â€ TR: â€œAbout 1976. No, I think it was about 15 years ago.â€ ER: â€œI would tell Tom itâ€™s the best thing heâ€™d ever written. Itâ€™s got so much mood and character and just sounds so satisfying to me.â€ TR: â€œI know Ed meant it as a compliment but I kept on taking it as a bit of a diss really. But I finally gave in.â€ ER: â€œWe spent ages processing the drums and then Tom sampled the Geovarn vocal and came up with the insane outro. The track is at 135 BPM, and by the end itâ€™s at 170 BPM, but you never really notice itâ€™s changedâ€”it just flips the vocal into a different spot. We really wanted the album to be a place where tracks would often morph into something completely different. That itâ€™s bubbling over with ideas.â€ â€œGood Liesâ€ ER: â€œWe went through a phase of trying not to sample every Smerz song because they just had so many good hooks. Theyâ€™re incredible at writing these top lines that sound straight off early-2000s garage records, but not in a pastiche way. We had the vocal from [2018 Smerz track] â€œNo harmâ€ and spent a lot of time chopping it into the phrasing we wanted and creating a hook out of this little section that had jumped out at us. The demo for the instrumental then came together in a day, but there was an 18-month, almost two-year period from writing the demo to coming back and starting to really chip away at it.â€ â€œGood Lies (Outro)â€ TR: â€œWhen we were writing the â€˜Good Liesâ€™ instrumental, we thought weâ€™d see if we could flip it and turn the vibe on its head into something moodier. Itâ€™s always going back to that ambiguity with us. Thereâ€™s something of that in the Good Lies title. What constitutes a good lie?â€ â€œWalk Thru Waterâ€ (feat. St. Panther) TR: â€œEd was at my studio in February [2022], and we were battening down the hatches for Storm Eunice.â€ ER: â€œIt was this quite nice feeling of, â€˜All right, thereâ€™s a storm coming, weâ€™ve got loads of snacks and a few drinks, the place to ourselves, and we canâ€™t go anywhere.â€™ Tom had written these really beautiful chords and Iâ€™d kept saying I wanted to do something with them. We got really stoned while the rain was coming down, listening to these chords, and we came across the St. Panther vocal.â€ TR: â€œI then started doing the beat on the Pulsarâ€”which is a drum machine thatâ€™s quite difficult to tame but on certain things it just works beautifully.â€ â€œCold Bloodedâ€ TR: â€œThis started out as something quite different. It dawned on us that weâ€™d written this massive IDM tune.â€ ER: â€œIt was a bit too nice, wasnâ€™t it?â€ TR: â€œIt was this late-â€™90s breakdance thingâ€”not really the vibe we should be going for.â€ ER: â€œI had this Kindora sample that Iâ€™d wanted to use for ages, and then Tom sent me this slowed-down version of â€˜Cold Bloodedâ€™ with the new drums and I realised itâ€™d be fucking killer. It then became a month of last-minute adjustments, which we sometimes get ourselves into a bit of a hole with. Tweaking everything until the last.â€ â€œSkulledâ€ ER: â€œWe had the Kelly Erez sample put away into our sample folder. And then we built a drum machineâ€”a copy of a â€™70s drum machine called the Syncussion, made by Pearl, the drum kit manufacturer. It [the Syncussion] was meant to sound like a normal drum kit, and it sounds so far away from real drums itâ€™s insane. We spent a couple of weeks trying to make our version sound like weâ€™d soldered it not quite right. It has this weird, sort of dry, alien, â€™80s vibe to it. Like with all our stuff, itâ€™s processed so heavily.â€ TR: â€œEd has come up with this mad compression chain, which you can basically put any sort of drums into and you get this massive wall of noise.â€ ER: â€œI said earlier the best thing Tom has written was the bassline on â€˜Arla Fearnâ€™, but Iâ€™ve changed my mind now: Itâ€™s the piano outro to â€˜Skulledâ€™. We both loved the idea of the song ending like a classic balladâ€”a CÃ©line Dion tune.â€ â€œSugarushhhâ€ TR: â€œWe liked the idea of trying to shoehorn in a screaming 303 to the album somewhere.â€ ER: â€œTomâ€™s good at doing these quite irregular things that you donâ€™t immediately notice. This, if you actually count it out, is in some weird time signature and itâ€™s cycling every nine bars. It was also really important that we had this abrasive, aggressive 303 line being offset completely with a really beautiful vocal.â€ â€œCalonâ€ ER: â€œTom played me the first iteration of this in the back of a van on the way to a festival in Minehead. Weâ€™ve sampled Joe Trufant a few times before and we liked the idea of there being a few familiar voices on the album.â€ TR: â€œWe then hired a studio in Ibiza and Ed had the idea of making the beat much slower. It became this big, slowed-down house tuneâ€”it dropped to something like 110 BPM.â€ ER: â€œWe were in a US club sound-checking and played through some tunes from the album. Hearing it on the club system we were like, â€˜Fuck me!â€™ Itâ€™s this sneaky banger.â€ â€œIs Uâ€ ER: â€œWeâ€™ve both been massive Tirzah fans since the start, and one day the â€˜All I want is youâ€™ line from â€˜Gladlyâ€™ just jumped out of the speaker at us. We then spent ages trying to make the beat on this mono machine we have, which has all these really shit â€™80s drum samples. We just mangled them until we had the beat, and then chopped up the vocal to get what we felt was a really strong and more confrontational delivery. Tom then put these lush chords in the breakdown and it opens the track up, like the sun coming out from behind a cloud.â€ TR: â€œItâ€™s amazing when a track starts to take on a life of its own. Playing this out and seeing the reaction gives me goosebumps every time.â€ â€œVermonlyâ€ ER: â€œA lot of our tracks will be written on just one piece of gear and we see what you can do with it. I had bought Tom a synth for his birthday, but when I gave it to him he said he wasnâ€™t going to be in the studio for a few days, so I asked if I could take the synth I had just given him. I sent him a really rough 16-bar loop with the main melodic ideas, and he did the rest, really.â€ TR: â€œTracks like this are really important to us. They might get lost on an EP. Itâ€™s not always about writing dance-floor bangers.â€ â€œSo U Knoâ€ ER: â€œWe were doing this mix for fabric and we both knew we wanted a very particular tune in the mix but couldnâ€™t find it. So we basically just thought, â€˜Fuck it, itâ€™ll be quicker to write something ourselves.â€™ I had a chopped-up vocal and a rough beat going, played it to Tom, who went straight over to a Jupiter-6 synth and immediately played the bassline before doing the same with the chords.â€ â€œCalling Outâ€ TR: â€œEd had suggested to try and sample something by slowthai and I managed to find this little [section] I really liked from quite an obscure track called â€˜Dead Leavesâ€™. I loved the line â€˜Iâ€™m like the sun, I rise up and then gone.â€™ Then we combined it with a CASISDEAD and dâ€™Eon sample and it really started to make sense. I have a tendency to overcomplicate things, but Ed is often able to say, â€˜We donâ€™t need thatâ€™, or â€˜Change a snare from there to thereâ€™. A tiny idea or decision can make such a huge difference.â€ ER: â€œI remember when Tom sent me the chords for the end and I felt like it reminded me of old Radioheadâ€”the perfect way to close the album.â€
entries.title: Good Lies

entries.notes: The polymathâ€™s mixtape is serpentine and exquisite. Hear it in Spatial Audio.
entries.title: CAPRISONGS

entries.notes: In the context of NilÃ¼fer Yanyaâ€™s second album, the word â€œpainlessâ€ has a few different meanings. â€œI was enjoying the process of making the record, and thinking, â€˜Why do you have to beat yourself up in order to make something?â€™â€ the London singer/guitarist tells Apple Music. â€œObviously, you have to work hard, but often the idea of really struggling is something that people inflict on others, just because it's the idea they sell to them, like, â€˜Oh, you need to go through this.â€™â€ Yanya felt that she hadn't given herself enough time and space to make her 2019 debut, Miss Universeâ€”a record based loosely, and playfully, around the concept of self-help and wellness, and what happens when you get too in your head about things. So, in the thick of the pandemic, she eased into making PAINLESS, writing the songs more collaborativelyâ€”mostly with producer Will Archerâ€”than she had been used to. â€œI kind of felt a bit like, â€˜Am I cheating?â€™ Because you're sharing the work, it feels lighter,â€ she says. "But then because of that, I kind of delved in deeper and it got a bit darker.â€ (The album title actually comes from the â€œshamelessâ€ lyric â€œUntil you fall, it's painless.â€) Those depths can be felt both in Yanya's vocal dynamics and the sense of urgency that underpins much of the album, particularly on opener â€œthe dealerâ€ and â€œstabiliseâ€, the first single. â€œI think the rhythm plays a big part in these songs,â€ Yanya says. â€œYou feel like there needs to be an escape somewhere.â€ Here Yanya talks through PAINLESS, track by track. â€œthe dealerâ€ â€œIt's like when someone's hiding behind their layers, or not being honest, but then also you're not being honest with yourself. My favourite lyric is 'I hope it's just the summertime you grew attached to,' because it's like you're lying to yourself. Youâ€™re not saying, 'Oh, it was this person that made the difference, or it was this person that I miss.' You're just saying, 'I had a great time,' and you're not being honest about why.â€ â€œL/Râ€ â€œ[Producer] Bullion played me this beat, and it had this pitched drum in it. It just made me feel really happy and warm. It had this kind of marching feeling to it, which I really liked. It took us like a year to finish it, but the initial idea came really quickly. I like the almost spoken element to it, because it sounds like you're speaking rather than singing, but then the chorus is very much singingâ€”and it took a while to get that right. It's kind of about so many things. In my notebook at the time, I'd written, 'Do less things'â€”like, less is more. That was my thinking behind the song: trying to enjoy simple things and not overcomplicate things.â€ â€œshamelessâ€ â€œIt's a really intimate song. I felt like it was about someone that's trying to run away from stuff in their life, but they kind of don't have much hope. The vocals are very celestialâ€”not something I really experimented with in the past. At first, I was going to kind of speak the words, but it needed a lighter touch, like something even more delicate.â€ â€œstabiliseâ€ â€œThat was the first one me and Will did together. All the others kind of grew off that song. It's about environments and the way they impact you, and not being able to escape your environment, taking it with you wherever you go. And it kind of becomes your cage or the way you view things. You know when you've been somewhere too long and then it's hard to imagine the world another way? Definitely a very lockdown song.â€ â€œchase meâ€ â€œI really liked the line 'Through corridors your love will chase me,' because it was like the safe feeling you can get when you know you are loved, but you don't necessarily want it. It's almost like an ego song for me. It's very confident.â€ â€œmidnight sunâ€ â€œI was digging into more of an overall feeling and a mood. I feel like it's a song about confidence and finding your own voice in order to speak up, whether that's about your own feelings or bigger issues: â€˜I can't keep my mouth shut this time. I can't keep my head down. I'm not going along with this anymore.â€™â€ â€œtroubleâ€ â€œThat song is so sadâ€”in a beautiful way, if I may say so. It also felt like quite a brave one for me because it's very different. When I was writing, I was like, 'Am I doing a straight-up pop song?' It's not. I think it definitely has that take on it. The vocals needed to be more intimate. Like one voice, and it just all keeps spilling out. It's quite challenging to sing. â€˜Troubleâ€™ is one of those wordsâ€”I think I heard it in a Cat Stevens songâ€”'Trouble, set me free'â€”and I really loved the way it was being referred to almost like a person. In the lyrics here, it's something that's quite persistent and it's not going away. Something's definitely broken that you can't fix.â€ â€œtryâ€ â€œThis one is about getting better, and feeling the need to connect on a deeper level, finding new depths and making new connections, but becoming confused, tired and dejected with the effort it takes.â€ â€œcompanyâ€ â€œIt's about giving up and you're not in a happy place. Originally it started out as, like, you're in a relationship that you are just really not sure about and you're trying to give signs across that you're trying to get rid of someone. But I think the song now is definitely about your inner demons, and they're not really going away.â€ â€œbelong with youâ€ â€œI did this with Jazzi Bobbi, who's in my band. She does more electronic stuff, so that definitely comes into play. I feel like builds are always my favourite things in songs, and at the beginning we actually tried to overcomplicate the song and there was like a whole other section and it changed tempo and it just wasn't working. And I was like, 'We just need to keep building and that's it.' What it's about is like you're tied into something, but you know you're too good for it or you want to leave. I feel like these are all the songs, in a way. Itâ€™s like, escapeâ€”but you can't escape.â€ â€œthe mysticâ€ â€œIt's about watching other people get on with their lives and feeling like you're being left behind. I spend a lot of time doing music, so that's where I put all my energy, and I was like, 'Oh, I thought we were all still doing that.' Other people have got other plans and you're like, 'Oh, you're a grown-up. You're going to move in with your boyfriend,' or, 'Oh, you can drive now.' The verse is really sad, because it's about watching that happen, and feeling very insecure and unconfident.â€ â€œanotherlifeâ€ â€œFor me, this has a completely different energy. It's kind of like you're admitting you're lost now, but in a parallel universe or in the future, you won't always be lost. It's not always bad to be in that kind of lost, super-emotional, flung-out state. I find sometimes when something bad happens and you get really upset, it's kind ofâ€” I don't want to say cleansing, but you see things with this new kind of brilliance and clarity. And that's kind of a beautiful moment.â€

entries.notes:
Pitchfork: 

â€œAfter experiments in free jazz and psychedelia, the UK producer reckons with the rave music of his youth. Itâ€™s a utopian project that melds dance musicâ€™s forms with an organic sensibility.

Drop the needle at any given point on James Holdenâ€™s fourth album, and you might think the music is building toward carefully orchestrated catharsis: the moment when the big melody finally drops in, or the various rhythms cohere into a single body-moving lockstep, and the crowd loses its collective mind. There were plenty of those moments in Holdenâ€™s earlier work, when he was a young DJ making sweeping trance and progressive techno anthems. But time and time again on Imagine This Is a High Dimensional Space of All Possibilities, the climax turns out to be an illusion. A filter sweep reaches its apex to reveal the full glowing resonance of a particular synth, and you realize the pulse of its chord progression has been working at cross purposes with the rest of the track, pulling you away from its patient groove rather than toward it. A strobe-lit rave piano arrives just in time for the drums to drop out entirely. 

Holden has said that the album is his attempt to recreate the sense of hearing, as a teenager, far-off pirate radio broadcasts of early UK dance music, the soundtracks to a woolly and utopian rave scene that had largely dried up by the time he was old enough to make music professionally and had to settle for more slickly commercial sounds. Thematically, this is not so different from the territory where Burial has made his career, summoning the atmospheres of emptied-out warehouse parties and solitary walks home. Rather than mourning a paradise lost, Holden instead focuses on the joy and freedom his younger self imagined those ravers must have been feeling. Every individual sound is as bright and welcoming as can be. Itâ€™s the way that these sounds cohereâ€”or more often, refuse toâ€”that suggests a certain distance. The albumâ€™s new-agey title may provoke eye rolls in some listeners, but the first word poignantly grounds it. If we have to imagine that this is a place where everything is possible, it probably isnâ€™t in reality. 

By the time of Holdenâ€™s first album, 2006â€™s The Idiots Are Winning, he was already dislodging himself from the club; his third, 2017â€™s The Animal Spirits, looked like a final break, with Holden leading a full live band on excursions into free jazz and Terry Riley-ish minimalism. His full-lengths have also reflected a growing interest in oblique, free-flowing rhythms, seemingly inspired by the unpredictable complexity of the natural world rather than the mechanistic precision of much dance music. While High Dimensional Space on one level represents a return to the timbres of clubland, it retains this organic sensibility. Acoustic instruments like saxophone and tabla punctuate â€œCommon Landâ€ and â€œContains Multitudes,â€ respectively. The latter also plays with your expectation that the sounds of electronic dance music will stick to their own narrowly defined bands of the frequency range and roles in the larger arrangement. One particular keyboard ostinato begins in the middle, and traverses down to sub-bass depths and up to piercing heights over the course of the track. Listening closely is like watching a time lapse of a treeâ€™s roots bursting through the sidewalk. 

The quality of the rhythms across the album, each developing concurrently at its own pace rather than in strict alignment, mirrors the fragmentary timelines of nature as well. â€œTrust Your Feetâ€ comes tantalizingly close to ecstatic release, its arpeggios percolating onward past the juncture where they might have locked in with the other instruments to deliver a satisfying payoff. Witnessing waterfalls and sunsets, thereâ€™s no single perfect moment when all the elements come together and make their mysterious relationships clear; this music works similarly, absorbing you in the whole of its trajectory rather than any specific waypoint. 

The lack of definitive resolutions can make the album at times difficult to really love, rather than just appreciate or admire, despite the musicâ€™s unflagging optimism. The rare moments when everything does come together are the ones that move me the most: the tumbling snare drum and burbling modular synth of â€œContinuous Revolution,â€ rushing together toward a horizon we never quite glimpse; the droning violins and unexpectedly funky bass guitar of â€œWorlds Collide, Mountains Form,â€ which sound a bit like what might happen if the ancient architects of Stonehenge decided to form a jam band. In between these set pieces, the full enjoyment of Imagine This Is a High Dimensional Space of All Possibilities requires some imagination of your own, a sort of listening past the vaporous surface of the music. Like teenage Holden at the radio, you may sense a magical world there, just beyond what you can hear. â€œ
entries.title: Imagine This Is a High Dimensional Space of All Possibilities

entries.notes: Perfect music for COVID 19 at home working. And occasionally you think what a really great track that is. But other tracks are mediocre at best. Mixed bag but still good material from the guys that came up with Tosca afterwards...

Where KICK ii delves into the lurching, snapping grooves of reggaetÃ³n, KicK iii applies an even more forceful touch to experimental beats that zigzag between futuristic club rhythms and vintage IDM. The strutting â€œBrujaâ€ fires merciless ballroom salvos over car-crash drums and apocalyptic synth squeal; â€œIncendioâ€ twists Arcaâ€™s perpetually morphing vocals over drums that punch like Brazilian funk carioca or Portuguese batida; and â€œMorboâ€ dissolves into a gooey morass of slow-motion techno. From there, things just get more unpredictable: The shuddering beats of â€œFieraâ€ and â€œRipplesâ€ feel like theyâ€™re coming apart at the seams, while the shimmering melody of â€œSkullqueenâ€ channels mid-â€™90s Aphex Twin, long a latent influence on Arcaâ€™s fractured syncopations. But the storm clouds part for the closing â€œJoyaâ€: Over soft, feathery chimes, she sings sweetly, â€œI want to tell you/You are a jewel among men/I feel so much love.â€ After so much violent turmoil, to let us down so gently feels like an act of kindness.
entries.title: KicK iii

entries.notes:
Duncan Bellamy and Jack Wyllie had a more productive lockdown than most in 2020. The drummer and saxophonist pair, who make up the London-based jazz and electronic group Portico Quartet, recorded two albums in only a matter of months. The first, Terrain, arrived in May 2021 and is a three-track, minimalist exploration of melodic loops and textural atmospheres. It is followed by Monument, a concise encapsulation of the Portico Quartet sound. Where Terrain dug into lengthy meditative compositions, Monument traverses everything from the driving groove of â€œImpressionsâ€ to the krautrock-referencing â€œUltravioletâ€ and the strings-laden, cinematic melodies of â€œOn the Lightâ€. â€œThere isnâ€™t much wastage in Monument,â€ saxophonist Wyllie tells Apple Music. â€œIt feels like this sculptural, composed exploration of our sound and evolution over the years.â€ Read on for his thoughts on the album, track by track.
â€œOpeningâ€ â€œOur process generally works with us individually building ideas over the course of a month and then in the following month we work together to make them into tunes. This track began with an idea that Duncan had and that I added some sax and synth to, as well as recorded strings. We did a lot of studio work on it afterwards by running it back through delays to give it a sense of space and ambience.â€
â€œImpressionsâ€ â€œThis is a recognisably Portico Quartet tune, featuring the hang drum, which is a key part of the identity of the band. It's similar to the track â€˜Ruinsâ€™ from our third album, but this is more up front and direct. There's a nice contrast between the rhythmic groove that is quite big and then the sax, which is played very gently. There's a load of vocal samples that we sang on too in the background. All of that helps make up its ambient textures.â€
â€œUltravioletâ€ â€œThis is contrastingly quite different from our earlier music. It's got a krautrock groove to it, as well as that pitched saxophone at the start and the Prophet synth line that Duncan's playing. At this point in the record, we felt like you need to have a bit of propulsion, since you've come out of the intro into something quite up front and now you want to keep on driving through.â€
â€œEver Presentâ€ â€œDuncan wrote the piano part, and I liked the simplicity of it. We put it back through some modulated reverb to give it a woozy effect, and then my saxophone melody references our earlier work with its melodic economy. Duncan's playing bass on it as wellâ€”itâ€™s quite busy underneath the melody, but it fits together nicely.â€
â€œGatewayâ€ â€œWe didn't have any interludes on the album at first, but after we sent it in to the record label, they said it felt slightly too full-on and needed a bit of space to breathe. We had already written this hang drum melody and the one on â€˜Portalâ€™, which we then slid into the track listing. It gives the album a different pace and allowed it to be an easier listen.â€
â€œMonumentâ€ â€œThis started with a vocal loop, in a similar feel to an earlier track of ours called â€˜Endlessâ€™. I added a very simple melodic sax sound to the loop that is then quite heavily manipulated through effects pedals. The whole song is supposed to feel like a journey, where the listener is taken through these different sonic worlds and ends up in an entirely new space.â€
â€œA.O.Eâ€ â€œThe connection between the tracks and their titles is sometimes so abstract for usâ€”we just go with whatever feels like it works. We spend so long doing them; it could take three months to write the album and three months to do the sequencing and titles. This stands for â€˜Age of Enlightenmentâ€™, since Duncan and I were both reading an article about it at the time. It's one of my favourite tunes, since I really like how it cuts between these two sections, switching from electronic drums to acoustic drums and then the soaring sax and cello melody.â€
â€œWarm Dataâ€ â€œAfter we've separately worked with each other's ideas, we usually go to a recording studio and turn them into pieces of music by re-recording everything. With â€˜Warm Dataâ€™, we jammed most of it in a studio that had a Steinway piano. We improvised along to a groove that Duncan had already written, and then after we'd recorded it, we chopped it up and made it more coherent.â€
â€œPortalâ€ â€œWe probably could have turned â€˜Gatewayâ€™ and â€˜Portalâ€™ into more fleshed-out tunes of their own, but they fit on this album perfectly as interludes. They are both hang drum melodies processed through reverb and delay. They're functional tracks, but they are also essential to the listening experience of the record as a whole.â€
â€œOn the Lightâ€ â€œThis is classic Portico territory. Duncan initially wrote the drum and bass grooves and then I built the melodies on top. It's a really nice way to finish the record, since the strings come in at the end and elevate it into a cinematic feel. It was lovely to have the strings players Simmy Singh and Francesca Ter-Berg in the studio with us, helping with the arrangements. It's a celebratory way to end the album.â€
entries.title: Monument

entries.notes: When Jessie Ware wrote â€œRemember Where You Areâ€â€”the final song on her career-altering 2020 record Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure?â€”she knew sheâ€™d unlocked the sound of her future. â€œI think I finally understood my place in music,â€ she tells Apple Music. â€œI felt like I was combining all my loves, from musical theatre to soul, groove, dance and funk to R&B and orchestral moments and group vocals. I wanted to do â€˜Remember Where You Areâ€™, but with a big old dance beat.â€ Thatâ€™s more or less what you can expect from That! Feels Good!, on which the London singer-songwriter doubles down on her devotion the dance floor andâ€”after the varnished opulence of Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure?â€”embraces a looser, louder, more live sound. Itâ€™s (almost) all up, with brass and string arrangements, choruses of voices, very winking lyrics and, perhaps most surprisingly, rapping Ã  la Blondie or Tom Tom Club. â€œMy voice was always the thing, which is fabulous,â€ says Ware (who, of course, also belts out plenty of elastic vocals here). â€œBut for me it was like, â€˜Letâ€™s see what else Iâ€™ve got.â€™â€ Made with â€¦Pleasure collaborators James Ford, Clarence Coffee Jr., Shungudzo and Danny Parker, plus UK producer Stuart Price (Madonna, Kylie Minogue, The Killers, Pet Shop Boys), That! Feels Good! was powered by the roaring success of its predecessor. Released during the pandemic, the disco-fuelled Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure? became an antidote for many during lockdown, and earned Ware a British Album of the Year BRIT Award nomination, a support slot on tour with Harry Styles and an army of new fans. All of which gave her the confidence to just keep having fun. â€œI felt like Iâ€™d been granted permission to let loose and show all sides of myself,â€ says Ware. â€œI wanted it to feel free, and I think that was indicative of how I was feeling. This record was about celebration and joy. I wanted it to feel like the sexiest slap around the face.â€ Read on as Ware walks us through That! Feels Good!, one song at a time. â€œThat! Feels Good!â€ â€œI needed it to feel like you landed straight into a groove, which is very different to how I started Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure?. It felt like I was imagining me as Dâ€™Angelo or James Brown. With the spoken thing at the start of this track, Iâ€™d said to [producer] James Ford, â€˜Letâ€™s really enjoy this intro: What do you think about [including] loads of different people so it felt like were in an orgy?â€™ It was about making people feel slightly uncomfortable, particularly British people, and to make you go, â€˜Hang on, what is she about to do?â€™ Those voices are RoÃ­sÃ­n Murphy, Kylie Minogue, Aisling Bea, Jamie Demetriou, Gemma Arterton, benny blanco, my mum [Lennie Ware; Jessieâ€™s co-host on their podcast Table Manners), my [podcast] producer Alice and her husband, who speak French, because they sounded really good, an ex-boyfriend whoâ€™s Spanish and Clara Amfo. We got them all!â€ â€œFree Yourselfâ€ â€œWe nearly didnâ€™t write this song. It was the first day Iâ€™d worked with Stuart [Price], and heâ€™d played this house song but I felt it was a bit too close to Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure?. Respect to Stuart, because he never gives up and said, â€˜Can we just listen to that instrumental again?â€™ We put the vocal down just to see what happened and then Coffee [London-based songwriter and producer Clarence Coffee Jr.] sang, â€˜Free yourselfâ€™â€”and it was really fun. Me and Coffee went and celebrated afterâ€”we had tequila and toasted the song because it felt like it was going to change things.â€ â€œPearlsâ€ â€œIt felt very camp and soulful, immediate, bombastic, glorious and fun. Itâ€™s saying, â€˜Here are some of the ladies Iâ€™m going to be on this record.â€™ The lyric â€˜And I do what I wanna/A perfect prima donnaâ€™ is said with a wink because I know that I can play up to the role of being a pop star when I need to, but I never take myself too seriously. And when I say prima donna, itâ€™s very much playing with the notion of women being thought of a certain way when they have an opinion, but also acknowledging that I am quite perfect at being a bit of a diva. Hopefully I donâ€™t do it for too long!â€ â€œHello Loveâ€ â€œI needed there to be a breather because I didnâ€™t want people to feel exhausted by those first three songs, which are supposed to hit hard and feel like a bang. I hope this song lives on forever, because it feels quintessentially me, but with me having grown with experience in writing. Itâ€™s me tapping into romance and Donny Hathaway and soul music and groove like The Gap Band. Iâ€™m a sucker for a love song, but I wanted to do one that didnâ€™t feel like a ballad per se. I also kind of wanted this to feel like the opportunity for a new first-dance song [at weddings], because I feel like everyoneâ€™s been using â€˜Champagne Kissesâ€™ and â€˜Say You Love Meâ€™, but theyâ€™re both really sad songs so they should just give up on those and do this one.â€ â€œBegin Againâ€ â€œâ€˜Begin Againâ€™ is the pathway from Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure? into That! Feels Good!. Itâ€™s where this album startedâ€”and was written over Zoom between LA and Hackney. The lyric â€˜Why does all the purest love get filtered through machines?â€™ probably came from thatâ€”Iâ€™m sick to death of Zooms! But if you think further into it, itâ€™s about being a prisoner to screens and it becoming so habitual and wanting to escape that, but not being able to. It was very much inspired by Stevie Wonderâ€™s â€˜Another Starâ€™ and Talking Headsâ€™ Stop Making Sense, and bossa nova, Brazilian disco and longing for travel.â€ â€œBeautiful Peopleâ€ â€œI wanted this song to feel like it went from a monologue into a conversation. That there was a bit of a narrative, however fantasy-led that was. You go from talking yourself out of a crap day to going to a club and feeling free and happy. I think thatâ€™s what dance music, particularly going clubbing, can be, and I love that feelingâ€”thereâ€™s nothing greater. But as a mother of three, who also works insanely hard, clubbing isnâ€™t on the agenda every week. This was my way of transporting myself to that place.â€ â€œFreak Me Nowâ€ â€œStuart made this instrumental and he was adamant that we were going to use it. This song has kind of French house nods and I was thinking about how RÃ³isÃ­n Murphy would say something, as well as Mousse T.â€™s â€˜Hornyâ€™ and Gwen McCraeâ€™s â€˜Keep the Fire Burningâ€™. Itâ€™s another commanding song like â€˜Free Yourselfâ€™ and Iâ€™m in the driverâ€™s seatâ€”itâ€™s not requesting, itâ€™s like this personâ€™s going to have to do it. That was a really fun position to be in.â€ â€œShake the Bottleâ€ â€œThis is almost my cabaret song. Itâ€™s highly camp and itâ€™s me as a â€˜madameâ€™ and is just really fun. It was like, â€˜How far can we push this innuendo?â€™ It feels more like a performance piece. I really hope all my queens that lip-sync like this, because I think I made it for lip-syncers. Iâ€™m in awe of the performance and I so respect drag and the creativity and the confidence. I feel so loved and cherished by a beautiful community and theyâ€™re always in my mind, particularly because we have so much fun together. I feel very lucky to have an incredibly strong following from the LGBTQ community. Theyâ€™ve made me a better performer.â€ â€œLightningâ€ â€œI was definitely leaning into a more R&B moment: This pulled from Sade, Madlib, Drake. There needed to be a bit of space on the record to just take a moment, but I also wanted to feel like it could connect with the rest of the album. This is my husbandâ€™s favourite tune: itâ€™s sex, itâ€™s languid, itâ€™s a bit of a breather. Maybe itâ€™s also the end of the night when the party is starting to die out and itâ€™s just you and somebody else. It has a vulnerability.â€ â€œThese Lipsâ€ â€œI wanted it to feel like there was Earth, Wind & Fire on this, or Minnie Riperton. It felt right to finish with this spoken-word thing at the end, which is me trying to do my little Gil Scott-Heron moment. But itâ€™s also got the celebratory and dramatic backing vocals. It felt optimistic, and like the groove carried on, but thereâ€™s also ceremony and dramaâ€”thatâ€™s how I wanted to leave people. It felt like a blissful, sensual ending.â€
entries.title: That! Feels Good!

entries.notes: Phenomenal performance from multi-instrumentalist Nils Frahm. Especially the track Fundamental Values.
