entries.notes: The most jarring part about listening to the London band black midi isnâ€™t how much musical ground they coverâ€”post-punk, progressive rock, breakneck jazz, cabaretâ€”but the fact that they cover it all at once. A quasi-concept album that seems to have something to do with war (â€œWelcome to Hellâ€, â€œ27 Questionsâ€), or at least the violence men do more generally (â€œSugar/Tzuâ€, â€œDangerous Liaisonsâ€), Hellfire isnâ€™t an easy listen. But itâ€™s funny (main character: Tristan Bongo), beautiful, at least in a garish, misanthropic way (the Neil Diamond bombast of â€œThe Defenceâ€), and so obviously playful in its intelligence that you just want to let it run over you. The first listen feels like being yelled at in a language you donâ€™t understand. By the third, youâ€™ll be yelling with them.
entries.title: Hellfire

entries.notes:
Like Lâ€™Rain, Fatigue is marbled with personal recordings: Dishes being washed in the sink beneath a piano melody on â€œNeed Be,â€ a voicemail from her mother buried in â€œBlame Me.â€ The clips imbue the music with fleeting traces of closeness and familiarity. Cheek approaches them from a distance, recontextualizing some of the most heartfelt or difficult moments of her life in song. The mercurial, six-minute highlight â€œFind Itâ€ begins downcast, with a metronomic synth loop and the repeated mantra, â€œMake a way out of no way.â€ Screams echo through the sluggish beat as coming through a wall; the dust settles on an organist and singer performing the gospel song â€œI Wonâ€™t Complain,â€ recorded at the funeral of a family friend. Cheek intones over it until the song crests in a rapturous, overwhelming finale, with no less than 13 musicians contributing to the commotion. Itâ€™s easily the most poignant song she has ever made, a deeply felt, Biblically minded portrait of forging a path out of darkness. Yet the journey has room for lightness and humor, too, like the â€œoopsâ€ that slips into the end of â€œWalk Throughâ€ or the wacky vocal affect of a former roommate on â€œLove Her.â€ On the brief â€œBlack Clapâ€ and the rhythmic, low-lit â€œSuck Teeth,â€ Cheek incorporates the percussive sounds of a handclap game she made up with multi-instrumentalist Ben Chapoteau-Katz, a way to pay tribute to the joyful sound of childhood hand games played by Black girls.

Cheek upends expectations in more direct pop and dance traditions, too. On â€œTwo Face,â€ a roving piano line and stuttering samples melt into a soulful, psychedelic throb as she ruminates on a failed friendship. â€œI canâ€™t build no new nothing no new life no new nothing for me,â€ she trills in a singsong cadence, the words bouncing over oscillated coos. The lyrics on the tense â€œKill Selfâ€ are even more unforgiving: â€œDid you see me chew myself out?â€ she asks, voice rippling in a cascade over shuffling percussion. â€œHear the gnawing?â€ At once the albumâ€™s darkest and most propulsive moment, â€œKill Selfâ€ eventually assumes a seething dancefloor pulse, bending skillfully toward structure without abandoning Cheekâ€™s wandering impulses.

Fatigue ends with the beatific â€œTake Two,â€ a spare reconfiguration of â€œBatâ€ from Lâ€™Rain. She repurposes the song in a similar way to her field recordings, as raw material to mold into an unfamiliar shape. Stripped bare of percussion and transformed into an airy, droning spiritual, Cheekâ€™s voice unfurls in billowy, Auto-Tuned tones as she repeats the words, â€œI am not prepared for what is going to happen to me.â€ In her skyward voice, the sentiment is more life-affirming than terrifying, suggestive of infinite possibilities. There is no fixed road toward healing, Fatigue reassures us; there is only the way forward.
entries.title: Fatigue

entries.notes: I especially like the Klezmer sound in both the opening and closing track. Interesting album that gets better with every additional listening.
entries.title: For the first time

entries.notes:
This is just a phenomenal album from a phenomenal artist. Except for the country tack. Branch died last year because of an overdose but I will definitely revisit her previous albums.

From Pitchfork:
â€œ(world war))â€™s most striking departure from branchâ€™s previous work comes in â€œthe mountain,â€ the aforementioned country tune, a reworking of â€œCominâ€™ Downâ€ by Arizona twang-punks the Meat Puppets that is drastic and inspired enough to merit its new title. In stark contrast to the rest of the albumâ€™s rollicking maximalism, its instrumental accompaniment consists almost entirely of Jason Ajemianâ€™s pizzicato double bass. Ajemian sings lead, and branch harmonizes. Neither is a virtuosic singer, but showiness is not the point. The lyric, about the fitful search to transcend everyday toil, monotony, and misunderstanding, benefits from the humility of their performance. The recording is as sparse and unslick as could be: We hear collective deep breaths, a bit of branch muttering to psyche herself up, the sound of the two musicians physically shifting around the microphone. Given the bare-bones arrangement, branchâ€™s trumpet solo, when it arrives near the songâ€™s end, comes as a delightful surprise, even on an album by a trumpeter. Thereâ€™s something jaunty and insouciant about the soloâ€™s plainness, especially the simple three-note run that provides its emotional climax, coming at a spot where another player might have attempted a more impressively elaborate gesture. Its self-assuredness and refusal to bow to anyone elseâ€™s ideas about presentability obliquely bring to mind the cocked baseball cap that branch often wore onstage.â€
entries.title: Fly or Die Fly or Die Fly or Die ((World War))

entries.notes: Thereâ€™s a haunting intensity and rare poetic beauty about Ryuichi Sakamotoâ€™s blend of ambient sounds, stripped down to the bare essentials of melody and rhythm. And for all its simplicity, this is an album that is profoundly moving. His dozen pieces, created spontaneously in March 2021 during the early stages of convalescence from major cancer surgery, speak of lifeâ€™s fragility and of musicâ€™s power to comfort, console, even to heal. It feels almost intrusive at first to listen to what originated as private musical thoughts, conceived on synthesiser and piano out of an innate need for the presence of pure, unadorned sounds. Sakamotoâ€™s choice of 12 favourite sketches, each named for its date of composition, charts the stages of his recovery, from pieces infused with his laboured breathing to a sublime final sequence of impressionistic miniatures.
On Piano day, Nils Frahm surprisingly released this album with tracks from 10 years old.
entries.title: Graz

entries.notes: â€œThis album is all about contrasts,â€ Wevalâ€™s Harm Coolen tells Apple Music. â€œItâ€™s mixing in-your-face, heavy dance music with a joyful hopefulness to make you move.â€ Since forming in 2012, Dutch duo Harm Coolen and Merijn Scholte Albers have been crafting melodically intricate electronic tracks with an underlying acoustic warmth. Theirs is a sound full of earworming melodies and luscious arrangements, producing 2016â€™s self-titled debut album and The Weight in 2019. On their latest release, Remember, they pay homage to their decade in music by piecing together fragments of long-standing unreleased songs with fresh, emphatic production. The result is 11 infectiously energetic tracks, from the soaring vocal hooks of â€œNever Stay for Loveâ€ to the earthy funk of â€œEverything Went Wellâ€ and the distorted rhythms of â€œLosing Daysâ€. â€œItâ€™s a propulsive record but one with a positive feeling,â€ Coolen says. â€œItâ€™s made from the longing to play loud and to let people have fun with the music.â€ Read on for Coolen and Albersâ€™ in-depth thoughts on the album, track by track. â€œRememberâ€ Harm Coolen: â€œâ€˜Rememberâ€™ is one of the final tracks we made for the record. We had been working on the album for three and a half years already but we were still searching for new ideas to help round out its contrasts.â€ Merijn Scholte Albers: â€œWe were on the road in LA and stopped into the studio to jam with our friend, producer Daniel Lynas. It was meant to just be a hang but then we came up with the stems for â€˜Rememberâ€™. It had a perfect, positive feeling and, once we got back home, we built the vocal line and knew it would be the ideal opener.â€ â€œEverything Went Wellâ€ HC: â€œOver the summer, we spent a week in Germany with a group of other artist friendsâ€”this was one of the tracks we wrote there. Iâ€™d just gotten back from a one-off therapy session using psychedelics, and I had an amazing experience. Itâ€™s not something I usually do but the lyrics were influenced by that unique moment, since the first sentences that came out of my mouth were about how you feel when everything goes well. Itâ€™s an uplifting song about looking back with gratitude.â€ â€œLosing Daysâ€ MSA: â€œThis was one of the first tracks we wrote for the album, encapsulating that feeling of the two worlds of distortion and hopeful melodies combining. The beat is really heavy, like it might blow up your speakers, but the chords are so soothing.â€ HC: â€œThis track started the whole concept of the record. Itâ€™s meant to be played with the volume loud and blazing.â€ â€œWhere It All Leadsâ€ HC: â€œWe had the elements of the track that would go on to become â€˜Where It All Leadsâ€™ for quite some time but we didnâ€™t know how to fully piece it together. We didnâ€™t want to overload it, so we focused on the groove and its harshness, which gave new context to the sweet vocal lines on top.â€ MSA: â€œThis has a similar concept to â€˜Losing Daysâ€™, starting with a heavy beat and a compressed, gritty sound then layering on a hopeful melody.â€ â€œDonâ€™t Lose Timeâ€ MSA: â€œThe final 20 seconds of â€˜Donâ€™t Lose Timeâ€™ is a snippet of the first demo we made of the track. That used to be a five-minute song that we were very happy with, but it didnâ€™t quite fit with the sound of the new record.â€ HC: â€œIt was almost too sentimental, so we shifted it into a rave direction and really embraced our dance music influences. We knew we had gotten it right because we just wanted to dance in the studio when we came up with it!â€ â€œNever Stay for Loveâ€ (feat. Eefje de Visser) HC: â€œEefje was one of the artists staying in the house we rented in Germany, and we asked her to feature on another tune, â€˜Is That How You Feel Itâ€™. We jammed for a while over that instrumental, and she did an incredible job. So much so that when we isolated the vocal track and worked on it further, it became an entirely new song, which is â€˜Never Stay for Loveâ€™.â€ MSA: â€œThat reworking is something we do quite often now. Itâ€™s a fun way to surprise yourself by switching vocals from different chord progressions.â€ â€œDay After Dayâ€ MSA: â€œThis is another fragment of an old ideaâ€”a song called â€˜Daysâ€™ from 2016. We had tried to finish it for years but we always failed. We loved the basic idea but didnâ€™t know how to fill in the other elements until I pitched the chords down one day and it became an entirely new thing. It has this driving, big-beat feel, which is exactly how we wanted the whole record to be. The song is like a train, it just keeps on going.â€ â€œChanged for the Betterâ€ HC: â€œâ€˜Changed for the Betterâ€™ came out of our longing to play live again during the pandemic. We wanted to make a tune that we could play in front of a crowd once things reopened, something where the vocals are clear and punchy and that incorporates dance elements to get people moving.â€ MSA: â€œIt was the perfect single for us to release as it embodies the new direction weâ€™re exploring. Itâ€™s in-your-face, fun and full of distorted 808 kick drums.â€ â€œI Saw Youâ€ HC: â€œThis was another late addition to the album. Since so many of the other tracks are driving and more intense, we needed a breather and something to showcase a more uplifting side to the darker elements. Even though â€˜I Saw Youâ€™ is upbeat and almost drum â€™nâ€™ bass tempo, it embodies that lightness we were looking for in its melodies.â€ â€œIs That How You Feel Itâ€ HC: â€œEefjeâ€™s initial vocal take for this track ended up becoming the basis for â€˜Never Stay for Loveâ€™, so we were then left with a gap where we needed new lyrics and vocals. I was playing around and recording some lines and ended up slowing down the track while jamming. It suddenly made my vocal take on a great vibrato and soulful feel. Itâ€™s not our typical sound but it just fits perfectly here.â€ â€œForeverâ€ HC: â€œâ€˜Foreverâ€™ is another example of us stitching together pieces of old tracks to make something new. The beat on the song is around three years old, while the vocal was taken from another demo. We added a rave-y, acid synth line to a 120 BPM dancey feel and hopeful lyrics on being thankful for everything that has come before. As soon as we made it, we knew it was the only way to end the album.â€
entries.title: Remember

entries.notes: Black Thought may be best-known as part of The Roots, performing night after late night for Jimmy Fallonâ€™s TV audience, yet the Philadelphia native concurrently boasts a staggering reputation as a stand-alone rapper. Though heâ€™s earned GOAT nods from listeners for earth-shaking features alongside Big Pun, Eminem and Rapsody, his solo catalogue long remained relatively modest in size. Meanwhile, Danger Mouse had a short yet monumental run in the 2000s that made him one of that decadeâ€™s most beloved and respected producers. His discography from that period contains no shortage of microphone dynamos, most notably MF DOOM (as DANGERDOOM) and Goodie Mobâ€™s CeeLo Green (as Gnarls Barkley). Uniting these low-key hip-hop powerhouses is the stuff of hip-hop dreams, the kind of fantasy-league-style draft youâ€™d encounter on rap message boards. Yet Cheat Codes is realâ€”perhaps realer than real. Danger Mouseâ€™s penchant for quirkily cinematic, subtly soulful soundscapes remains from the old days, but the growth from his 2010s work with the likes of composer Daniele Luppi gives â€œAquamarineâ€ and â€œSometimesâ€ undeniable big-screen energy. Black Thought luxuriates over these luxurious beats, his lyrical lexicon put to excellent use over the feverish funk of â€œNo Gold Teethâ€ and the rollicking blues of â€œClose to Famousâ€. As if their team-up wasnâ€™t enough, an intergenerational cabal of rapper guests bless the proceedings. From living legend Raekwon to A$AP Rocky to Conway the Machine, New York artists play a pivotal role here. A lost DOOM verse, apparently from The Mouse and the Mask sessions, makes its way onto the sauntering and sunny â€œBelizeâ€, another gift for the fans.
entries.title: Cheat Codes

entries.notes: â€œNo, I'm not the same/I think I done changed,â€ Janelle MonÃ¡e raps with a swagger on â€œFloatâ€, the opener for her fourth LP, The Age of Pleasure. Over powerful brassâ€”courtesy of Seun Kuti and Egypt 80â€”and heavy-lidded 808s, the singer-songwriter introduces listeners to another side of herself where she embraces the present. â€œThose lyrics for 'Float', I was like, I have to put this out now,â€ she tells Apple Music. â€œThis is exactly, how do I honour how I'm feeling and who I am now. I'm not thinking about the future, but right now, because this is all we have right now.â€ Where MonÃ¡e's previous records were character-drivenâ€”set in a complex futuristic world filled with androidsâ€”and explored themes about power, race and humanity, The Age of Pleasure highlights a new era of liberation that sheds her Afrofuturist persona in favour of an unmasked exploration of her own sensuality and deservedness to feel good above all else. MonÃ¡e creates a safe space within the album's 14 tracks where people can relax into themselves and express their queer identities, sexuality, and unapologetic Blackness. â€œWe had an Everyday People Wondaland party, and I was like, Oh, this is who I want to make music for,â€ she says. â€œThis moment right here, I want to make the soundtrack to this lifestyle. They get it. This is what we fight to protect. All of my work that centres around protecting my communities that I'm a part of, from the LGBTQIA+ communities to being Black to all of that.â€ The Age of Pleasure is a love letter to the Pan-African diaspora. MonÃ¡e trades in her previous albums' New Wave indie-electronic beats for an effortless fusion of jazz, dancehall, reggae, trap and Afrobeats. The first half features tightly produced jazz- and funk-inspired tempos and rhythms over which she flexes her accomplishments (â€œChampagne Shitâ€) and proudly celebrates herself (â€œFloatâ€, â€œPhenomenalâ€, â€œHauteâ€). The album's second half switches gears with midtempo, reggae-influenced sounds and MonÃ¡e indulging her carnal desires. â€œI like lipstick on my neck/Hands around my waist so you know what's coming next/I wanna feel your lips on mine/I just wanna feel/A little tongue, we don't have a long time,â€ she sings on â€œLipstick Loverâ€, a seductive, summery groove that is a joyous celebration of queer Black sexual liberation. She uses water metaphors to underscore her euphoric pleasure-seeking on â€œThe Rushâ€ and â€œWater Slideâ€, while â€œOnly Have Eyes 42â€ is an ode to polyamory, with more than one lover at the centre of MonÃ¡e's affections. Ultimately, on The Age of Pleasure, MonÃ¡e taps into her â€œfree-ass motherfucking spiritâ€, as she calls it, and delivers an album that honours the space that she's currently inâ€”unabashed and proud of who she is. â€œMy friends have gotten an opportunity to see a different side of me that nobody gets to see, and this album, this moment that I'm having, I'm allowing myself to show that version of Janelle that friends get to see all the time,â€ she says. â€œI want to own all of me and be all of me.â€
entries.title: The Age of Pleasure

entries.notes: Itâ€™s not easy to dance with oneâ€™s tongue buried deeply in cheek. But Charlotte AdigÃ©ry and Bolis Pupul effortlessly combine lean, punchy electro-pop with an unapologetically sarcastic sense of humour. On the Belgian duoâ€™s debut album, Topical Dancer, the two musicians draw on their multicultural backgrounds to take sly potshots at racism, sexism and self-doubt. On â€œEsperantoâ€, AdigÃ©ry riffs on microaggressions over plunging electric bass, and on â€œBlendaâ€, she marries a crisp, funky groove with a surprisingly vulnerable chorus: â€œGo back to your country where you belong/Siri, can you tell me where I belong?â€ Co-produced by their long-time collaborators Soulwax, the album slices neatly across the overlap between punky disco, indie dance and underground house; â€™80s avant-pop influences (Art of Noise, Talking Heads) brush up against the sing-speaking wit of contemporaries like Marie Davidson and Dry Cleaning. Some of the albumâ€™s most powerful moments transcend language entirely: On â€œHahaâ€, AdigÃ©ryâ€™s laughter is chopped up and dribbled over an EBM-inspired beat, making for a slow-motion floor-filler thatâ€™s as surreal as it is captivating.
entries.title: Topical Dancer

entries.notes: On his milestone 10th album, pianist, composer, improviser and healer Nduduzo Makhathini distils a decadeâ€™s worth of creative output into an offering that reflects upon both his and his forebearerâ€™s footsteps. â€œThis whole journey started in 2012, when I went to studio to record my debut album,â€ he tells Apple Music. â€œThis is me summarising my journey. This is the moment for a birdâ€™s-eye view of the recurring themes and dialoguing thatâ€™s been taking place.â€ In the Spirit of Ntu muses on various ideasâ€”from a range of disciplinesâ€”that collectively shape us. â€œAn underpinning concept of ubuntu is that everything that lives carries vital force, and this vital force is what counts as â€˜Ntuâ€™,â€ Makhatini explains. â€œIâ€™ve found that the hinge that connects all African art, music, religions, worldviews and histories is this notion of Ntu. This is the part the colonial system was not able to erase. This album is an intervention to hold on to the things that refused to be removed.â€ Crafted by a talented young lineup, these 10 tracks situate Makhathiniâ€™s ideas in the realm of sound. â€œI was grappling with what it means to locate the sonic inside of these conversations,â€ he says. â€œYou exist in the context of the whole, and that became the underpinning conceptual view towards the bandstandâ€”all the musicians are younger than me, to build continuity within that shared â€˜insidenessâ€™ of this cultural sphere.â€ Here, Makhathini breaks down key tracks from the album. â€œUnonkanyambaâ€ â€œWhen I was growing up, there was this myth that if there were heavy quakes, Inkanyamba [the serpent] was emerging from beneath the earth. When it emerges, thereâ€™s no way you can survive, and we were told we couldnâ€™t see it cause weâ€™d die immediately. As a kid, Iâ€™d internalised this as a masculine energy. Here, I use the idea of â€˜Unoâ€™ as pointing towards a different polarity. What if these energies were feminine? Anything that has to do with water, we consult Nomkhubulwaneâ€”thatâ€™s a deity or divinity for rain. Thereâ€™s a sense in which the arising of Unonkanymaba could be seen as a metaphor for all the things that could possibly emerge from beneath the earth.â€ â€œMamaâ€ (feat. Omagugu) â€œThis whole album is underpinned by Ntu configured as essence, and essence as a space of origin. Thereâ€™s always this feminine energy surrounding the womb and water. â€˜Mamaâ€™ is a human manifestation of what Unonkanyamba would mean at a cosmic level. My wife, Omagugu, composed [this song] for my mother-in-law, who got sick and passed away. Itâ€™s paying tribute to a mother in a spiritual formâ€”as part of the lineage of ancestors that can make interventions on our behalf. The sonic arrangement starts with a gentleness, then builds, almost like a foetus growing in the womb. The break is the idea of giving birth as something that is high frequency. Though it tries to give a sonic feeling of what it means to be a mother, it asks what it means to lose one.â€ â€Amathongoâ€ â€œIn English, we say youâ€™re in â€˜deep sleepâ€™, which has nothing to do with being elsewhereâ€”in a world that functions. In isiZulu, we say â€˜usebuthongweniâ€™, which means he or she is one with the â€˜star godsâ€™ or amathongo. That says something about sleep as this moment where weâ€™re actually alive in another reality. Ntu speaks about how we collapse these two realities. So, when I say, â€˜Vumani vumani vumani weZangoma,â€™ itâ€™s because you have to surrender. Through this invocation of â€˜ukuvumaâ€™ [â€˜to agree or concurâ€™], a collective agreement enables a ritual state where time and space are suspended. When I grew up, jazz musicians had no sense of cultural situatedness. There was no relationship between amathongo and the things that we see around us, until Busi Mhlongo and Zim Ngqawana arrived. They brought these connections in a more deliberate way, so this is part of that codification.â€ â€œEmlilweniâ€ (feat. Jaleel Shaw) â€œIn various creation stories on the [African] continent, the earth was once filled with fire. When water emerged, all the fires escaped to the underworlds as a sign of obedience. As we speak about the underworlds, we also speak about the location of our ancestors, so itâ€™s interesting to me how South Africans use fire as one of our codes for expressing our tiredness. We're so tired, weâ€™re telling our ancestors that we need bigger interventions. This was the language post-coloniality and still is. Throughout these time periods, weâ€™ve viewed musicians as operating from the edges of these burning firesâ€”to propel the fire burning in the middle. Given the urgency of things to change in a very fragile system, thereâ€™s an even deeper urgency for musicians to enunciate from within these burning fires instead of from around them.â€ â€œOmnyamaâ€ â€œWhen I first heard Mfazâ€™Omnyama, his voice would just cut through. He always projected something that was distant from hereâ€”something untouchable by the systems. Babâ€™ Mfazâ€™Omnyama, Mamâ€™ Busi Mhlongo and Babâ€™ Phuzekhemisi were unlocking codes, and if you heard that, that was your access. They were like, â€˜Iâ€™m giving this to you, and the only way to enter is for you to hear, to sense.â€™ I think of Maskanda musicians as a radical movement. To pick up a Western classical instrument and do a full-on colonisation of it is radicalâ€”the guitar was speaking English, and they made it speak isiZulu! Through this unconventional tuning, they were telling us something deeper about how to make these tools obey your own story.â€ â€œSenzeâ€™ Ninaâ€ â€œWeâ€™ve seen how men are targeted in a deep way, even during apartheid. We grew up without our fathers, and these were the creations of dysfunctionality in the Black family. There are problematic constructs weâ€™ve created ourselves, too, and men really need to add gentleness to their vocabulary of masculinity. â€˜Senzeâ€™ Ninaâ€™ is about the truth that at the very core of every man lives a gentleness that is inherent just by the mere fact that they were born of a mother. I propose the idea of the making of a new man when that gentleness needs to be reawakened. Some of the most powerful things are projected with a gentleness!â€ â€œNtuâ€ â€œIn the Spirit of Ntu starts with all these things that are clashing and conflicting, and it ends with this gentle solo pianoâ€”this very utopian place. All the things that happen on this album are things that you can see, but this last song leads into a dream and happens elsewhere. This music is one of those ritual technologies that takes us to different locations, where you enter a space and come out of it different. Ntu is that reconfiguration of self.â€
entries.title: In The Spirit Of Ntu

entries.notes: After the pandemic hit, Harley Streten left his adopted home, LA, for his real one, Australia. He moved to Byron Bay in Northern NSW and set up a new, quieter life for himself. â€œIâ€™ve got property, I live on an acreage, I just live a simple life,â€ he tells Apple Music. â€œI grow my own vegetables. I have a snake that lives in my roof that sometimes crawls down to my front door.â€ Itâ€™s about as far removed as you can get from the bustle and drama of the city that placed him into â€œnot in a particularly productive space or good spaceâ€. Itâ€™s here that he set up a new studio and got to work on the pieces that would become his third album, Palaces. The producerâ€™s first two albums propelled him from Sydneyâ€™s nightclubs to festival stages around the world. His 2016 release, Skin, was built on the warped, unique production style heâ€™d become known for and earned him his first Grammy. The next few years were packed with touringâ€”until the pandemic hit. â€œThis time has been really good for me, mentallyâ€”itâ€™s just really given me a chance to slow down,â€ he says. â€œI got on this train, it started speeding up and getting faster and faster. When I was 19, I started touring and it just didnâ€™t stop. Then COVID happened, and I had two years to just be a normal human. Itâ€™s been fantastic.â€ Palaces stretches in every direction. The sounds and style Streten is known for flings itself into new places, big and small, heavy and tender. Thereâ€™s a healthy array of collaborators, including Caroline Polachek, who sings on the cinematic â€œSirensâ€. â€œIâ€™m really proud of that song,â€ Streten says. â€œCaroline was in lockdown at the time in London and she was hearing all the sirens outside. The song is like, â€˜I wish I could start world peace. It would be really lovely to be able to just wave a wand and end all suffering.â€™â€ Stretenâ€™s trademark head rush of textures is still well-represented on the skittering â€œESCAPEâ€ (featuring longtime collaborator KuÄka), â€œHollowâ€ (featuring Emma Louise) and â€œSay Nothingâ€ (featuring MAY-A)â€”all proof of his continuing expertise when it comes to big, emotive pop. Meanwhile, Spanish DJ and producer Virgen Maria evokes playful sexuality with her vocal contributions on â€œOnly Fansâ€. â€œIt can go from zero to 100 and then back to zero,â€ he says of his musicâ€™s sudden hairpin turns and mood swings. But there are plenty of soft, ruminative moments here, too, such as ambient centrepiece â€œJasperâ€™s Songâ€, featuring pianist Jasper Harris. â€œThat was originally a house track,â€ Streten reveals. â€œIt was a full house banger. But I then felt like it took away from the beauty of it, so I stripped it all the way back and just had it as this ambient piano piece. It feels like a nice contrast in the record. Thereâ€™s a lot of hard stuff, so itâ€™s nice to have some really mellow, warm feelings.â€ And the closing track concludes the album in a gorgeous, atmospheric manner. It starts with field recordings from around Stretenâ€™s property, and slowly builds, rhythm and ambient chords billowing out behind Damon Albarnâ€™s vocals. â€œWorking with him, it was cool,â€ Streten says. â€œIâ€™m a huge fan. I was nervous. I was fucking nervous.â€ A decade since his debut album, Streten has found his stride. Much like how his music darts from intense to meditative, hard-hitting to mellow, heâ€™s realised his life, too, is all about equilibrium. â€œNow, Iâ€™ve got a really nice balance between LA and Australia, two ends of the spectrum,â€ he says. But he canâ€™t overstate how important his choice was to move home, to take a break. In fact, the album name was inspired by the solace he felt after leaving LA. â€œIâ€™d gone home to Australia, started life in the countryside and felt like Iâ€™d found my palace. Thatâ€™s where the record really came together. I was having a bit of trouble with music in the States. Going homeâ€”all that room, the simple life, it just gave me the space to create. And it just felt like a sanctuary.â€
entries.title: Palaces

entries.notes:
When Fred again.. began work on Actual Life 2 (February 22 - October 15 2021), the BRIT Award-winning producer saw it as a way to close the book on the most traumatic period of his life. Still processing the grief of losing a loved one, he imagined that making his second solo album would be a way to get through and move on. Instead, he learned that life doesnâ€™t work that way. Grief has long legs. â€œI was like, â€˜Yeah, OK, this is going to be the journey through grief, from it being there and unbearable to it all being solved,â€ Fred Gibson, the man behind the handle, tells Apple Music. â€œBy the end, I was like, â€˜This is an ever-going thing, and this is just one chapter of it.â€™â€ Following up on his debut, Actual Life (April 14 - December 17 2020), released in April 2021, itâ€™s a soulful and emotional dance record. Blending euphoric bangers and atmospheric electronica, it confirms the producer whoâ€™s collaborated with Headie One, Stormzy, Romy, Ed Sheeran and FKA Twigs as an exhilarating artist in his own right.
Like its predecessor, Actual Life 2 (February 22 - October 15 2021) uses snippets and samples from real-life events and conversations as the foundation for intricate soundscapes. â€œAs soon as I make a song, I start dragging in shit from my iPhone, a bunch of voice notes that Iâ€™ve recorded from around the world,â€ says Gibson. â€œI just love the way that feels, so much more than opening up some dry synth and playing some notes.â€ Gibson says Actual Life is an ongoing project, each LP a snapshot of his life in that particular era. â€œIâ€™m going to do this forever now. Itâ€™ll be like chapters. Iâ€™m obsessed with it.â€ Let Fred again.. guide you through this phase, track by track.
â€œFebruary 2nd 2021â€ â€œItâ€™s the first sample I found. Itâ€™s picking up from where the last album ended, beginning to try and move on from a thing. It felt very clearly like it needed to be at the beginning.â€
â€œCatrin (The City)â€ â€œI thought this lyric was just really beautiful and very much resonated with me. I adore London, and I always have, and I always will. I make most of my music just out in the city, just on benches or in museums. My real brother on this record felt like the city. It just felt very clear and honest to me that this was how the album needed to begin. I only sing four lines in this tune, but theyâ€™re like flashbacks. I see them as being montage flashbacks at different moments from last year. And then it moves forward again.â€
â€œRoze (Forgive)â€ â€œThis is a sample Iâ€™d found on Instagramâ€”someone in his bedroom singing this song. To me the feeling of it was itâ€™s still not moving forward, itâ€™s still reflecting on the past. But it was at least a step in there being a nostalgia over itâ€”it wasnâ€™t present tense. It was like, â€˜This is whatâ€™s happenedâ€™. The main breakthrough on that was finding the thing of doing it with the strings. Iâ€™m going to record a version of it actually with a string orchestra, which will be fun.â€
â€œGigi (What You Went Through)â€ â€œThis is [London singer-songwriter] Gigi Moss, a sample of her singing at a pub. Sometimes itâ€™s very much as simple as just stumbling across someone saying what Iâ€™d want to say and then Iâ€™ll be like, â€˜OK, thank you for holding my hand through that. You need to carry on helping me, and I can sample it so I can sing around it.â€™ I find it hard to go from a white, blank page to singing it myself off of nothing. But if thereâ€™s someone else there singing it with me, I see it as a safety blanket.â€
â€œKahan (Last Year)â€ [feat. Kodak Black] â€œFor a while, there was a version of this where I wanted it to feel like I was out of my mind, chaotic and claustrophobic. Then my brother, who I work with on lots of music, was like, â€˜What if you make the opposite interpretation, just a piano?â€™ As soon as it was on piano, it was able to breathe. And then I was like, â€˜OK, I would want to sing on this now. I need to tell my part of the story.â€™ It becomes more of a duet. The whole record is very much in memory mode of the previous year, and I think this song summarises that.â€
â€œTate (How I Feel)â€ â€œThe lyric is saying, â€˜I donâ€™t know how I feelâ€™â€”just that over and over again. The music sounds more positive, which I think was just how I was feeling. I couldnâ€™t work out if it was a good or a bad thing. I think, in hindsight, it was just a pending thing. I thought I was through it. I was like, â€˜Weâ€™re getting to the good bit and to a good state of mindâ€™. But that was definitely, definitely not the case.â€
â€œHannah (The Sun)â€ â€œItâ€™s in the same portion of time [of â€˜Tate (How I Feel)â€™], of that feeling of thinking the sunâ€™s coming through, thereâ€™s an optimism here. It was short-lived but real. I like things when the answer isnâ€™t, â€˜Yeah, and then that was that and thatâ€™s it, doneâ€™. I like it more when itâ€™s like, â€˜It really felt like it was that, but it was a total fallacy, and you were totally wrong two weeks later.â€™ Iâ€™m into that side of it; it feels more human.â€
â€œCarlos (Interlude)â€ â€œCarlos is the OG. Heâ€™s the first person I met that I sampled. And I adore him and feel forever indebted to him. Iâ€™m going to try and track him down at the beginning of next year when Iâ€™m in America. Every album will sample Carlos somewhere. I like the challenge of finding new ways of using this little, 14-second video I have with Carlos. Iâ€™ve made 20 songs out of it.â€
â€œFaisal (Envelops Me)â€ â€œThis is probably the song that means the most to me on the record. The verse is very much about the traumas of the year before, but I think the chorus is representing a hug of the beautiful people I have around me. I think I was coming out of the short-lived sun moment and realising that this would be a lifelong thing. I think traumas and grief, it gets less frenetic and thereâ€”but then it just becomes part of you. It doesnâ€™t just disappear. It just becomes you. And thatâ€™s not a bad thing; itâ€™s just a true thing. I was making peace with the fact that there would be no leaving this behind.â€
â€œTayla (Every Night)â€ â€œI love this sample. Itâ€™s of this amazing singer called Tayla Parx. Itâ€™s a song that we actually wrote together a time ago, but it was a balladâ€”itâ€™s a song Iâ€™ve made quite a few versions of. This one felt right for this moment in this record. Before it picked up, I wanted it to have this stiller, more washed, padded moment of just a few lyrics before it starts to get some momentum.â€
â€œTanya (Maybe Life)â€ â€œThis is the beginning of a form of optimism. I like it sounding like all these loads of different voices, loads of different chops, loads of different people around you trying to help in different ways. Thereâ€™s a chop of Tanya going, â€˜Maybe life ainâ€™t as bad as it seems.â€™ Thereâ€™s a chop of Romy from The xx going, â€˜You can lean on me, you can lean on me.â€™ Thereâ€™s a chop of a whole host of other stuff, and they were representing the different people around me and the different approaches thatâ€”theyâ€™re all love, but just the different aspects of the people around me.â€
â€œMarco (And Everyone)â€ â€œI love making these reprise songs that summarise all the samples that youâ€™ve heard in the record. On the last record, the reprise song was over this washy pad, and it was very ambient and still, so I was like, â€˜OK, letâ€™s try doing that same thing of finding a song that can incorporate everything youâ€™ve heard, but in the opposite way of a super-driving beat.â€™ Also, I was like, â€˜Weâ€™re picking up now; I want to be building a momentum.â€™â€
â€œBillie (Loving Arms)â€ â€œThis is the real climax of the feeling of letting people help you, the most visceral incarnation of that. It feels like a pinger to meâ€”just a proper, undiluted serotonin hit of falling into someone else. After a year of that whole aspect of things being gone, I think those things are even sweeter. This song felt like the pinnacle of allowing people in.â€
â€œBillie (Interlude)â€ â€œI knew that the record had to end with â€˜Mollieâ€™ because I was absolutely adamant it didnâ€™t end with â€˜Loving Armsâ€™. It was so insincere for it to end on â€˜Loving Armsâ€™ because that so isnâ€™t the truth of the end of the journeyâ€”not that there is an end. I wanted to end â€˜Loving Armsâ€™ in a way that it could get into â€˜Mollieâ€™ without it being too rogue. It needed to just pause for a second to allow it the space to breathe so it could go into that last song.â€
â€œMollie (Hear Your Name)â€ â€œIf â€˜Loving Armsâ€™ is the Saturday night, the reality is much more of a Sunday afternoon. That â€˜Loving Armsâ€™ serotonin hit isnâ€™t a sustainable state of mind. Itâ€™s more like â€˜Mollieâ€™â€”â€˜OK, actually we are more here, and this is our cruise pace and thatâ€™s OK, and weâ€™re going to try and marathon this out as opposed to some little sprint of a gassed-up pingerâ€™s life.â€™â€
â€œ15th October 2021â€ â€œThis is literally just me, very ill in my bed, finishing the record. Itâ€™s just a message to someone, a little minute of stillness after â€˜Mollieâ€™.â€

entries.notes: A decade into their career, London duo Jungle are determined to make up for lost time. Josh Lloyd-Watson and Tom McFarland felt that theyâ€™d taken too long to follow up 2014â€™s self-titled Mercury-nominated debut, with second album For Ever arriving four years later. It injected their third album Loving in Stereo, released in 2021, with a creative restlessness and that thrilling urgency continues on Volcano. â€œWeâ€™d just come off the road and went straight back into the studio,â€ Lloyd-Watson tells Apple Music. â€œWe got the record done between November and December 2022 and wrapped it up in January, which is one of the quickest turnarounds weâ€™ve done. You can feel that in the music.â€ Itâ€™s a record that both sharpens the pairâ€™s melodic hooks and hones their nu-disco, soulful pop swaggerâ€”pushing them further away from being a band and deeper into how theyâ€™ve always imagined themselves. â€œItâ€™s going back to what is essentially a production duo,â€ says Lloyd-Watson. â€œItâ€™s a collectiveâ€”we wouldnâ€™t be where we are without the dancers, without the incredible vocalists, without all the people that come together to make the full thing. But ultimately, it feels like bits of it are heading much more towards something like Justice or Daft Punk, more dance-y.â€ Exploring themes of love found, loss, heartbreak and rediscovery, Volcano is also a record that insists you move to its rhythm. This is Jungle at their most vibrant and infectious. Lloyd-Watson talks us through it, track by track. â€œUs Against the Worldâ€ â€œThis starts in almost chaotic fashion. I think we like that because it bamboozles you a little bit and you canâ€™t really work out whatâ€™s going on. Itâ€™s frantic and a bit crazy and then it settles in and takes a while to find some solid harmony that Jungle would be known for. Weâ€™re embedded deep in harmony. Itâ€™s like a breakbeat track, a little bit on edge. I suppose the track can be taken as, â€˜Weâ€™re about to climb this mountain together, this volcano.â€™ Itâ€™s a setting-off track. Itâ€™s us against the world.â€ â€œHolding Onâ€ â€œThis is one that wasnâ€™t necessarily made for Jungle, we made it with [Dublin DJ/producer] Krystal Klear and [Essex singer-songwriter/producer] Lydia Kitto. It has a much more clubby touch to it, itâ€™s got heavier kicks and itâ€™s got 909 hats, which weâ€™ve never really used. It continues that more aggy side of what we wanted to do, we wanted to have a bit more of the disco-punk element to it, Ã  la [the South Bronxâ€™s early-â€™80s punk-funk pioneers] ESG, something that was anti the soft, midtempo Jungle that we know and love. Itâ€™s a bit strobe-y and then eventually it releases to this refrain, which sounds like some old soul sample that we made. I suppose itâ€™s the first time youâ€™re like, â€˜OK, this is a Jungle record. I know whatâ€™s going on here.â€™â€ â€œCandle Flameâ€ (feat. Erick the Architect) â€œTrack three has always been the big one for usâ€”[2014 breakthrough hit] â€˜Busy Earninâ€™â€™ was track three [on their debut album]. We had this hook for a long time. It had been sitting at 104 BPM and we eventually got a bit bored of it down at that tempo and ramped it up so you get those sped-up, soul-pitched vocals. We wanted to have something that was really fun and carefree and had this atmosphere of a party. I think â€˜Candle Flameâ€™ is about the fire and the passion in early love, essentially. Erick the Architect, of Flatbush Zombies fame, jumped on it and did a verse which reminded me of a young Snoop Dogg. It had that fiery energy and just set the thing on fire reallyâ€¦like a candle flame!â€ â€œDominoesâ€ â€œâ€˜Dominoesâ€™ is another song that had this old soul vibeâ€”it was a lot slower originally, it was down at 85 BPM. â€˜Dominoesâ€™ is a metaphor for falling in love and the cataclysmic events that happen as you adapt to being deeper and deeper in love and you change your whole life. It has a sample of the [US R&B singer] Gloria Ann Taylor song â€˜Love Is a Hurtinâ€™ Thingâ€™, which we took and then mixed with the vocals of our song, like this mashup thing. Itâ€™s got this cruising, The Avalanches vibe, a real summer jam. I suppose itâ€™s the first time in the album when you get a little bit of respite and itâ€™s not so explosive.â€ â€œIâ€™ve Been in Loveâ€ (feat. Channel Tres) â€œThis features Channel Tres and is from a session that we did a while backâ€”basically before Channel Tres was even established as an artist. We wrote this over another song which was called â€˜Iâ€™m Dying to Be in Your Armsâ€™, which you can hear in the middle of â€˜Iâ€™ve Been in Loveâ€™. We re-sampled the original track that he was on, which forms the middle eight. It tells the story of love past and the idea of coming out of that love.â€ â€œBack on 74â€ â€œThe feeling of â€˜Back on 74â€™ is a nostalgic one, itâ€™s that feeling of having this place of your life where you grew up, where you had these really fond memories. 74 is a fictitious thing, but for us itâ€™s like 74th Avenue or 74th Street or something, where, in your imagination or as a kid, you were playing out on the street. Youâ€™ve gone back to this place and itâ€™s giving you this really nostalgic feeling but everythingâ€™s not quite the same. Youâ€™ve come out of something on â€˜Iâ€™ve Been in Loveâ€™ and through â€˜Back on 74â€™, you have this desire to go home, back to a place that felt safe.â€ â€œYou Ainâ€™t No Celebrityâ€ (feat. Roots Manuva) â€œThis is probably the most raw and honest track on the record, a warning to people in your life that think theyâ€™re a bit of a princess or a bit of a divaâ€”when they become demanding or a little bit self-righteous or a little bit expectant of certain things to fall their way. Roots Manuva was maybe relating to that feeling. He had these lyrics which were originally on another track, something we did with him way back in 2016 or something. He had these almost like nursery-rhyme, Mr Motivator-style hooks that werenâ€™t even a verse, almost like this mantra. It explains the compromise that you have to have in a relationship with somebody, the push and pull, over easy and easy over, a constant back and forth.â€ â€œComing Backâ€ â€œThis is a continuation of â€˜You Ainâ€™t No Celebrityâ€™ but itâ€™s a little bit more of a celebration. It takes the resentment and the anger and turns it into this more cheeky, throwaway, carnival vibe. It starts off with these shouted vocals, like, â€˜I donâ€™t miss youâ€™, these realisations about yourself, and the chorus goes on to say you keep coming back for moreâ€”once youâ€™ve let go of somebody, somebody keeps wanting more from you. It explores the idea of expectation in relationships, but we end up with this almost carnival ending where everybodyâ€™s joining in, getting through it through fun.â€ â€œDonâ€™t Playâ€ (feat. Mood Talk) â€œâ€˜Donâ€™t Playâ€™ is a sample from â€˜Faith Is the Keyâ€™, a really rare record by Enlightment, a Washington soul and gospel outfit. They put this record out in â€™84 but then the record plant basically went under and their distributor went under, which made this record quite valuable, a holy grail for collectors. It surfaced again in 2000 and now copies are going for about Â£800. It had this amazing little hook in it and my cousin, who is Mood Talk, put this beat together and sampled it. We featured him on the record and we sang over the sample. â€˜Donâ€™t Playâ€™ is, â€˜Stop playing these games, Iâ€™m not botheredâ€™. That message can be applied at the beginning and it can be applied at the end of a relationship. There are always games on the in and the outâ€¦â€ â€œEvery Nightâ€ â€œThis is fun and guitar-based. We really wanted to make a song without a snare drum. Itâ€™s a fun song, a positive message about love and itâ€™s got gospel influences to some extent. Itâ€™s a bit of a party.â€ â€œPROBLEMZâ€ â€œThis came out originally in 2022 and I suppose in some way with [its double A-side] â€˜GOOD TIMESâ€™ was the blueprint for the sound of the record. We left â€˜GOOD TIMESâ€™ off the record because it didnâ€™t feel like it was right, it didnâ€™t really feel like the production or the vibe was quite where this record was. But â€˜PROBLEMZâ€™ is one of our favourite bits of music weâ€™ve ever made and we didnâ€™t want to leave it as some B-side. Itâ€™s got Latin American vibes and feels to it, especially in the flutes and the swing of the music, a classic disco feel. At the end, it goes to this place thatâ€™s almost like musical theatre with the strings.â€ â€œGood at Breaking Heartsâ€ â€œThis is the first traditional ballad of the record. Itâ€™s like, â€˜Iâ€™m only good at making mistakesâ€”a bit of a juxtaposition in that you are only good at breaking hearts.â€™ It features [London singer-songwriter] JNR Williams and 33.3â€”which is mine and Lydiaâ€™s new project. JNR has an amazing voice and Iâ€™ve been working with him for two or three years, writing loads of songs with him. This is a song that we made for his album but he was like, â€˜I donâ€™t want itâ€™, and then as soon as it was done, he was like, â€˜Oh, I wish Iâ€™d taken this!â€™ I said, â€˜You should have trusted me, man!â€™ Itâ€™s a beautiful song, his voice has got touches of Nina Simone and Bill Withers and Stevie Wonder to him. Heâ€™s got an amazing voice.â€ â€œPalm Treesâ€ â€œWe made this out in LA originally. It was about this idea that you could escape to this place, like holiday-themed, â€˜Here we come, palm trees!â€™. That feeling of â€˜Iâ€™m just going to escape this and I want to go somewhere hot and I want to go somewhere where my troubles donâ€™t affect me and I can leave all this stuff behind.â€™ Itâ€™s told through this story of a girl going to a club and taking a drug that sends her on this wild space disco trip.â€ â€œPretty Little Thingâ€ (feat. Bas) â€œThis was something that got made in the same chunk of time in which â€˜PROBLEMZâ€™ and â€˜GOOD TIMESâ€™ were made and fans would know that itâ€™s actually on the end of the video for â€˜GOOD TIMES/PROBLEMZâ€™â€”on the credits we ran a little snippet of â€˜Pretty Little Thingâ€™. Itâ€™s a ballad, a chance to reflect on moments and reflect on the old experience. [Queens-via-Paris rapper] Bas jumped on this and told his own story, which weirdly made sense of the whole thing anyway. It was serendipity.â€
entries.title: Volcano

entries.notes: The piano is at the heart of Nils Frahmâ€™s music. The Berlin musicianâ€™s earliest releases were solo piano affairs. On 2011â€™s Felt, he applied preparations to hammers and strings; in 2015, he founded Piano Day, a celebration of the instrument. But on Music for Animals, which follows 2021â€™s solo piano record Old Friends New Friends, Frahm closes the cover on his keyboard and, instead, busies himself with his studio full of vintage and analogue synthesisers. Begun during the first year of the pandemic, when the world pressed pause on daily life, it basks in an almost reverent sense of calm. Chords unfurl patiently against a backdrop of velvety reverb. There are few distractions and little harmonic developmentâ€”just abiding quiet and sparkling focus. The pinging arpeggios of â€œSheep in Black and Whiteâ€ recall the clockworks of Frahmâ€™s live shows rendered in slow motion and zero gravity; the languid â€œDo Dreamâ€ drapes a wheezing pump organ in negative space. Three hours long and soft as a whisper, Music for Animals is a breathtakingly beautiful ode to stillness and solitude.
entries.title: Music for Animals

entries.notes: If The Smile ever seemed like a surprisingly upbeat name for a band containing two members of Radiohead (Thom Yorke and Jonny Greenwood, joined by Sons of Kemet drummer Tom Skinner), the trio used their debut gig to offer some clarification. Performing as part of Glastonbury Festivalâ€™s Live at Worthy Farm livestream in May 2021, Yorke announced, â€œWe are called The Smile: not The Smile as in â€˜Aaah!â€™â€”more the smile of the guy who lies to you every day.â€ To grasp the mood of their debut album, itâ€™s instructive to go even deeper into a name that borrows the title of a 1970 Ted Hughes poem. In Hughesâ€™ impressionist verse, some elemental forceâ€”compassion, humanity, love maybeâ€”rises up to resist the deception and chicanery behind such disarming grins. And as much as the 13 songs on A Light for Attracting Attention sense crisis and dystopia looming, they also crackle with hope and insurrection. The pulsing electronics of opener â€œThe Sameâ€ suggest the racing hearts and throbbing temples of our age of acute anxiety, and Yorkeâ€™s words feel like a call for unity and mobilisation: â€œWe donâ€™t need to fight/Look towards the light/Grab it in with both hands/What you know is right.â€ Perennially contemplating the dynamics of power and thought, he surveys a world where â€œdevastation has comeâ€ (â€œSpeech Bubblesâ€) under the rule of â€œelected billionairesâ€ (â€œThe Oppositeâ€), but itâ€™s one where protest, however extreme, can still birth change (â€œThe Smokeâ€). Amid scathing guitars and outbursts of free jazz, his invective zooms in on abuses of power (â€œYou Will Never Work in Television Againâ€) before shaming inertia and blame-shifters on the scurrying beats and descending melodies of â€œA Hairdryerâ€. These arenâ€™t exactly new themes for Yorke and itâ€™s not a record that sits at an extreme outpost of Radioheadâ€™s extended universe. Emboldened by Skinnerâ€™s fluid, intrepid rhythms, A Light for Attracting Attention draws frequently on various periods of Yorke and Greenwoodâ€™s past work. The emotional eloquence of Greenwoodâ€™s soundtrack projects resurfaces on â€œSpeech Bubblesâ€ and â€œPana-Visionâ€, while Yorkeâ€™s fascination with digital reveries continues to be explored on â€œOpen the Floodgatesâ€ and â€œThe Sameâ€. Elegantly cloaked in strings, â€œFree in the Knowledgeâ€ is a beautiful acoustic-guitar ballad in the lineage of Radioheadâ€™s â€œFake Plastic Treesâ€ and the original live version of â€œTrue Love Waitsâ€. Of course, lesser-trodden ground is visited, too: most intriguingly, math-rock (â€œThin Thingâ€) and folk songs fit for a â€™70s sci-fi drama (â€œWaving a White Flagâ€). The album closes with â€œSkrting on the Surfaceâ€, a song first aired at a 2009 show Yorke played with Atoms for Peace. With Greenwoodâ€™s guitar arpeggios and Yorkeâ€™s aching falsetto, it calls back even further to The Bendsâ€™ finale, â€œStreet Spirit (Fade Out)â€. However, its message about the fragility of existenceâ€”â€œWhen we realise we have only to die, then weâ€™re out of here/Weâ€™re just skirting on the surfaceâ€â€”remains sharply resonant.
entries.title: A Light for Attracting Attention

What a great surprise this album is. Has the atmosphere of Kanye West epic albums thanks to the producer but much more melodic. 

070 Shake sounds like sheâ€™s in pain across You Canâ€™t Kill Me. If love was an inspiration for the Jersey-hailing G.O.O.D. Music signee's follow-up to 2020â€™s Modus Vivendi, it is only to the extent that it has wounded her, caused her to wound someone else or forced her to treat wounds of her own. The project is heavy and operatic (production credits list Dave Sitek, johan lenox and Dave Hamelin, among others), and Shake sings frequently about relationships past (â€œWebâ€, â€œStayâ€, â€œMedicineâ€, â€œSe Fue La Luzâ€), present (â€œBlue Velvetâ€, â€œCocoonâ€, â€œWine & Spiritsâ€) and, in one instanceâ€”hopefullyâ€”future (â€œInvitedâ€). Whatâ€™s clearer than anything else across You Canâ€™t Kill Me is that 070 Shake knows how to turn her pain into art. Or maybe itâ€™s more like she tells us on â€œWine & Spiritsâ€, that â€œLife is about balance, war and harmony/Canâ€™t have one without the other.â€
entries.title: You Canâ€™t Kill Me

entries.notes: Letâ€˜s start with that speech. In September 2022, as Taylor Swift accepted Songwriter-Artist of the Decade honours at the Nashville Songwriter Awards, the headline was that Swift had unveiled an admittedly â€œdorkyâ€ system sheâ€™d developed for organising her own songs. Quill Pen, Fountain Pen, Glitter Gel Pen: three categories of lyrics, three imagined tools with which she wrote them, one pretty ingenious way to invite obsessive fans to lovingly obsess all the more. And yet, perhaps the real takeaway was the manner in which she spoke about her craft that night, some 20 years after writing her first song at the age of 12. â€œI love doing this thing we are fortunate enough to call a job,â€ she said to a room of her peers. â€œWriting songs is my lifeâ€™s work and my hobby and my never-ending thrill. A song can defy logic or time. A good song transports you to your truest feelings and translates those feelings for you. A good song stays with you even when people or feelings donâ€™t.â€ On Midnights, her tenth LP and fourth in as many yearsâ€”if you donâ€™t count the two sheâ€™s just re-recorded and buttressed with dozens of additional tracksâ€”Swift sounds like sheâ€™s really enjoying her work, playing with language like kids do with gum, thrilling to the texture of every turn of phrase, the charge in every melody and satisfying rhyme. Alongside long-time collaborator Jack Antonoff, sheâ€™s set out here to tell â€œthe stories of 13 sleepless nights scattered throughout [her] lifeâ€, as she phrased it in a message to Apple Music subscribers. Itâ€™s a concept that naturally calls for a nocturnal palette: slower tempos, hushed atmosphere, negative space like night sky. The sound is fully modern (synths youâ€™d want to eat or sleep in, low end that sits comfortably on your chest), while the aesthetic (soft focus, wood panelling, tracklist on the cover) is decidedly mid-century, much like the Mad Men-inspired title of its brooding opener, â€œLavender Hazeâ€â€”a song about finding refuge in the glow of intimacy. â€œTalk your talk and go viral,â€ she sings, in reference to the maelstrom of outside interest in her six-year relationship with actor Joe Alwyn. â€œI just want this love spiral.â€ (A big shout to Antonoff for those spongy backup vocals, btw.) In large part, Midnights is a record of interiors, Swift letting us glimpse the chaos inside her head (â€œAnti-Heroâ€, wall-to-wall zingers) and the stillness of her relationship (â€œSweet Nothingâ€, co-written by Alwyn under his William Bowery pseudonym). For â€œSnow on the Beachâ€, she teams up with Lana Del Reyâ€”an artist whose instinct for mood and theatrical framing seems to have influenced Swiftâ€™s recent catalogueâ€”recalling the magic of an impossible night over a backdrop of pizzicato violin, sleigh bells and dreamy Mellotron, like the earliest hours of Christmas morning. â€œIâ€™ve never seen someone lit from within,â€ Swift sings. â€œBlurring out my periphery.â€ But then thereâ€™s â€œBejeweledâ€, a late, 1989-like highlight on which she announces to an unappreciative partner, a few seconds in: â€œAnd by the way, Iâ€™m going out tonight.â€ And then out Swift goes, striding through the centre of the song like she would the room: â€œI can still make the whole place shimmer,â€ she sings, relishing that last word. â€œAnd when I meet the band, they ask, â€˜Do you have a man?â€™/I could still say, â€˜I donâ€™t remember.â€™â€ There are traces of melancholy layered in (see: â€œsapphire tears on my faceâ€), but the song feels like a triumph, the sort of unabashed, extroverted fun that would have probably seemed out of place in the lockdown indie of 2020â€™s folklore and evermore. But here, side by side with songs and scenes of such writerly indulgence, itâ€™s right at homeâ€”more proof that the terms â€œsinger-songwriterâ€ and â€œuniversal pop starâ€ arenâ€™t mutually exclusive ideas. â€œWhatâ€™s a girl gonna do?â€ Swift asks at its climax. â€œA diamondâ€™s gotta shine.â€ This special expanded version of Midnights includes seven additional songs.
entries.title: Midnights (3am Edition)

entries.notes: Unique, strong and sexyâ€”thatâ€™s how BeyoncÃ© wants you to feel while listening to RENAISSANCE. Crafted during the grips of the pandemic, her seventh solo album is a celebration of freedom and a complete immersion into house and dance that serves as the perfect sound bed for themes of liberation, release, self-assuredness and unfiltered confidence across its 16 tracks. RENAISSANCE is playful and energetic in a way that captures that Friday-night, just-got-paid, anything-can-happen feeling, underscored by reiterated appeals to unyoke yourself from the weight of othersâ€™ expectations and revel in the totality of who you are. From the classic four-on-the-floor house moods of the Robin S.- and Big Freedia-sampling lead single â€œBREAK MY SOULâ€ to the Afro-tech of the Grace Jones- and Tems-assisted â€œMOVEâ€ and the funky, rollerskating disco feeling of â€œCUFF ITâ€, this is a massive yet elegantly composed buffet of sound, richly packed with anthemic morsels that pull you in. There are soft moments here, too: â€œI know you canâ€™t help but to be yourself around me,â€ she coos on â€œPLASTIC OFF THE SOFAâ€, the kind of warm, whispers-in-the-ear love song youâ€™d expect to hear at a summer cookoutâ€”complete with an intricate interplay between vocals and guitar that gives BeyoncÃ© a chance to showcase some incredible vocal dexterity. â€œCHURCH GIRLâ€ fuses R&B, gospel and hip-hop to tell a survivorâ€™s story: â€œI'm finally on the other side/I finally found the extra smiles/Swimming through the oceans of tears we cried.â€ An explicit celebration of Blackness, â€œCOZYâ€ is the mantra of a woman who has nothing to prove to anyoneâ€”â€œComfortable in my skin/Cozy with who I am,â€ â€ BeyoncÃ© muses on the chorus. And on â€œPURE/HONEYâ€, BeyoncÃ© immerses herself in ballroom culture, incorporating drag performance chants and a Kevin Aviance sample on the first half that give way to the disco-drenched second half, cementing the song as an immediate dance-floor favourite. Itâ€™s the perfect lead-in to the album closer â€œSUMMER RENAISSANCEâ€, which propels the dreamy escapist disco of Donna Summerâ€™s â€œI Feel Loveâ€ even further into the future.
entries.title: RENAISSANCE

entries.notes: Compared to the strutting reggaetÃ³n of KICK ii and the demonic club experiments of KicK iii, kick iiii captures Arca at her most serene. The crooning â€œXenomorphgirlâ€ is a kind of cyborg lullaby; â€œEsunaâ€ curls up like a kitten in the soft swirls of Oliver Coatesâ€™ strings. But serenity is not the same as docility, and kick iiii also features some of Arcaâ€™s most coolly triumphant work to date. On the self-empowerment anthem â€œQueerâ€, Planningtorock testifies to their â€œtears of powerâ€, while on â€œAlien Insideâ€, Garbageâ€™s Shirley Manson solemnly intones the virtues of Arcaâ€™s self-proclaimed â€œmutant faithâ€ over a shimmering shoegaze backdrop. Most affecting of all is Arcaâ€™s own proclamation on â€œLost Woman Foundâ€: â€œIâ€™ve been walking toward the light for years now/And itâ€™s the first time I feel the sunâ€™s warmth on my skin, now that itâ€™s my own/A lost woman, found.â€ The quest for oneâ€™s true identity has long been at the centre of Arcaâ€™s work, and here at the heart of her sprawling, futuristic bildungsroman, she channels years of trauma into something like peace.
entries.title: kick iiii

entries.notes:
Geez, how could I have missed this artist. Seems to be her third/fourth record? Anyways, she combines forces with whoever is behind Sault, so guarantees for some good music.
