Oh yes, I agree with the critics that the interludes are a bit pointlessâ€¦
entries.title: Sometimes I Might Be Introvert

entries.notes: NO THANK YOUâ€”the follow-up to 2021â€™s Mercury Prize-winning Sometimes I Might Be Introvertâ€”emphatically deepens Little Simzâ€™s connection with producer Inflo, and provides further confirmation of the Islington rapperâ€™s generational abilities. The initials of the title of her soul-searching fourth LP spelled out her first name, and the name of its surprise follow-up also hints at a purposeful double meaning. Perhaps a kindly expression of gratitude for the flowers given since SIMBIâ€™s success? More likely an act of defiance. Either way, within this trademark ambiguity Simz gets her shine on across 10 sumptuous tracks. BRIT Awards Producer Of The Year 2022 Dean Josiah Coverâ€”aka Infloâ€”taps into the rich, bluesy elements of his enigmatic Sault music for urgent dispatches from Simbi Ajikawo. Itâ€™s a rich sonic seam: A returning undercurrent of gospel-rooted R&B reinforces lines with spiritual resonance. From tone-setting opener â€œAngelâ€ (dedicated to the model Harry Uzoka, who died in January 2018), soft choral flourishes and dreamy Cleo Sol vocals help Simz pick up where she left off in 2021. â€œRevoke access, Iâ€™m running it back, yes/Missing opportunities, I wish I was that pressed.â€ Building on a deep-rooted synergy, Simz and Inflo go the whole length on the gut feeling that has made their partnership so prolific. For Simz, an artist whoâ€™s always operated to her own set of standards, an equally clear-sighted collaborator (Inflo is also across the keys, chords and strings) finds her at her most compassionate and precise, tackling family trauma and the emotional isolation of success. Within the streams of sharp, self-analysing rhymes, scattered samples and prolonged orchestral sectionsâ€”â€œSidewaysâ€ and â€œControlâ€â€”lies the sound of a winning combo firmly in the groove. As Simz continues to soar, sheâ€™s evidently still clearing house. By facing down the dark reaches of the mind and the tests of her daily environment, emotional and soulful highs and lows are wonderfully bared across her tightest lyrical offering to date.
entries.title: NO THANK YOU

entries.notes: What a fantastic serie this is. And the music is great to. The final song of the final episode is epic, named â€œUnfoldedâ€¦â€. But also a lot of the other tracks are reminding of what a trip it was watching Squid Game.
entries.title: Squid Game (Original Soundtrack from the Netflix Series)

entries.notes: Young Fathers occupy a unique place in British music. The Mercury Prize-winning trio are as adept at envelope-pushing sonic experimentalism and opaque lyrical impressionism as they are at soulful pop hooks and festival-primed chorusesâ€”frequently, in the space of the same song. Coming off the back of an extended hiatus following 2018â€™s acclaimed Cocoa Sugar, the Edinburgh threesome entered their basement studio with no grand plan for their fourth studio album other than to reconnect to the creative process, and each other. Little was explicitly discussed. Instead, Alloysious Massaquoi, Kayus Bankole and Graham â€œGâ€ Hastingsâ€”all friends since their school daysâ€”intuitively reacted to a lyric, a piece of music or a beat that one of them had conceived to create multifaceted pieces of work that, for all their complexities and contradictions, hit home with soul-lifting, often spiritual, directness. Through the joyous clatter of opener â€œRiceâ€, the electro-glam battle cry â€œI Sawâ€, the epic â€œTell Somebodyâ€ and the shape-shifting sonic explosion of closer â€œBe Your Ladyâ€, Young Fathers express every peak and trough of the human condition within often-dense tapestries of sounds and words. â€œEach song serves an integral purpose to create something that feels cohesive,â€ says Bankole. â€œYou can find joy in silence, you can find happiness in pain. You can find all these intricate feelings and diverse feelings that reflect reality in the best possible way within these songs.â€ Across 10 dazzling tracks, Heavy Heavy has all that and more, making it the bandâ€™s most fully realised and affecting work to date. Let Massaquoi and Bankole guide you through it, track by track. â€œRiceâ€ Alloysious Massaquoi: â€œWhat weâ€™re great at doing is attaching ourselves to what the feeling of the track is and then building from that, so the lyrics start to come from that point of view. [On â€˜Riceâ€™] that feeling of it being joyous was what we were connecting to. It was the feeling of fresh morning air. Youâ€™re on a journey, youâ€™re moving towards something, it feels like youâ€™re coming home to find it again. For me, it was finding that feeling of, â€˜OK, I love music again,â€™ because during COVID it felt redundant to me. What mattered to me was looking after my family.â€ â€œI Sawâ€ AM: â€œWeâ€™d been talking about Brexit, colonialism, about forgetting the contributions of other countries and nations so that was in the air. And when we attached ourselves to the feeling of the song, it had that call-to-arms feeling to it, itâ€™s like a march.â€ Kayus Bankole: â€œIt touches on Brexit, but it also touches on how effective turning a blind eye can be, that idea that thereâ€™s nothing really you can do. Itâ€™s a call to arms, but thereâ€™s also this massive question mark. I get super-buzzed by leaving question marks so you can engage in some form of conversation afterwards.â€ â€œDrumâ€ AM: â€œItâ€™s got that sort of gospel spiritual aspect to it. Thereâ€™s an intensity in that. Itâ€™s almost like a sermon is happening.â€ KB: â€œThe intensity of it is like a possession. A good, spiritual thing. For me, speaking in my native tongue [Yoruba] is like channelling a part of me that the Western world canâ€™t express. I sometimes feel like the English language fails me, and in the Western world not a lot of people speak my language or understand what Iâ€™m saying, so itâ€™s connecting to my true self and expressing myself in a true way.â€ â€œTell Somebodyâ€ AM: â€œIt was so big, so epic that we just needed to be direct. The lyrics had to be relatable. Itâ€™s about having that balance. You have to really boil it down and think, â€˜What is it Iâ€™m trying to say here?â€™ You have 20 lines and you cut it down to just five and thatâ€™s what makes it powerful. I think it might mean something different to everyone in the group, but I know what it means to me, through my experiences, and thatâ€™s what I was channelling. The more you lean into yourself, the more relatable it is.â€ â€œGeronimoâ€ AM: â€œItâ€™s talking about relationships: â€˜Being a son, brother, uncle, father figure/I gotta survive and provide/My mama said, â€œYouâ€™ll never ever please your woman/But youâ€™ll have a good time trying.â€â€™ Itâ€™s relatable again, but then you have this nihilistic cynicism from Graham: â€˜Nobody goes anywhere really/Dressed up just to go in the dirt.â€™ Itâ€™s a bit nihilistic, but given the reality of the world and how things are, I think you need the balance of those things. Jump on, jump off. Itâ€™s like: decide. Youâ€™re either hot or youâ€™re cold. Donâ€™t be lukewarm. You either go for it or you donâ€™t. Then encapsulating all that within Geronimo, this Native American hero.â€ â€œShoot Me Downâ€ AM: â€œâ€˜Shoot Me Downâ€™ is definitely steeped in humanity. Youâ€™ve got everything in there. Youâ€™ve got the insecurities, the cynicism, youâ€™ve got the joy, the pain, the indifference. Youâ€™ve got all those things churning around in this cauldron. Thereâ€™s a level of regret in there as well. Again, when you lean into yourself, it becomes more relatable to everybody else.â€ â€œUlulationâ€ KB: â€œItâ€™s the first time weâ€™ve ever used anyone else on a track. A really close friend of mine, who I call a sister, called me while we were making â€˜Uluationâ€™: â€˜I need a place to stay, Iâ€™m having a difficult time with my husband, Iâ€™m really angry at himâ€¦â€™ I said if you need a place to chill just come down to the studio and listen to us while we work but you mustnâ€™t say a word because weâ€™re working. Weâ€™re working on the track and she started humming in the background. Alloy picked up on it and was like, â€˜Give her a mic!â€™ Sheâ€™s singing about gratitude. In the midst of feeling very angry, feeling like shit and that lifeâ€™s not fair, she still had that emotion that she can practise gratitude. I think thatâ€™s a beautiful contrast of emotions.â€ â€œSink Or Swimâ€ AM: â€œIt says a similar thing to what weâ€™re saying on â€˜Geronimoâ€™ but with more panache. The music has that feeling of a carousel, youâ€™re jumping on and jumping off. If you watch Steve McQueenâ€™s Small Axe [film anthology], in Lovers Rock, when theyâ€™re in the house party before the fire startsâ€”this fits perfectly to that. Itâ€™s that intensity, the sweat and the smoke, but with these direct lines thrown in: â€˜Oh baby, wonâ€™t you let me in?â€™ and â€˜Donâ€™t always have to be so deepâ€™. Sometimes you need a bit of directness, you need to call a spade a spade.â€ â€œHoly Molyâ€ AM: â€œItâ€™s a contrast between light and dark. Youâ€™re forcing two things that donâ€™t make sense together. You have a pop song and some weird beat, and youâ€™re forcing them to have this conversation, to do something, and then â€˜Holy Molyâ€™ comes out of that. Itâ€™s two different worlds coming together and what cements it is the lyrics.â€ â€œBe Your Ladyâ€ KB: â€œItâ€™s the perfect loop back to the first track so you could stay in the loop of the album for decades, centuries and millenniums and just bask in these intricate parts. â€˜Be Your Ladyâ€™ is a nice wave goodbye, but itâ€™s also radical as fuck. That last line â€˜Can I take 10 poundsâ€™ worth of loving out of the bank please?â€™ Iâ€™m repeating it and Iâ€™m switching the accents of it as well because I switch accents in conversation. I sometimes speak like someone whoâ€™s from Washington, D.C. [where Bankole has previously lived], or someone whoâ€™s lived in the Southside of Edinburgh, and I sometimes speak like someone whoâ€™s from Lagos in Nigeria.â€ AM: â€œI wasnâ€™t convinced about that track initially. I was like, â€˜What the fuck is this?â€™â€ KB: â€œThatâ€™s good, though. Thatâ€™s the feeling that you want. Thatâ€™s why I feel itâ€™s radical. Itâ€™s something that only we can do, it comes together and it feels right.â€
entries.title: Heavy Heavy

entries.notes: The more I listen the better it gets.
entries.title: Black To The Future

entries.notes: Lana Del Rey has mastered the art of carefully constructed, high-concept alt-pop records that bask inâ€”and steadily amplifyâ€”her own mythology; with each album we become more enamoured by, and yet less sure of, who she is. This is, of course, part of her magic and the source of much of her artistic power. Her records bid you to worry less about parsing fact from fiction and, instead, free-fall into her theatrical aestheticâ€”a mix of gloomy Americana, Laurel Canyon nostalgia and Hollywood noir that was once dismissed as calculation and is now revered as performance art. Up until now, these slippery, surrealist albums have made it difficult to separate artist from art. But on her introspective ninth album, something seems to shift: She appears to let us in a little. She appears to let down her guard. The opening track is called â€œThe Grantsâ€â€”a nod to her actual family name. Through unusually revealing, stream-of-conscious songs that feel like the most poetic voice notes youâ€™ve ever heard, she chastises her siblings, wonders about marriage and imagines what might come with motherhood and midlife. â€œDo you want children?/Do you wanna marry me?â€ she sings on â€œSweetâ€. â€œDo you wanna run marathons in Long Beach by the sea?â€ This is relatively new lyrical territory for Del Rey, who has generally tended to steer around personal details, and the songs themselves feel looser and more off-the-cuff (they were mostly produced with long-time collaborator Jack Antonoff). It could be that Lana has finally decided to start peeling back a few layers, but for an artist whose entire catalogue is rooted in clever imagery, itâ€™s best to leave room for imagination. The only clue might be in the albumâ€™s single piece of promo, a now-infamous billboard in Tulsa, Oklahoma, her ex-boyfriendâ€™s hometown. She settled the point fairly quickly on Instagram. â€œItâ€™s personal,â€ she wrote.
entries.title: Did you know that there's a tunnel under Ocean Blvd

entries.notes: â€œWhen itâ€™s just us two, itâ€™s really easy to make music,â€ JD BECK tells Apple Music. â€œWe play around, and the tracks come pouring out.â€ Instrumental prodigies DOMi & JD BECK certainly have a telepathic connection when it comes to creativity. First meeting in 2018 at the NAMM trade show in Southern California, where the two teenagers were individually invited to perform as part of a larger ensemble, Texas-born drummer BECK formed an instant connection with French keyboardist and Berklee student DOMi Louna (born Domitille Degalle). The pair soon began writing fast-paced, note-packed jams to upload to their Instagram, and by 2020, they had caught the attention of multi-instrumentalist Anderson .Paak. Swiftly signing them to his APESHIT label, he challenged the duo to release an updated body of work as a debut. â€œHe basically told us we could do better than the albumâ€™s worth of material we already had,â€ BECK says. â€œSo, we put together a wish list of collaborators and got to work.â€ The result is NOT TiGHT, a 15-track jazz-fusion odyssey of head-nodding hip-hop, psychedelic vocoder experiments and rhythmic freakouts. â€œWe just wanted to surprise ourselves with this album,â€ DOMi says. â€œThis music is an expression of ourselves at our core.â€ Here, DOMi & JD BECK offer their thoughts on each of the albumâ€™s tracks. â€œLOUNAâ€™S iNTROâ€ DOMi Louna: â€œWe thought the album needed book-ending to help bring the listener in and then back out of the tracks. We already had the outro, â€œTHANK Uâ€, so we wrote these chords and added synth patches before sending it to violin, double bass, viola, cello and harp players all around the world. It was like a mini online orchestra opening the album for us.â€ â€œWHATUPâ€ DL: â€œWeâ€™ve had these chords since 2018, as they were part of a track that was going to be the intro for our original album. We kept playing around with it when we were locked down together during the pandemic, and after deconstructing it a few times, we decided to make a new tune. We added a drum solo section, and so now the record has two intros before we get into â€˜SMiLEâ€™.â€ â€œSMiLEâ€ JD BECK: â€œI sing dumb little melodies a lot, and when I was in the bathroom on my phone one day in 2018, the melody just came to me. I put it together in my head and shouted to DOMi to quickly set it to some chords.â€ â€œBOWLiNGâ€ (feat. Thundercat) JDB: â€œWe met Thundercat around the same time as meeting each other. Whenever we were in LA, we would go and stay with him and take over his house. We always write a lot with him when weâ€™re thereâ€”we must have 50 song ideas together already. Back in 2018, weâ€™d all go bowling a lot, as itâ€™s his favourite thing to do, and so we wrote this song about hanging out in the bowling alley.â€ â€œNOT TiGHTâ€ (feat. Thundercat) JDB: â€œItâ€™s probably the closest representation of our soundâ€”just singing random melodic lines to crazy chord combinations. In 2019, we played it for Thundercat, and he loved it so much that he wanted to be on it. He became the first instrumentalist to collaborate with us, and it was incredible to have him soloing on the track with DOMi.â€ â€œTWO SHRiMPSâ€ (feat. Mac DeMarco) DL: â€œWe wrote the instrumental for this track while we were on tour in 2019. JD had a little drum machine, which he made a loop on, and then I added the keyboard parts and put it in a 9/8 time signature. We met Mac the same day we met Anderson .Paak in 2019, and by 2020, we were spending a lot of time at Macâ€™s house. We played him this instrumental, and he started singing along to it, just listing random sandwich names. The track was originally called â€˜Sandwiches of Americaâ€™. We ended up re-recording new lyrics with him, but thankfully itâ€™s still food-related.â€ â€œU DONâ€™T HAVE TO ROB MEâ€ JDB: â€œIâ€™ve been playing gigs by myself since I was 11, and I got used to the element of danger, being in cities late at night. When DOMi and I started going out in LA, you could feel when there was danger, like one day we were in the parking lot of the bowling alley at 1 am, and this dude asked us for a cigarette, and it really felt like he might pull a knife on us too. It made us think about how we never have cashâ€”only cards that we can cancel easilyâ€”so why even go through that trouble of robbing us?â€ â€œMOONâ€ (feat. Herbie Hancock) JDB: â€œAndy made us write down all our goals for the record, and among them was a list of people weâ€™d love to work with. Herbie was at the top of those names. One of Andyâ€™s managers had a connect with Herbie, and he called us one day to say that Herbie had watched our videos on YouTube and was down to collaborate.â€ DL: â€œWe were shitting our pants, as we knew we now had to come up with the best song weâ€™d ever written. Sunlight is some of our favourite stuff that Herbie has done with the vocoder, and so we wrote â€˜MOONâ€™ to that same vibe. Luckily, we got him on piano, too, and when we recorded it together in 2021, we got to hang out with him, which was amazing.â€ â€œDUKEâ€ JDB: â€œThis track is a George Duke reference. We had been hanging out a lot with Earl Sweatshirt and his producer Black Noise, and they inspired us to put three of our loops together into one track and then record it as a new song. The record is full of crazy songs, and we needed something to chill after Herbieâ€”a track that has a natural feel.â€ â€œTAKE A CHANCEâ€ (feat. Anderson .Paak) DL: â€œWe really wanted a feature from Anderson, as weâ€™re huge fans of his, and so we had to come up with something unique and very pretty for him to sing and play on. JD wrote this hook, and when we played it to Andy, he just started rapping over the verses, and then we all sang on the chorus. The whole track was a bunch of surprises and sections put together, since Andy can fit over pretty much anything.â€ â€œSPACE MOUNTAiNâ€ JDB: â€œWhen we first got to LA, I couldnâ€™t get into any clubs, so the only thing we ended up doing, apart from making music, was going to Disneyland. We went on the ride Space Mountain a lot, and it felt like the perfect title for this crazy tune. The first section is a loop we wrote in 2019, where I recorded the drums through an intense compressor, and then the second half used to be part of the original intro to our first album.â€ â€œPiLOTâ€ (feat. Anderson .Paak, Busta Rhymes & Snoop Dogg) DL: â€œWe made this beat in 2020, before we signed with Anderson. We used to send him clips of what we were making, and the day after we sent him this, he emailed it back with him and Busta on it, which was amazing. Once we signed, we had Snoop Dogg on our dream list of collabs, and we thought he would be perfect for â€˜PiLOTâ€™. He was down for it, so we went to Snoopâ€™s studio for six hours one day and recorded it all super smooth. It was very cool to see him and Andy interact and write to our loop.â€ â€œWHOAâ€ (feat. Kurt Rosenwinkel) JDB: â€œDOMi wrote the first part of this tune when she was 12. It was on a random Sibelius session that she played by accident, and I loved it. I knew we had to do a song with it, and Kurt felt like the perfect fit. We met him through the drummer Louis Cole when we were in New York in 2019. A week after he had the track, he sent it back with him soloing from beginning to end. It was perfect.â€ â€œSNiFFâ€ DL: â€œThe original title for this was â€˜You Can Sniff My Buttâ€™. JD wrote it in 2018, all in one go in front of meâ€”and itâ€™s one of my favourite things heâ€™s ever made. We played it at every show as a closer and people loved its pace, so it felt like a good idea to close the record with it too. It was one of the earliest songs we came up with together.â€ â€œTHANK Uâ€ JDB: â€œThis used to be a crazy loop in a 13 time signature, which was called â€˜Dermatologistâ€™ because DOMi had just learned what that word was. We wrote it in an Airbnb somewhere in 2018 and then, when we came back to it a few years later for this record, we realised it was perfect to send to the mini-orchestra who played on the intro. It rounds out the album really well.â€
entries.title: NOT TiGHT

entries.notes: Composed during the darkest days of the pandemic, this beautiful album reunites Dutch composer Joep Beving with his cherished Schimmel upright piano and offers up beauty and peace in a destabilised world. Hermetism is inspired by ancient philosophical ideas of nature and the universe. No track rises far above a whisper, yet they are all compelling in their expressive power. Beving journeys through an array of influences, from the timelessness of Bach (â€œAccent Graveâ€, â€œLast Danceâ€) and Eastern modal inflection (â€œDervishâ€) to the haunting simplicity of 19th-century French composer Erik Satie (â€œLe fee verteâ€). In the childlike, Chopin-inspired waltz â€œParis sâ€™enflammeâ€, Beving pays a heartfelt tribute to the French capital, while the final track, â€œRosesâ€, takes the role of a calming, hypnotic postlude.
entries.title: Hermetism

entries.notes: Conforming to the expected has never been Amaaraeâ€™s strong suit. And it should come as no surprise that the Ghanaian American artist would create a sonic otherworld where the trappings of R&B, hip-hop, Afropop, punk and alternative rock mesh with globe-trotting instrumentation and exist harmoniously without question on her album Fountain Baby. The result? A culmination of what a transnational pop star is in 2023â€”boundless. Fountain Baby lends its credence to Amaaraeâ€™s continued quest for growth and mastery, but not in a contrived way. There are pockets of carefully crafted yet carefree melodies like the dreamy â€œAngels in Tibetâ€ and sultry â€œReckless & Sweetâ€. On â€œCounterfeitâ€, the singer-songwriter swiftly glides with confidence on production by KZ Didit thatâ€™s reminiscent of an early-2000s movie soundtrack. â€œWasted Eyesâ€ opens with a quick koto solo and progresses as Amaarae soliloquises about a wounded romance. The 14-track solo project pushes the ante of its 2020 predecessor, The Angel You Donâ€™t Know, towards newer heights.
entries.title: Fountain Baby

entries.notes: This is a remarkable album. Remixes of Butterlfy 3000 which I missed at album last year. DJ Shadow opens with a great track and itâ€™s a mixed bag of sometimes really nice remixes vs long boring stuff.
entries.title: Butterfly 3001

entries.notes: Brimming with astrological fervour and unbridled emotionality, Red Moon in Venus finds the Colombian American sensation zeroing in on love. From the proud promises behind â€œEndlesslyâ€ to the sweet little profundities of â€œLove Between...â€, the album plays with genre without losing cohesion or connection. On the guest front, Don Toliver matches her R&B potency amid the polyrhythmic blur of â€œFantasyâ€, while Omar Apollo brings his own certain charm to the sumptuous duet â€œWorth the Waitâ€. Yet most of the album keeps the spotlight rightfully on her, leading to breathtaking moments like â€œI Wish You Rosesâ€ and the Sade-esque â€œBlueâ€. And while Red Moon in Venus returns the artist to a primarily English-language mode, she hasnâ€™t dispatched entirely with the approach taken on 2020â€™s Sin Miedo (del Amor y Otros Demonios) âˆž. She brings bilingual lyricism alongside orchestral accents for â€œComo Te Quiero Yoâ€ and retro grooves for â€œHasta Cuandoâ€.
entries.title: Red Moon In Venus

entries.notes: Pharaoh Sanders revisited.
entries.title: Gold

entries.notes:
The Avalanches are back. This third album resembles very much their groundbreaking debut album â€˜Since I Left Youâ€™, from almost two decades ago. Absolutely stunning with a return of Terence Trend dâ€™Arby under a complete different name in the best song of the album titled â€˜Reflecting Lightâ€™.
The more I listen to this album, the better it gets.
entries.title: We Will Always Love You

entries.notes: In an ambient-music landscape well-stocked with vague spiritualism and aural equivalents of palliative care, the tension in Tim Heckerâ€™s productions has always stood out. It isnâ€™t that the Montreal artistâ€™s music is dark or confrontational per se, though he can be (â€œAnxietyâ€â€”good title); itâ€™s that he uses beauty as a bridge to more emotionally indeterminate qualities and states. Just listen to the way the pulsing minimalism of â€œLotus Lightâ€ wavers between meditative and threatening, or how the drones of â€œLiving Spa Waterâ€ seem to rot in real time. More than 20 years out from the glitchy sound of his early albums and heâ€™s still one of the most engrossing artists in his field.
entries.title: No Highs

entries.notes: Alongside Moor Motherâ€™s 2021 album, Black Encyclopedia of the Air, Jazz Codes explores the question of how accessible a generally inaccessible artist can get without sacrificing the density of their ideas. It isnâ€™t to say itâ€™s easy music (45 tightly collaged minutes of spoken word, free jazz, electronic loops and fragmentary hip-hop)â€”only that it makes space for the listener in ways she hasnâ€™t always in the past. Given the albumâ€™s subject matterâ€”jazz history, the nature and place of Black artâ€”itâ€™s easy to hear the shift as one from personal expression to stewardship and communication: She wants you to understand where sheâ€™s coming from as a gesture of respect to those who came before, whether Woody Shaw (â€œWOODY SHAWâ€), Mary Lou Williams (â€œODE TO MARYâ€) or Joe McPhee (â€œJOE MCPHEE NATION TIMEâ€). Her fellow travellersâ€”multi-hyphenate Black artists like AKAI SOLO and Melanie Charlesâ€”show you she isnâ€™t alone. And while the difficulty lingers, it gets explicit purpose, courtesy of professor, artist and activist Thomas Stanley on the outro: â€œUltimately, perhaps, it is good that people abandoned jazz/Replaced it with musical products better-suited to capitalismâ€™s designs/Now jazz jumps up like Lazarus if we allow it, to rediscover itself as a living music.â€
entries.title: Jazz Codes

entries.notes: The Norwegian duo assemble a guest-packed ride of glossy ambient anthems.
entries.title: Profound Mysteries II

entries.notes: Third album of Sault now about London, its gangs and other dark aspects. Again, nice combination of afro beats, great rhythms, jazz influence and nice lyrics. But not as great as two previous albums. Maybe it has to grow on me?
entries.title: Nine

entries.notes: Ever since 2013, when Sons of Kemet saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings first leapt onstage to join synth-and-drums duo Soccer96 in a spontaneous explosion of pure groove, the three musicians have been honing their gale-force attack. Dubbed The Comet Is Coming, the trioâ€”Hutchings, drummer Max Hallett and synth player Dan Leaversâ€”first laid out their double-barrelled jazz-dance fusion on 2016â€™s Channel the Spirits, then gave free rein to more psychedelic urges on 2019â€™s Trust in the Lifeforce of the Deep Mystery and The Afterlife, which followed six months later. With Hyper-Dimensional Expansion Beam, The Comet Is Coming deliver their biggest, most expansive record yet. Part of that might stem from recording at Peter Gabrielâ€™s Real World Studios, where the three musicians tracked four days of improv sessions that Hallett and Leavers subsequently reworked into these 11 powerhouse jams. In contrast to the previous two albumsâ€™ star-gazing tendencies, Hyper-Dimensional Expansion Beam unleashes a focused blast of energy with the opening â€œCODEâ€, with Hutchings meting out stabbing arpeggios over the rhythm sectionâ€™s heads-down stomp. They expand their range with every track. â€œTECHNICOLOURâ€ is a slinky detour into liquid funk, and â€œLUCID DREAMERâ€ drifts on a cloud of ambient soul; album highlight â€œPYRAMIDSâ€ taps the tunnel-vision intensity of early-2000s techno. â€œATOMIC WAVE DANCEâ€ is another big one, with spiky sax riffs set against jagged arpeggios and a driving 4/4 beat, while on â€œAFTERMATHâ€, they pursue krautrock down an almost ambient path. And listeners pining for the last albumsâ€™ offworld vibes will find an escape pod in the form of â€œANGEL OF DARKNESSâ€, an unrestrained journey to their cosmic-jazz limits. The Comet Is Coming have never sounded tighterâ€”or freerâ€”than they do here.
entries.title: Hyper-Dimensional Expansion Beam

entries.notes: Mike Hadreasâ€™ music as Perfume Genius has always walked an interesting line between experimentalism and accessibilityâ€”pop for listeners more interested in â€œpopâ€ as a concept than a reality. Written as a companion to a dance piece by choreographer Kate Wallich, Ugly Season effectively inverts the balance, situating Hadreasâ€™ hallmarksâ€”his romanticism, his expressivity, his startling, sometimes violent sense of dramaâ€”in the context of something that plays more like a symphony or soundtrack than a set of discrete songs. The title is a feint, of course: This is extremely beautiful music even in its dissonance, from the Philip Glass-like grid of â€œTeethâ€ and the spiderweb instrumental of â€œScherzoâ€ to the industrial roar of â€œHellbentâ€. And just in case, he gives you something called â€œPop Songâ€â€”which isnâ€™t one, of course.
entries.title: Ugly Season

entries.notes:
What a remarkable album: 45 minutes using one repeating accord glued together with the sax of Pharoah Sanders, culminating somewhere in the middle in a sound orgy thanks to the London Symphony Orchestra and then fading out once again with the help of Pharoah Sanders. Superb job by Floating Points all over the place.
From Pitchfork: â€œThroughout its emotional 46 minutes, Promises stirs feelings that can be hard to name. The first sound we hear is one that courses through the entire pieceâ€”a brief, seven-note refrain played by what seems to be a harpsichord, sometimes accented by a bell-like tone that could be the celeste. The cluster of sounds begins in silence, and we can hear the creak of wood and some shifting objects in the room where it was recorded, and it repeats every nine seconds for almost the duration of the piece. Itâ€™s a small twinkly loop that brings to mind the feeling of awakening, as if something that was unclear is now understood, there to be rediscovered with each cycle. And that repeating fragment holds the composition together, and every sound exists in relation to it, even if we canâ€™t quite sense how they fit together.â€
entries.title: Promises

entries.notes: Long before he made his name at jazzâ€™s vanguard, editing together off-the-cuff live sessions like a hip-hop beatmaker, drummer and producer, Makaya McCraven set out to create a comprehensive record of his collaborative processâ€”a testament to the intuition of improvisation. Its sessions recorded over the course of seven years, between multiple projects and releases, In These Times is McCravenâ€™s sixth album as a bandleader, and it showcases the virtuosic instrumentalists he has spent his career building an almost telepathic bond withâ€”bassist Junius Paul and guitarist Jeff Parker among them. Itâ€™s also the warmest and most enveloping album heâ€™s produced to date. Frenetic beat-splicing might underpin the polyrhythms of tracks such as â€œSeventh Stringâ€ and â€œThis Place That Placeâ€, but the soft melodies played by Parker and harpist Brandee Younger always permeateâ€”a reminder of the clarity of the moment of creation, rather than its post-production manipulation. Indeed, In These Times is a reflection of the past decade of McCravenâ€™s instrumental expertise, but itâ€™s also a powerful reminder of the freedom inherent in this time, in the here and now of making music together, when the artist lets go and surrounds us with the ineffable beauty of collective creation.
entries.title: In These Times

entries.notes: Listeners expecting the stylish soul-funk of Saultâ€™s 2020 albums Untitled (Rise) and Untitled (Black Is) might be momentarily thrown by the cosmic choral-and-orchestral suite of Air, but thematically, it fits: Like all their music, Air is, at heart, a study of Black artistic traditions, in this case early-â€™70s Alice Coltrane (â€œSolarâ€), the soulful ambience of Stevie Wonderâ€™s Journey Through the Secret Life of Plants (â€œHeartâ€), even a little of the modern-classical side of artists like Anthony Braxton. And as sci-fi as the sound can seem, the core feeling is one of uplifting Earthâ€”a message confirmed as equally by the skyward arc of the strings as by the prayer-like recitation on â€œTime Is Preciousâ€. Or, as producer Inflo tells Apple Music, not fantasy, but â€œart in realityâ€â€”air.
entries.title: Air

entries.notes: â€œâ€˜Do the wrong thingâ€™ is my thing,â€ TJ â€œLil Silvaâ€ Carter tells Apple Music. â€œBecause everyone thinks, â€˜Oh, we've got to use this bassline, or do that sound.â€™ But actually, we should all strive to be in the now. What feels good, right now?â€ More than a decade on from his teen emergence in the UKâ€™s Funky House scene, Lil Silvaâ€™s genre-bending odyssey lands here: a debut LP hosting a vigorous bout between ego and self-doubt. â€œIt's all self work,â€ he says. "But thatâ€™s important, because how much time do you want to invest in yourself? What do you want to unlock in your brain that you havenâ€™t? How much are you worth?" These questions arose for the producer, singer, songwriter and DJ throughout the course of deep meditation and Theta healing (an energy healing technique and spiritual philosophy), and lay central to his ongoing exploration of the self. Yesterday Is Heavy crafts a moving elegy that explores feelings of alienation (â€œBackwardsâ€), raw emotion (â€œAnother Sketchâ€) and disjointedness (â€œStillâ€) experienced throughout lockdown, and remedied in rich, experimental textures that draw on the sincerity of Silvaâ€™s bluesy vocals and arrangement style, plus some eclectic collaborations (including standout moments with Sampha and Little Dragon). â€œIâ€™ve always been skeptical about being genre specific,â€ he says. "Iâ€™ve always known that Lil Silva is going to be a sound. Yes, Iâ€™ve been influenced by Timberland, Pharrell, and even the early grime era of Davince, Plastician, Jon E Cash, Wiley. All have defining sounds. But I wasnâ€™t listening to music for about two years when making this album. I was only going back in my archive, and bringing out what hadnâ€™t seen the light of day.â€ Here, Lil Silva talks us through the 12 expansive tracks of his debut album, track by track. â€œAnother Sketchâ€ â€œIâ€™m constantly inspired by the changing state of water. The idea that something can be, in real time, one thing, in the past something else, and in the future have a different existence, state or body. This song is about heritage, and moments in time, whether thatâ€™s in the past, present or future. So itâ€™s about family, also.â€ â€œBe Coolâ€ (with Little Dragon) â€œI started writing this song with [producer and multi-instrumentalist] Mansur Brown. Heâ€™s dangerous to be in a studio with because in between trying to finish a song, he'll play something crazy, I think we made five songs that day. His [guitar] playing is insane, and the way he's got his pedal game is a joke. He was playing this groove, and I done this whole beat around it. And after I wrote this song, I sent it over and [Little Dragonâ€™s] Yukimi [Nagano] loved it. It really related to her, and she also added in a few things. Iâ€™d done some remix work with Little Dragon before, but weâ€™d been itching to get a song of our own together.â€ â€œVera (Judah Speaks)â€ â€œThis track picks up from the tempo of the intro. I started with the drums off the top, working with [producer] Duncan Laurence, we did â€œDeja Vuâ€ [on 2016 EP Jimi] together, and working with peope that I consider family on this album just felt right. We created this orchestral feel and had strings played by [composer and arranger] Sally Herbert. Iâ€™ve always known Iâ€™d have some strings on my albumâ€”and that goes back to my early tracks like [2008 single] â€œSeasonsâ€, with the brass influence, Iâ€™m just pulling from that.â€ â€œLeave Itâ€ (with Charlotte Day Wilson) â€œThis is a message about celebrating whatâ€™s right in front of you. Thereâ€™s no need to worry, or at least donâ€™t worry for too long. The clouds of doubts that hover over, in life, and sometimes in love feel like youâ€™ll never move out of. But, however grey and however challenging, thereâ€™s a way to get through it. Itâ€™s too easy to get caught up in everything around you. â€œSeptemberâ€ â€œThere was a lot raw emotion in this. I was definitely feeling a lot of grit in that day, and it all came out in â€˜Septemberâ€™. I was with James Vincent McMorrow and Benji B, and weâ€™d clipped through this sample, and Benji played it for me at the perfect time. I was like: â€˜Wow, I've never really put samples on my song before like this.â€™ So, it was paying homage to it I guess. James is dope, really dynamic, and always comes up with these crazy interesting melody trips. And Benji has done a lot. Heâ€™s the perfect guy to have in the room, for his energy, and knowledge of music, to radio, and fashion. It wouldn't have felt right if I didn't have the [club brand] Deviation family in-and-out of this, to bounce the energy off, because my music's gone from the club to here, and he's been a massive part of that.â€ â€œTo The Floorâ€ (with BADBADNOTGOOD) â€œIt's in the title, man. Just get to it, basically. With BADBADNOTGOOD, we had this unconventional arrangement and it was about just pocketing those grooves, and the funk. This was one of the five, myself and Mansur had done, but I was like, man, this could definitely have an extra bit of funkâ€”there's a groove that could be interesting here. So I played the idea to BADBADNOTGOOD, and they came through with: drums, guitar, and even some flutes!â€ â€œBackwardsâ€ (with Sampha) â€œThis song touches on the feeling of alienation and constantly venting in the matrix you find yourself in, whatever that may be. Restricted and feeling guilty to move forward, constantly going backwards mentally; I guess the song is about being in a never ending cycle and the heaviness that can bring.â€ â€œWhat If? (with Skiifall)â€ â€œI really channeled inspiration from our roots on this record. You can hear the reggae, bashment and grime influence weave in and out. This track is about the course we find ourselves on, without even thinking. Itâ€™s about the huge role that love and family plays in our lives, but staying grounded and never forgetting what got us here.â€ â€œColoursâ€ â€œI was coming into the studio shoot for about four or five days, I kept singing, â€˜There's colours, colorus, coloursâ€™â€¦ it's like, why is this bugging me? It's every day, saying the same thing. It just kept trickling through my brain. And I made that into this beautiful soul thing, and eventually I switched it up. This bassline you could say comes from grimeâ€”but grime is in me. I used to be in [Bedford grime collective] Macabre Unit back in the day.â€ â€œAbout Usâ€ (with Elmiene) â€œIt was good for me to get back into my archive, it was like a massive soundboard for myself with sounds and work I could take. Across this process when I would have a block, I would just dig in my archive, as you would, it's almost like I'm going to remix one of my tracks that no one knows about this. It's all there.â€ â€œStillâ€ (with Sampha & Ghetts) â€œWe were all in the room jamming for around 30 minutes. And as Iâ€™ve dissected this beatâ€”everyone behind me, they all loved this bassline. But I didn't like it. Just how familiar, or how close to familiar it was, so I flipped it and found the right bass. Then Sampha dropped the first line, and I knew he had to repeat it. It's so honest, man, it's just like, â€˜Fuck, I still got all this shit to doâ€™. And he just kept on flowing. And that was the thing: If it feels good to me now, we're going to do it now. This shit was lighting me up. Because if it's not lighting you up, why are you doing it?â€ â€œEnds Nowâ€ (with serpentwithfeet) â€œSo weâ€™re back to Mansurâ€™s crazy licks. I breathed a vocal on this, and asked Serpentâ€™ to try some vocals on it, and he fell in love. He just got it. Then he's taking my lyrics and putting them in places to sustain his vocal in moments, and pocket it differently. Heâ€™s also not trying to do the conventional thing, itâ€™s all about what feels good.â€
entries.title: Yesterday Is Heavy

entries.notes: Like a lot of music made in the early 2020s, the electronic pop producer and dance music experimenter Kathy Yaeji Leeâ€™s colourful, searching first official album was born in part out of the forced reckonings of the pandemic. â€œThe promptâ€”which is what started the storyâ€”was my anger,â€ Yaeji tells Apple Music. â€œIâ€™m stuck in my room. I have no distractions. Thoughts, memories, things I havenâ€™t processed because I would distract myself usuallyâ€”they started to come up. And for the first time, from all of thatâ€”from remembering childhood, from what was happening around us politically, sociallyâ€”I felt deep anger, and I had no idea what to do with it. So I said, 'I have to make something. I have to write.'â€ But part of what makes the album interesting is Leeâ€™s ability to frame that anger with sounds that feel inviting, even celebratoryâ€”a contrast that has the meditative effect of diffusing emotions even as she expresses them; or, put another way, to demonstrate curiosity about them instead of just venting them, whether itâ€™s the panic of cyclic thinking (â€œFor Grantedâ€, â€œDone [Letâ€™s Get It]â€) or the discomfort of self-alienation (â€œPassed Me Byâ€). â€œWhen I write, itâ€™s to understand what happened better, to understand myself better,â€ she says. â€œAnd for that reason, in the moment, Iâ€™m not clocking whatâ€™s happening or exactly what it is Iâ€™m writing about. But then, after Iâ€™m done writing it, after I play it for a friend, after it comes out into the worldâ€”sometimes thatâ€™s when I realise or fully process the thing I was trying to figure out.â€ The feelings of With a Hammer are hot, but the musicâ€”spacious, patient, round, guided by Leeâ€™s naturally diminutive voiceâ€”is cool. The project also offered Lee opportunities to discover new creative approaches. The flute that opens â€œSubmerge FMâ€, for example, was one of many samples Lee collected from sessions with friends before sheâ€™d even started writing the album in earnest but whose role didnâ€™t become clear until much later. â€œI just sat with this loop on forever and then I started improvising on my synth, and it became almost like this conversation or call-and-response. And thatâ€™s what started the first track on the albumâ€”me just having a conversation with Gabby [Gabrielle Garo].â€ (Similar conversations appear with a trumpet on â€œIâ€™ll Remember for Me, Iâ€™ll Remember for Youâ€ and fractured percussion on â€œWith a Hammerâ€.) She also managed to further explore not just her identity as a speaker of Korean and English, but the way both languages can dovetail with the abstractions of musical expression. â€œWhen I was writing â€˜Passed Me Byâ€™, the main chorus of it isnâ€™t even made up of lyrics, itâ€™s just sound,â€ she says. â€œAnd the combination of the bass and the [â€™90s-style] synthâ€¦made me feel like Iâ€™m expressing a feeling I havenâ€™t been able to say in words before.â€
entries.title: With A Hammer

entries.notes: When Kendrick Lamar popped up on two tracks from Baby Keemâ€™s The Melodic Blue (â€œrange brothersâ€ and â€œfamily tiesâ€), it felt like one of hip-hopâ€™s prophets had descended a mountain to deliver scripture. His verses were stellar, to be sure, but it also just felt like way too much time had passed since weâ€™d heard his voice. Heâ€™d helmed 2018â€™s Black Panther compilation/soundtrack, but his last proper release was 2017â€™s DAMN. That kind of scarcity in hip-hop can only serve to deify an artist as beloved as Lamar. But if the Compton MC is broadcasting anything across his fifth proper album Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers, itâ€™s that heâ€™s only human. The project is split into two parts, each comprising nine songs, all of which serve to illuminate Lamarâ€™s continually evolving world view. Central to Lamarâ€™s thesis is accountability. The MC has painstakingly itemised his shortcomings, assessing his relationships with money (â€œUnited in Griefâ€), white women (â€œWorldwide Steppersâ€), his father (â€œFather Timeâ€), the limits of his loyalty (â€œRich Spiritâ€), love in the context of heteronormative relationships (â€œWe Cry Togetherâ€, â€œPurple Heartsâ€), motivation (â€œCount Me Outâ€), responsibility (â€œCrownâ€), gender (â€œAuntie Diariesâ€) and generational trauma (â€œMother I Soberâ€). Itâ€™s a dense and heavy listen. But just as sure as Kendrick Lamar is human like the rest of us, heâ€™s also a Pulitzer Prize winner, one of the most thoughtful MCs alive and someone whose honesty across Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers could help us understand why any of us are the way we are.
entries.title: Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers

entries.notes: Part of the appeal of Londoner Tom Skinnerâ€™s first release under his own name is that it sounds perpetually familiar but canâ€™t be traced to a single source. Over the course of 27 minutes and with the unusual quintet of drums, bass, two cellos and two saxophones, he compresses â€™70s-style cosmic jazz (â€œBisharaâ€), noir soundtrack music (â€œRed 2â€), abstract blues (â€œThe Day After Tomorrowâ€) and sparkling post-bop (â€œQuiet As Itâ€™s Keptâ€) into pieces small enough to digest easily but dense enough to get across the essence of their respective reference pointsâ€”a feat not just of composition but editing, which, in Skinnerâ€™s own words, owed more to the chopping and looping of disco and house DJs than anything else. But to the modern jazz fans who landed here because of Skinnerâ€™s affiliation with Sons of Kemet or the International Anthem label, know that Voices of Bishara isnâ€™t a beat tape or collage project, and to the Radiohead fans curious about Thom Yorke and Jonny Greenwoodâ€™s collaborator in The Smile, know that, like great Radiohead, what makes Skinnerâ€™s process here interesting is how little you can hear its seams.
entries.title: Voices of Bishara - EP

entries.notes: Having collaborated as the London-based Portico Quartet for more than a decade, drummer Duncan Bellamy and saxophonist Jack Wyllie know how to maximise their time and effort. Their sessions for the 2021 album Monument were productive enough to have generated this compelling follow-up EP. Of the four contrasting songs, the title track is the most rhythmically intense, with long manipulated soprano sax sounds floating over Bellamyâ€™s fast broken-beat patterns. On the opening â€œCaptured Timeâ€, Wyllie gets an almost trumpetlike tone from the soprano as string textures and rhythmic agitation swell around him. â€œProcessionâ€ begins in a piano-centred stillness, with breath elements and drones setting up a doleful, slowly pulsing elegy on tenor sax. â€œYouthâ€, also with Wyllie on tenor, has fat, sustaining synth-bass tones undergirding a reverberant and impassioned melody. Aesthetically, Next Stop is one with Monument, though it expands the scope of that previous achievement.
entries.title: Next Stop

entries.notes:
The artist meditates on grief through intricate blips and beats.

From Pitchfork:

Liv.eâ€™s brilliant second album bends her expressive R&B into fearsome new shapes, acknowledging all the nuance and pain on the long journey to personal truth.

Couldnâ€™t Wait to Tell You, Liv.eâ€™s debut LP, flipped through the pages of her diary quickly enough to animate her scattered musings on young romance while preserving each entryâ€™s distinct perspective. Its allure rested on Liv.eâ€™s charismatic storytelling, in her belief that â€œeverybody got a love storyâ€ and her ability to play every role in those tales herself. Aggressively non-linear and rich in lo-fi charm, Couldnâ€™t Wait to Tell You kept the proceedings light and easy. Even in the albumâ€™s darkest moments, Liv.e never felt more than 30 seconds away from a cathartic breakthrough, rescued by a tempo shift, a false ending, or the affirming words of a guest feature. She tore through dreamy realizations like outfits ripped off a garment rack, theorizing that a change of heart could be as easy as a change of costume.

Girl in the Half Pearl cuts to the scene after the diary slams shut, when your face crashes into the pillow before a long and sleepless night. In place of Couldnâ€™t Wait to Tell Youâ€™s rose-tinted psychedelia, Liv.e builds a mirror, surgically examining the ugliest parts of her subconscious and clawing toward her worst impulses and most frightening thoughts. Healing is a minefield of doubt and confusion, crossed only by necessity. Liv.e doesnâ€™t waste time idealizing the process. â€œWhen I looked inside my brain, there were all these webs of pain,â€ she groans on opener â€œGardetto.,â€ somersaulting over a wave of pitch-shifted oh nos. She strains like a petulant child, burnt out before the work even begins: â€œI just wanna play with my toys/Iâ€™m too young for the worldâ€™s big problems.â€ Girl in the Half Pearl delves into the rich tension between deciding to change and taking the first step, dwelling in both the pain and promise of learning things about yourself that you sometimes wish you could forget. Itâ€™s a mesmerizing documentation of Liv.eâ€™s ongoing rebirth that dares you to keep your eyes open during the scary parts.

Liv.e heads a formidable ensemble of producers in soundtracking Girl in the Half Pearlâ€™s compounding existential crises, eliciting career-high performances from accomplices new and old. Frequent Remi Wolf collaborator Solomonophonic and West Coast new age keyboardist John Carroll Kirby pull out all the stops for the fluorescent â€œWild Animals,â€ wrapping its knowing eye roll to conniving men in trickling piano and the evergreen warmth of a brushed drum backbeat. Ever-reliable L.A. lysergist Mndsgn carves out a sizable chunk of real estate across the record, but lends a particularly inspired hand to â€œFind Out.â€ He digs deep in the crates, unearthing a jazzy, snare-less loop that thumps like an aching heartbeat, giving Liv.eâ€™s decision to trade loveâ€™s rollercoaster for â€œprecious time aloneâ€ the perfect dose of last-kiss sweetness. She walks away, a trilling synthesizer swirls in the mix, and the gut-wrenching resolve of her parting words (â€œI guess weâ€™ll find outâ€¦the hard wayâ€) cuts like a knife.

But true to the recordâ€™s â€œknow thyselfâ€ thesis, Liv.e tackles the bulk of the production solo, rediscovering herself through electronica and noise, and dousing her R&B foundations in a stunning coat of fresh paint. The most satisfying moments push her to undertake fearsome experiments with her voice. She crashes into the breakbeats of â€œGhostâ€ with a metallic howl, roaring with frustration as she bitterly acknowledges her need for securityâ€”and recalls how it was denied to her in the past. â€œI know I said I donâ€™t need the help/Just wanna get back home,â€ she cries, and the syllables begin to catch in her throat before suddenly vanishing, swallowed by grief. On â€œClowns,â€ Liv.e lures you into the tense moment before the emotional dam between two people bursts. At the breaking point, teasing percussion and sickly sweet strings erupt into gory pyrotechnics. â€œCanâ€™t be clowns for this long, so baby what do we make it?â€ she screams, her words sparking against the blown-out crash of the drums.

For years, Liv.e has found a home among some of Black musicâ€™s most critically lauded experimentalists like Earl Sweatshirt, Pink Siifu, and Black Noi$e. If you come to Girl in the Half Pearl looking to find a soothing voice in the wilderness, you will instead find a complex maze of battered beats and warped shouts. The gripping soundscape doesnâ€™t allow you to watch its protagonistâ€™s transformation from the safety of the back rowâ€”it shoves you through the screen. If Liv.eâ€™s going to â€œbreak the mirror 90 timesâ€ because she canâ€™t stand to see herself, youâ€™re going to help her sweep up the glass.

When Liv.e announced Girl in the Half Pearl, she described it as a send-off for â€œpeople pleasingâ€ behavior, and the album succeeds precisely because it feels so authentic and uncompromising: designed to serve only the needs of its creator. In burying the tender apology of â€œSnowing!â€ under a blanket of static, in applying a different vocal style and post-production technique to each vocal line of â€œSix Weeks,â€ in refusing to condense the long struggle of finding yourself into a catchy chorus, Liv.e affects an irresistibly magnetic anti-charm. She leads by example, by meeting herself in the present and holding her own gaze. Girl in the Half Pearl doesnâ€™t fixate on the light at the end of the tunnel. It chisels into the rock slowly, humming along to the sound of each strike.
entries.title: Girl In The Half Pearl

entries.notes:
The album of our Denia holiday trip in April 2022. 

â€œI literally donâ€™t take breaks,â€ ROSALÃA tells Apple Music. â€œI feel like, to work at a certain level, to get a certain result, you really need to sacrifice.â€ Judging by MOTOMAMI, her long-anticipated follow-up to 2018â€™s award-winning and critically acclaimed EL MAL QUERER, the mononymous Spanish singer clearly put in the work. â€œI almost feel like I disappear because I needed to,â€ she says of maintaining her process in the face of increased popularity and attention. â€œI needed to focus and put all my energy and get to the centre to create.â€ At the same time, she found herself drawing energy from bustling locales like Los Angeles, Miami and New York, all of which she credits with influencing the new album.
 
Beyond any particular source of inspiration that may have driven the creation of MOTOMAMI, ROSALÃAâ€™s come-up has been nothing short of inspiring. Her transition from critically acclaimed flamenco upstart to internationally renowned starâ€”marked by creative collaborations with global tastemakers like Bad Bunny, Billie Eilish and Oneohtrix Point Never, to name a fewâ€”has prompted an artistic metamorphosis. Her ability to navigate and dominate such a wide array of musical styles only raised expectations for her third full-length, but she resisted the idea of rushing things. â€œI didnâ€™t want to make an album just because now itâ€™s time to make an album,â€ she says, citing that several months were spent on mixing and visuals alone. â€œI donâ€™t work like thatâ€.
 
Some three years after EL MAL QUERER, ROSALÃAâ€™s return feels even more revolutionary than that radical breakout release. From the noisy-yet-referential leftfield reggaetÃ³n of â€œSAOKOâ€ to the austere and Yeezus-reminiscent thump of â€œCHICKEN TERIYAKIâ€, MOTOMAMI makes the artistâ€™s femme-forward modus operandi all the more clear. The point of view presented is sharp and political, but also permissive of playfulness and wit, a humanising mix that makes the album her most personal yet. â€œI was like, I really want to find a way to allow my sense of humour to be present,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s almost like you try to do, like, a self-portrait of a moment of who you are, how you feel, the way you think."
 
Things get deeper and more unexpected with the devilish-yet-austere electronic punk funk of the title track and the feverish â€œBIZCOCHITOâ€. But there are even more twists and turns within, like â€œHENTAIâ€, a bilingual torch song that charms and enraptures before giving way to machine-gun percussion. Add to that â€œLA FAMAâ€, her mystifying team-up with The Weeknd that fuses tropical Latin rhythms with avant-garde minimalism, and you end up with one of the most unique artistic statements of the decade so far.
entries.title: MOTOMAMI

entries.notes:
Pitcfork: â€œThe best song on Back of My Mind, H.E.R.â€™s debut full-length, is the first one. On â€œWe Made It,â€ over a glimmering sample moving in reverse, the singer and guitarist nimbly hits swirls of falsetto notes, sing-songy raps, and full-on wailsâ€”the only time she does so on the album. Thereâ€™s a gnarly guitar solo that sheâ€™s become known for at her many award-show performances, references to eating in fine-dining establishments in Paris, and a pretty piano outro. Back of My Mind never hits the triumphant high of its opener again.â€ 
Couldnâ€™t agree more. That firs track is really great (see my Songs 2021 chart) but the rest of the album is not reaching that level.

entries.notes:
From Pitchfork:

â€œOn their remarkable third album, the New Orleans band pushes their sound to both its bleakest and its sweetest brinks. Pop, disco, and house all melt into their raucous, revolutionary glam punk.

In a big enough mosh pit, the world jostles loose. You enter the pit as one person, and you leave as someone else. The late queer theorist JosÃ© Esteban MuÃ±oz described this transformation as a portal in his 2009 book Cruising Utopia. â€œI remember the sexually ambiguous punk clubs of my youth where horny drunk punk boys rehearsed their identities, aggressively dancing with one another and later lurching out, intoxicated, to the parking lot together,â€ he wrote. â€œFor many of them, the mosh pit was not simply a closet; it was a utopian subcultural rehearsal space.â€ In the squall of the music, reality starts to split and curl. Through communal, friendly violence, punks build muscle memory of what itâ€™s like to feel unhinged and cared for at the same time. The thrash of bodies clears a channel, however fleeting, into a more survivable life.

Special Interest drill down into that same molten core. Across three ferocious albums, the New Orleans band traces the line where the thirst for a new world meets the rage that torches the old one. Lit up and led by searingly charismatic singer Alli Logout, they call out the stakes of the era as they see them, excoriating gentrifiers, cops, warmongers, and trust-fund art-school kids with keenly tuned sneers. Songs about bracing for revolution brush up against songs about great sex on great drugs. Running on the tireless engine of Ruth Mascelliâ€™s clattering drum machine, they follow in a legacy of queer perturbations from the â€™80s and â€™90s that include Coil, Frankie Knuckles, and the B-52â€™sâ€”all of whom, in their own way, worked with the same mix of political dissatisfaction, biting humor, and erotic fantasy. On their third album, Endure, Special Interest push their sound to both its bleakest and its sweetest brinks. Pop, disco, and house all melt into their reliably raucous glam punk, and questions of communal caretaking press against a grief-riddled apocalyptic outlook. This time around, their thorns drip with honey.

Across Endure, Special Interest embellish the cornerstones they established on 2018â€™s Spiralling and 2020â€™s The Passion Of with gestures that wouldnâ€™t sound out of place on â€™90s radio. The after-dark sounds of house and techno started spilling onto commercial daytime airwaves toward the end of the last millennium, many of them drifting onto the Top 40 from overseas in the pan-flash genre called Eurodance. Logout stretches into certain vocal timbres and minor-key intervals that echo the perfect, ephemeral dance pop of a group like La Bouche, while behind their voice, delicate piano lines fringe the bandâ€™s hard-driving foundation. These shifts clear more air around Special Interestâ€™s sound. While certain moments still feel immediate and unignorable, others seem to waft out from a clubâ€™s open back door, beckoning passersby to come take a closer look.

The albumâ€™s most compelling songs use both strategies in tandem. They invite you to wander in of your own accord, then enclose you inside a fever pitch. On the rollicking dance track â€œ(Hermanâ€™s) House,â€ Special Interest forge an incandescent call to anger out of a surging hook. The song shares its name with a 2012 documentary about the imaginative collaboration between artist Jackie Sumell and activist Herman Wallace, a member of the Black Panther Party who spent 41 years in solitary confinement after serving a life sentence for a murder he denied committing. From his tiny cell, Wallace described his dream house to Sumell, who rendered it via computer graphics and as a tabletop model. In 2013, Wallace finally stepped out of prison, then died of cancer three days later. Sumell made plans to build the house he described to her as a youth community center in New Orleans, but property developers bought the proposed land out from under her.

The story ends bitterly, but Special Interest find solace in the idea of projecting utopia out from hell. â€œBuild it out like Hermanâ€™s house,â€ Logout screams at the chorus over Nathan Cassianiâ€™s jaw-clenched bassline. â€œWeâ€™ll all be Basquiats for five minutes or Hermans for life/So when I say build I mean dream, because thatâ€™s all we got promised,â€ they command in a spoken-word breakdown just before the final refrain. In a recent Quietus interview, Logout illuminated the juxtaposition between the Black queer artist Jean-Michel Basquiat and Wallace: â€œItâ€™s two different sides of what being Black in America is. Youâ€™re either fully idolized and destroyed, or youâ€™re thrown in a cage.â€

Special Interest began writing Endure in the middle of 2020, in the wake of uprisings against police killings that stirred cities around the world. Across the insistent drumbeat spikes of â€œConcerning Peace,â€ the band bemoans the whittling down of those revolutionary impulses into a neoliberal mold of nonviolent personal enrichment: â€œLiberal erasure of militant uprising is a tool of corporate interest and a failure of imagination,â€ goes a call-out line reminiscent of the interjections on System of a Downâ€™s â€œPrison Song.â€ Over Maria Elenaâ€™s frothing, sidelong guitar chords, the bandâ€™s voices come together for the chant-along chorus, where they collectively quote the Black Power activist Stokely Carmichael: â€œWe are not concerned with peace/Peace is not of our concern.â€ Power disguises its own violence as the natural order of things; to call for violence in retaliation clarifies the terms of a smiling oppressor. â€œNo one will ever rest in peace/When their value is less than property,â€ Logout seethes, pillorying commentators who expressed more concern over broken store windows than the lives of Black people killed by police.

Endure howls against a capitalist regime that feeds on the neglect and death of sidelined and exploited human beings, both in the U.S. and globally. This system is fragmented enough to work in the shadows; long threads connect military activity in the Middle East and the gas that seeps out of the pump at the 7-Eleven, but theyâ€™re obscured enough that whoeverâ€™s gripping the handle wonâ€™t typically feel them. On â€œKurdish Radio,â€ Special Interest draw an explicit line between oil lurking under the sands of contested territory and the lives lived in American cities. â€œIs love like Arab oil?/Do we take take take till itâ€™s depleted?â€ Logout sings. Later in the song, they overlay crude oil with blood staining the streets of New Orleans, as if to suggest that connecting local struggle to a global network makes for a start. At the climax of â€œConcerning Peace,â€ Logout calls out the names of metropolises across the world, tethering them together as sites of both historic disinvestment and revolutionary potential.

Amid calls to destroy every kind of cage, Special Interest stay attuned to what might sprout from the ashes. The music video for â€œMidnight Legend,â€ a sweetly melodic dance track whose single version features a verse from Mykki Blanco, follows a group of clubgoers through a messy night out. They flip off a handsy bouncer, ingest a few too many drugs, argue with exasperated bartenders, and get kicked out of the bathroom in the middle of a gay threesome. This club houses little of the utopia the dancefloor can sometimes tease; all night, it plays host to low-grade, aggravating conflict. Then the dancers spill out into the morning light. As passersby hustle their way to work, three of the clubgoers sync up for an impromptu dance routine. The people who have just woken up scowl at those who have been up all night. But the dancers look at each other and beam. Their movements reassure each other that they have each otherâ€™s backs even if no one else does. Under the new sun, they practice another world inside the cracks of this one.

The album rolls to a close with the slow-burning â€œLA Blues,â€ a song that sheds its skin multiple times over the course of its eight minutes. It starts with a handful of neighborhood scenes and a repeated falsetto taunt: â€œIf you donâ€™t like it you can fuck right off/Them boys in blue donâ€™t come around on this block.â€ In the third verse, Logoutâ€™s gaze turns inward. They ruminate on the end of a relationship, approaching a state of tenderness but quickly diverting it with a sarcastic â€œboo hoo,â€ then looping back to the bitterly laughing chorus. But as the song rolls on, as the one-two step of the drumbeat and the guitarâ€™s sour roar refuse to slow or pause, Logout dives deeper. The song boils into a dirge; Logout interrogates God in the wake of an immeasurable loss, their voice strained and cracking. As they hold their grief in its fullness, the song changes again, turning anthem-like, and Logout parts the curtains on a formerly hidden outlook. â€œThe end of the world is just a destination/I had to grow to love/Yes and now I know Iâ€™m not unworthy of love,â€ they conclude, their voice warm and open, defenses scattered on the ground. If this world is barrelling toward a cliff, if thereâ€™s an unavoidable terminus square in our path, maybe we should try to love like we did at the beginning.â€
entries.title: Endure

entries.notes:
During the disorienting first few months of the pandemic, Simon Green hit a creative block. The British electronic musician, better known as Bonobo, felt trapped and isolated working out of his home in east Los Angeles, starved for live music and human interaction. â€œI desperately needed to get into a different headspace,â€ he tells Apple Music. â€œReally, I needed to get out of the house.â€ Green began taking solo camping trips into the areaâ€™s remote mountains and deserts in an effort to get his creative juices flowing. â€œExploring California was a great way of breaking the monotony of being indoors all day,â€ he says. â€œDuring this time of zero stimulation, I felt like I had to make it for myself.â€ Fragments, his moody seventh album, born from these adventures, is a tribute to the West Coastâ€™s wide-open spaces. A laidback mix of mesmerising techno, orchestral instrumentation and hushed R&B balladry, the project is as sprawling, peaceful and varied as the landscape itself. Here, he takes us inside the making of each track.
â€œPolyghostâ€ (feat. Miguel Atwood-Ferguson) â€œThis began as a long, drawn-out, seven-minute techno track that didnâ€™t make the final cut. But it was built on top of two important thematic elements: harp, which is played by Lara Somogyi, who I recorded and then sampled, and strings, which are played by Miguel Atwood-Ferguson. In the end, I decided to keep just those two parts because they weave throughout the rest of the record and drew everything together. The minute I did that, it became the obvious opener.â€
â€œShadowsâ€ (feat. Jordan Rakei) â€œBack in 2019, before I even started assembling this album, I was working on a track that felt like a reference to guys like Theo Parrish and Moodymannâ€”that swingy, old-school Detroit sound. I had been listening to that Andrew Ashong song â€˜Flowersâ€™ and felt like, with a vocalist, this could be in that same area. I reached out to Jordan, who helped me work out the structureâ€”a bit of tension and releaseâ€”and it wound up being one of the first tracks I had in place for this project. Iâ€™ve been sitting on it for almost three years.â€
â€œRosewoodâ€ â€œA good ways into making this album, I started to feel like I had the record but I didnâ€™t have a proper single. So I went through my iPhone notes and voice memos and found a little piano loop that jumped out at me. I pulled it into Ableton and put a little kick drum under it and immediately felt like it could be the seeds of something. For the hook, I found this R&B a cappella on YouTube that had this little lyric of â€˜I won't leave you.â€™ And I knew that was it.â€
â€œOtomoâ€ (feat. Oâ€™Flynn) â€œThis features an archived folk recording of a Bulgarian bagpipe choir that, to me, feels like a huge sample. Itâ€™s this big, droning, ethereal, cathedral-y thing, and I hadnâ€™t heard anything like it before. I felt like it deserved to have some big moments around it, so I reached out to my friend O'Flynn, who does that so wellâ€”switching between tuneful melodies and percussive muscle. He wound up building an entire section for it, without even me prompting him, and it was perfect. Itâ€™s definitely the track thatâ€™s going to get played out in the club.â€
â€œTidesâ€ (feat. Jamila Woods) â€œIâ€™d been talking to Jamila and a few other vocalists about doing some collaborations, but nobody was feeling particularly motivatedâ€”it was too early into the pandemic. But then, in 2021, people came to life. Jamila texted me that she was going into the studio to record something, and it wound up being a demo thatâ€™s on the record. Hearing it really kick-started my creative energy. I remember when she first sent it to me, I was heading out for the night and was like, â€˜I'm going to wait to listen to this until I get home, when I can really give it my full attention.' When I got back, I'd had a couple glasses of wine, so I was in the perfect state. I hit play, and I was just...overcome. I almost cried. It was like suddenly there was an emotional centrepiece to the record. It changed everything.â€
â€œElysianâ€ â€œThis one is named after Elysian Park, which is very close to where I live in LA. Because it was the pandemic and most things were closed, I spent a lot of time in the park, going for walks, cycling up to Angels Point and so on. As this song came together, I listened to it while walking around in Elysian, so the tribute felt appropriate. Itâ€™s the midway point of the record, and felt like a good place to have a nice acoustic interlude. A moment of pause.â€
â€œCloserâ€ â€œI was digging around in my archives and stumbled upon an old session recording with Andreya Triana, a singer-songwriter who Iâ€™d worked with back in 2009. I produced her debut album, Lost Where I Belong, in my apartment in London. I pulled some vocals from this one track â€˜Far Closerâ€™, and it worked really well. I hit her up and was like, â€˜Hey! Remember this vocal? I've started sampling it again on this other thing.â€™ She got a kick out of it.â€ 
â€œAge of Phaseâ€ â€œThroughout this whole process, I was playing a lot with modular synths. It was a way of keeping the process exciting, to learn how to use different technology. â€˜Age of Phaseâ€™ is basically exclusively modular synths, apart from the vocals, and that was a new thing for me. I wanted to create all these interweaving melodies and vocals and have everything reach this chaotic peak, before diving down into something really lush. I'm going to try to deconstruct it for the live show and see how far I can push that idea.â€
â€œFrom Youâ€ (feat. Joji) â€œThis one seems like itâ€™s a bit of a curveball for some people. Maybe myself as well. But I was trying to do something that sounded a bit more like contemporary hip-hop and R&B. I was listening to Kehlani, SZA, slowthai, even some James Blake, and was really inspired by that blended sound. I'd always wanted to work with Joji, because I think he's a really interesting musician, and when the parts all came together I was like, â€˜Wow, okay, this is kind of a pop song. And I'm kind of into that.â€™â€
â€œCounterpartâ€ â€œThis song came together early on and was exactly the mix of sounds I was looking forâ€”a little bit techno, but quite melodic, with lots of modular synths. It was so fun to make that I was sad when I finished it, so now Iâ€™m working on a live version as well. I think itâ€™s going to have multiple lives.â€
â€œSapienâ€ â€œThis is my throwback to early-'90s raveâ€”artists like Mike Paradinas, Rephlex and Future Sound of London, that era of melodic, ravey breakbeats. I sent the piano part into a modular so I could get all those choppy synth parts that are actually from a Rhodes piano, and then I went apeshit on drum programming at the end as a way to hearken back to that era of frenetic drum breaks. Itâ€™s one of the more abrasive moments on the record, which I really like.â€
â€œDay by Dayâ€ (feat. Kadhja Bonet) â€œThis is a straight R&B jam, really. I had spoken to Kadhja for ages and we'd sent demos back and forth. And the thing I like about this one is that it references earlier stuff of mine. It feels like it could be from the Black Sands era, which makes me feel like Iâ€™ve come full circle. I also like that it has a sense of optimism as the album closer, serving as a reminder that everythingâ€™s going to be all right.â€
