entries.notes:
Especially the remixes are of great fun. What to think of Radio (Sinkane Remix). Almost minimal music. 
I have been listening to the original record and what a blast that is. Tracks like Radio, Etoh, Frontier Psychiatrist all mixed together using 900+ samples (truth is still out there); it is just phenomenal. Although this collection is about albums in 2021, this anniversary deluxe edition deserves a place in the charts.

From spectrumculture.com:

Do you remember a time before mashups? Before Danger Mouse made a name for himself splicing together Jay Zâ€™s The Black Album and the Beatlesâ€™ The White Album, or biomed engineer Gregg Gillis catapulting the genre into a world of nonstop blends of Biggie Smalls and Elton John or Birdman and Temple of the Dog? Before you could, essentially, type two similar songs into YouTube to discover that somebody cooked up the â€œHead Like a Holeâ€/â€Call Me Maybeâ€ mashup you imagined in your head? We wonâ€™t pretend that the Avalanches invented doing this around the dawn of the new millennium â€” to do so would ignore the Negativlands of the world, they of a strong lineage of splicers and visionaries who were doing things the hard way, without the help of Audacity or GarageBand or whatever program they chose to do it in.

And maybe itâ€™s disingenuous to even label Australiaâ€™s the Avalanches a â€œmashup bandâ€ â€” one might argue that what they do is plunderphonics, a term that sounds like your coolest uncle attempting to make up a word for, essentially, the same thing. It doesnâ€™t matter what you call it, though. In a worst-case scenario, you might produce an unlistenable mess of incongruous sounds that youâ€™d never foist on your worst enemy. But in the best-case â€” which is where we find ourselves with Since I Left You â€” youâ€™ll find yourself immersed in a rich, shimmering tapestry of sounds and sensations that leave you wondering, â€œNow, how the fuck did they do that?â€

These questions are the fairest ones to ask of any album this side of Paulâ€™s Boutique. How did the Avalanches do that, and how the fuck did they get away with it? The actual number of samples contained within the hourlong journey of Since I Left You â€” now re-released in a gargantuan 4LP format to celebrate its 20th(!) anniversary â€” is difficult to pin down. While some estimate that the number sits within the 900 range, Robbie Chater (one of the two founding members still with the group to this day) puts it somewhere in the 3,500 range. For those that somehow missed Since I Left You, the fact that thereâ€™s a dispute over whether or not the album only contains 900 samples should give you an idea of the magical beast weâ€™re working with here.

This article/love letter could be double in size if we covered the spiraling galaxy of removals and revisions that have taken place over the years; because the band never really foresaw anyone listening to the album, much less anyone giving it distribution outside of Australia, the matter of clearance becomes murky and impossible. That lack of foresight means that they did a ludicrously bad job of even cataloguing the samples they used and tossed in some biggies just for kicks â€” and as such, some sacrifices to the Clearance Gods had to be made in order to introduce the rest of the world to the record. Itâ€™s entirely possible that youâ€™ve only heard the version of â€œFrontier Psychiatristâ€ with vocals re-recorded in-house, and you may not have heard any clips from the film Midnight Run in the mix.

Underneath the dizzying number of samples and different versions of Since I Left You, though, thereâ€™s this album. It never truly feels like a real â€œalbumâ€ â€” many songs here present themselves more as connective tissue between bigger set pieces. If Since I Left You is the ultimate summer party captured by thousands of sound fragments, these moments are like hallways full of different conversations within the microparties that can bloom in those events. Youâ€™d expect it to feel disjointed, even disorienting, right? But no â€” even when theyâ€™re sampling the shit out of horses neighing, Since I Left You is a fully fleshed-out world, and one that feels staggeringly visual; Wildflower and We Will Always Love You would show the Avalanches expanding their ability to construct remarkably vivid albums that induce temporary synesthesia, urging you to hear the music in colors and shapes and whole vistas, but what becomes clear as time goes on is that they more or less arrived fully capable of performing this magic trick, immediately capable of invoking technicolor worlds you yearn to live in. They donâ€™t even need hits to keep you stoked â€” take a look at the beloved â€œFrontier Psychiatrist,â€ which moves away from the â€œsongâ€ part of the song long before the track itself ends, but totally organically.

Even given 20 years to spend with Since I Left You, itâ€™s hard to put a finger on what it is about these songs that endures like it does. From a certain view, the album can seem like amorphous noise that occasionally coalesces into a real â€œsong.â€ This feels myopic, though. The fact that the album is so easily equated to a party points to the fact that the album doesnâ€™t always feel like it was meant to serve as proper music, but instead, an aural gateway into your most fond memories. Itâ€™s a dreamworld dense with sounds that you feel like you must have heard somewhere, and just when you think youâ€™ve caught it, the sound passes. Every sound in the world might be totally new to you, but when youâ€™re hit with so many different things, it can create a strange phantom nostalgia for a formative experience that you never actually had. Songs like â€œExtra Kingsâ€ donâ€™t need to have cohesive structure for it to do to you what it wants to do â€” the Avalanches are powerful wizards, and they can give you those moments even without it.

Weâ€™d be remiss if we didnâ€™t go into the second half of this set. This massive 4LP reissue devotes two of those LPs to various remixes and (in the case of â€œThank You Caroline,â€ seen in its infancy at the tail end) alternate versions of album tracks. The very nature of the record lends itself to those remixes â€” artists like Stereolab, Black Dice, Deakin, and the late MF Doom tear the songs apart easily, inserting themselves into these worlds effortlessly. Your enjoyment in this aspect may vary: if you come to the Avalanches to spend your time within the world they designed, you may find these remixes unnecessary. After all, doesnâ€™t some of the magic of Since I Left You fade when you subject it to the standards of more typical dance music? Yet, for those willing to see what parts of each song are adopted and repurposed by each songâ€™s rebuilder. This is true of all remixes, but the album is such a treasure trove of sights and sounds, and each remix sneakily represents a love letter from the artist about the moments during that grand party that stuck in their minds the most.

The remixes here run the gamut, like the propulsive, gargantuan Carl Craigâ€™s Paperclip People Remix of â€œA Different Feeling,â€ or Sun Arawâ€™s psychedelic take on â€œClose to You.â€ The most perplexing omission is the eternal barnburner â€œStay Another Season,â€ but we do get Black Diceâ€™s thoroughly Black Dice-y spin on â€œSummer Crane,â€ which sees the band throwing the original into a blender with plenty of classic noise theyâ€™ve had sitting around, and then recording the sound of that blender on Max. This song is destined to be polarizing as hell, but itâ€™s easily the most unique track of the bunch (next to Deakinâ€™s zonked â€œExtra Kings,â€ that is). And then thereâ€™s the two sets of triplets: â€œSince I Left Youâ€ and, most surprisingly, â€œTonight May Have to Last Me All My Lifeâ€ each get a trio of different remixes, allowing us to compare and contrast. Watch as Cornelius steals the vocal hook of â€œSince I Left Youâ€ and lovingly sews it into a shimmering sea of beats, Prince Paul cranks the funkiness and Stereolab reveals how easily the song fits into their French futurist aesthetic. â€œTonight May Have to Last Me All My Life,â€ while existing squarely in the category of songs that feel representative of the space in between bigger set pieces, reveals itself as being highly remixable. Edan and MF Doom both choose to rap over the track, but the Dragged by Leon Vynehall version reconfigures the song into a bona fide dubstep banger worthy of a FactMag mix by Joy Orbison or Four Tet.

Twenty years on, the legacy of the Avalanches is a confusing one full of letdowns (the 16-year wait for its follow up) and triumphs (their follow-ups, Wildflower and We Will Always Love You, each a surprising and distinct masterpiece in their own ways), but as they broaden their scope and creation methods, their talent feels unassailable. The worst thing about their remarkable and unassuming debut is also one of the best things: itâ€™s an album that presents sounds that arenâ€™t always musical or even listenable when not in context, an aspect which then asks you to exist within its curious world instead of simply dipping your toe into certain moments. Since I Left You is still a breath of fresh air after two decades, its heady trajectory providing endless revisits and the constant discovery of new, exciting aspects. Ultimately, labeling the band anything at all is a gross misunderstanding of what makes the Avalanches special in the first place. They were â€” and are â€” just a band transforming the sounds they love into sounds they know weâ€™ll love, and that pursuit exists beyond any boxes we might try to put them in.
entries.title: Since I Left You (20th Anniversary Deluxe Edition)

entries.notes:
At the turn of the century, Radiohead released two albums that forever altered their identity. Now, Kid A and Amnesiac are reissued as a pair, along with whatever worthy B-sides, alternate versions, and outtakes they can find.
Kid A and Amnesiac, released eight months apart, have always had a big brother/kid brother relationship. They were recorded at the same time, during the same sessions, but Amnesiac inevitably became seen as a repository, the place where the music that wasnâ€™t on Kid A found a home. As a standalone album, its reputation has been unsettled since the minute it was releasedâ€”in a glowing New Yorker profile that same year, Alex Ross watches them tersely correct a hapless young MTV News reporter who accidentally refers to Amnesiac as the â€œouttakes.â€ â€œTry again,â€ snapped Phil Selway.

The band separated the two releases because they wanted to avoid releasing a double album, that most tired and bloated of rock-excess beasts. At the time, avoidance of all rock-star gestures had become something of a survival mechanism for the band. They had been touring, more or less continuously, for the past seven years. Six months into the long, punishing tour for OK Computer, Thom Yorke had briefly slipped into catatonia. They were getting more successful, and it felt awful: Watch the 1998 documentary Meeting People Is Easy and youâ€™ll see what rock stardom felt like to Yorkeâ€™s nervous systemâ€”dull, pointless torture, like being detained for eternity by airport security.

When they began the fitful, labored studio sessions that would produce both Kid A and Amnesiac in late 1999 and 2000, Radiohead knew very little about what they wanted, only that they did not want to be â€œrock starsâ€ anymore. Their new music, whatever else it might be, must accomplish that singular objective: All rock-band gestures were to be isolated, rooted out, and erased. They wanted to, as the song title had it, disappear completely.

A Radiohead axiom is that whatever the band set out to do, they usually wind up accomplishing the exact opposite. When they went in to record OK Computer, Thom Yorke declared confidently that they were about to make their first â€œpositiveâ€ record. And when they released Kid Aâ€”the album meant to chart a new course away from the rock-star treadmillâ€”it became their first-ever album to simultaneously top the U.S. and UK charts. Even more than â€œCreep,â€ which had only blown up Stateside, Kid A was now their big hit. Eight months later, Amnesiac would reach No. 2. They had gone as far away from guitar-based rock music as they knew how to go, and at the end of it, not only were Radiohead still a rock band, they were a generational one. All roads led back to the arena stage, even their escape route.

In the last five or so years, the band seems to have come to terms with its statusâ€”Selway and Ed Oâ€™Brien graciously accepted the bandâ€™s nomination into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2019. In 2017, they entered their commemorative re-release phase with OK Computer OKNOTOK 1997 2017, which collected the bandâ€™s foundational third album along with its ephemera. Now, they have finally released that long-avoided double album: Kid A Mnesia, which unites the two studio albums, along with whatever worthy B-sides, alternate versions, and outtakes they can find. 

Like many of their recent gesturesâ€”putting their music on Spotify for fans, years after Yorke memorably dubbed the streaming service â€œthe last desperate fartâ€ in the music industryâ€™s â€œdying corpseâ€; releasing hours of their demos for OK Computer after someone hacked their MiniDiscs from the sessionsâ€”it feels like an act of both generosity and capitulation. They have long since stopped fighting, but these albums capture the band when the stakes felt mortal; in recording these albums, they were fighting for their lives.

During the recording sessions, the band was frequently aimless, frustrated, certain only that they were accomplishing very little. On the online journal he maintained on Radioheadâ€™s website during the recording sessions, Oâ€™Brien worried publicly that the band was steering itself toward oblivion. â€œItâ€™s taken us seven years to get this sort of freedom, and itâ€™s what we always wanted,â€ he wrote. â€œBut it could be so easy to fuck it all up.â€ At times, it seems like every one of them was casting about in different directions, returning with half-cooked pieces of music that nobody else quite knew what to do with. They didnâ€™t know what kind of band they were supposed to become, but they all knew they were tired of the band they were currently in. None of them had one clear, resounding idea for a new direction.

One of the earliest songs they struggled with was â€œIn Limbo,â€ which layers guitar triplets over straight 4/4 drums, both of which slid off the surface of the underlying 6/4 meter. Rhythmically, it created a featureless expanse with no distinguishing marks, and the songâ€™s pulse resembled ocean waves more than any sort of backbeat. Perhaps in a nod to the songâ€™s maze-like rhythm, perhaps in acknowledgment of the quicksand they felt underneath, they called the demo â€œLost at Sea.â€

Meanwhile, Jonny Greenwood was fooling around with modular synthesizers, playing patches of radio static and snatches of electronic music records over rudimentary drum machine patterns, searching for a moment of inspiration. Yorke listened to it patiently, and found only 40 seconds of usable materialâ€”four refracted synth chords from the American composer Paul Lanskyâ€™s computer piece â€œMild Un Liese.â€ The seeds of â€œIdiotequeâ€ were planted.

In all this seeming directionlessness, Radiohead were zeroing in on the most primal essence of their artâ€”sound. Critics at the time knocked Kid A and Amnesiac for seeming half-formed, or sketch-like, but the de-emphasis on things like bridges and middle-eights seemed strategic. The members were seeking textures and tones, spaces expansive and inviting enough that they might stay awhile. In doing so, they reinvented the timbral palette for a rock band.

It was on Kid A and Amnesiac that they became in love with almost recognizable sounds. What was born out of a desire to eraseâ€”and Yorke used this word more than once, suggesting a vigorous desire, naming his solo album after this impulseâ€”became an opportunity to transfigure. The standard rock instruments became the ghostsâ€”nothing in Kid A sounds so otherworldly as the guitars, or Yorkeâ€™s voice. On â€œMorning Bell,â€ Greenwood scraped the strings with a coin to produce keyboard-like sounds.

The disembodied guitar sounds mingled eerily with the ondes Martenot, an instrument Jonny Greenwood mastered after becoming obsessed with the music of French composer Olivier Messiaen. Messiaen employed the ondes Martenot in his celebrated large-scale 1948 work TurangalÃ®la-Symphonie, which generated ecstatic, alien textures from the full orchestra and the early electronic instrumentâ€™s disembodied whine. The ondes Martenot is everywhere on these two albumsâ€”whining alongside the string section in â€œHow to Disappear Completely,â€ doubling the guitar and vocals on â€œOptimistic.â€ It is deployed as a forbidding chill whenever the textures threaten to get too familiar. Likewise, itâ€™s the non-rock instruments that are allowed to breathe, to exist in a recognizable shape as themselvesâ€”a harp glissandi, for instance, or a harmonium, both on â€œMotion Picture Soundtrack,â€ or the wailing New Orleans brass band on â€œLife in a Glass House.â€ These are the warmest textures on albums that defined digital-age paranoia, and they predate electricity completely.

Kid A was the first Radiohead album released in the harsh light of the Napster era, the dawn of musicâ€™s digital age. Because of that, the songs that would come to comprise Amnesiac were already pretty familiar to Radiohead fans who had been trolling P2P servers for new material. Live and demo versions of â€œDollars and Cents,â€ â€œYou and Whose Army?â€ and â€œPyramid Songâ€ were freely traded over Napster, as were a few of the outtakes that didnâ€™t make either album.

This means that none of the bonus material on Kid Amnesiae, the third â€œbonusâ€ disc accompanying the two studio albums, has the same revelatory quality as the inclusions on OK Computer OKNOTOK 1997 2017. The tracklist is padded out slightly with the isolated string tracks for â€œPyramid Songâ€ and â€œHow to Disappear Completely,â€ as well as a murmured two-minute take on â€œMorning Bellâ€ that sounds like a rehearsal for the version that appeared on Amnesiac. There is no â€œI Promise,â€ no â€œLift,â€ no bolt-from-the-blue alternate history that redefines our understanding of the band that wrote the album material. â€œFollow Me Around,â€ which was billed as the big inclusion on this re-release and the â€œholy grailâ€ for Radiohead fans, is a song that most Radiohead hardcore faithful know extremely wellâ€”it was included in a pivotal scene of Meeting People Is Easy.

Another â€œlostâ€ Radiohead song from these sessions, â€œFog,â€ is a little more intriguing. It was one of those nakedly vulnerable ballads that slipped out of Yorke from time to time, seemingly against his will. The grief-haunted lyrics mingled tenderness and dreadâ€”a child, possibly dead, runs forever up and down a hallway, while a luminous fog belches up from the sewers.

They first premiered it at a concert in Israel, where it was known as â€œAlligators in New York Sewers,â€ in July 2000. The live version is a simple, arresting two-minute piano ballad. The original studio version, which found its way into the world as one of the B-sides to the â€œKnives Outâ€ single, preserved this intimacy, but was marred by a slightly out-of-time tambourine and an uncertain-sounding guitar part. The version they include here isnâ€™t as good as either, with overly bright synth patches and a non-committal vocal take. It underscores the trouble that Radiohead have often had with their tender songs. If there is anything comical about the band, it is their distrust of their own instincts to write beautiful songs, and the agony and prolonged discomfort it seems to provoke in them.

If not for this slightly adolescent distrust of prettiness, however, Kid A might never have been born. â€œIt annoys me how pretty my voice is,â€ Yorke famously griped, and the last 20 years of their music can sometimes be seen as a battle between Yorkeâ€™s uglier impulses squaring off against the choirboy lilt of the instrument heâ€™s stuck with.

Yorkeâ€™s impulse to deform himself on record, however, led to moments of wild creativity. On Amnesiacâ€™s â€œPulk/Pull Revolving Doors,â€ seven years before Lil Wayneâ€™s â€œLollipop,â€ he intentionally mangled his voice with Auto-Tune. As an entire generation of hip-hop performers would go on to do, Yorke mumbled into the machine, allowing the pitch-corrector to randomly assign a key and a melody to his words.

Perhaps no single song encapsulates this mix of aimlessness and invention, the will toward prettiness and the losing war against it, as neatly as â€œLike Spinning Plates.â€ In the studio, they were grimacing their way through another demoâ€”the chord progressions were somehow insulting, too obvious. Thom Yorke, always quick with a withering aside for their own material, dubbed it â€œdodgy Kraftwerk.â€

They couldnâ€™t stop messing with it, however. No idea the band generated, no matter how wispy or maddeningly incomplete, seemed to stay away forever. (Yorke apparently wrote the bassline for â€œThe National Anthemâ€ when he was 16, and it sounds like it.) Their song fragments were like sick dogs that wouldnâ€™t stop limping after their masters. So there was Greenwood, messing around with the latest playback of that pretty ballad. Out of boredom, a fit of pique, whatever, he played it backwards.

Yorke, who was nearby, was transfixed. He crossed the room and demanded to hear it again. The track, played backwards, sounded like it was sucking nearby debris inward and pulling everything down with it. Yorke sat down and wrote a new song on top of his upside-down old one. But the backwards/forwards vortex seemed to have inspired a fever. So he sang his own lyrics backwards, on purpose, live. Then he reversed them so we heard them forwardsâ€”a subliminal message, just like the hysterical censors told us there would be when we played our records backward. But there it was, floating on the surface like a plastic bottle on the ocean.

That original upside-down song was a pretty ballad called â€œI Will,â€ which they would go on to rework, yet another time, and release for 2003â€™s Hail to the Thief. Radiohead fans have long tried to sync up the two versions themselves, re-reversing â€œLike Spinning Platesâ€ and laying the vocal take from â€œI Willâ€ atop it to recreate that â€œdodgy Kraftwerkâ€ demo that is lost to history.

Kid Amnesiae does not include that original â€œI Willâ€ demo, which, given the juvenilia and ephemera the band has allowed to see the light of day by now, suggests just how much Yorke must still hate it. The â€œLike Spinning Platesâ€ version on the bonus disc layers the grand piano arpeggios familiar from the version on I Might Be Wrong: Live Recordings atop the backmasked effects of the studio version. Notably, Yorke adds a verse that brings his desire for escape at the time into urgent focus: â€œWhy us? Why not someone else?/The cameras are turning off.â€ Like Bob Dylan post-motorcycle crash, doing everything he could to discourage the press and his fanâ€™s interest only to increase his enigmatic appeal, Yorke struggled against the straitjacket of his bandâ€™s grandness only to feel it pull tighter.

Decades later, the grandness of those sounds is what lingers. This is Radioheadâ€™s ultimate gift as a rock bandâ€”the transmutation of sound into sensation, the way an unnerving bit of audio can play upon our nerve endings, up-end us ever so slightly. The searching language of the chorus to â€œLike Spinning Platesâ€ (â€œThis just feels likeâ€¦Spinning platesâ€) nailed the curious, uneasy feeling that sound can give us, and the way those feelings translate into our other senses. It was the indelible sounds they made on Kid A and Amnesiac, more than any of the albumâ€™s digital age paranoia or its baleful view of the future, that comprise the bandâ€™s enduring legacy. Those sounds break free of anything you might want to attach to them.

entries.notes: â€œI had a responsibility to give people what they were asking for, especially during the pandemic,â€ Robert Glasper tells Apple Music. â€œThey wanted another Black Radio, so I had to deliver.â€ The pianist, composer, songwriter and producer has spent the past decade pushing the boundaries of what constitutes jazz music, combining its acoustic instrumentation with hip-hop swagger, R&B melodies and an ear attuned to improvisation. Ten years after the first Black Radio album, he returns to the genre-hopping, collaborative format, producing 13 tracks that seamlessly transition from the power of Amir Sulaimanâ€™s poetry on opener â€œIn Tuneâ€ to an elegantly downbeat version of Tears for Fearsâ€™ â€œEverybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€ to the funk of â€œWhy We Speakâ€ with Q-Tip and Esperanza Spalding. Here, Glasper talks through all the collaborations, track by track. â€œIn Tuneâ€ (feat. Amir Sulaiman) â€œI was scoring a Dave Chappelle documentary, and in the film, Amir performs a poem that floored me. Iâ€™ve never had a poem reach me that way. I was in tears. I immediately asked Dave to connect us, and we had a short conversation about what I was looking for. Two days later, he came back with this incredible poem that opens the record. A lot has happened in the 10 years since the first Black Radio, and a whole lot has happened for Black people in America in the last two years. I felt like I had to address the elephant in the room with this track and with â€˜Black Superheroâ€™.â€ â€œBlack Superheroâ€ (feat. Killer Mike, BJ The Chicago Kid & Big K.R.I.T.) â€œBJ is my bro, but this is the first time weâ€™ve done something together on wax. He came to the studio, and I was just playing around and testing the keyboard and he said, â€˜That sounds like some superhero shit,â€™ so I kept playing and the concept started from there. After that, I wanted to pick rappers that teach us. I wanted them to say something that spoke to this moment. I knew K.R.I.T. and Killer Mike would do it justice.â€ â€œShineâ€ (feat. Robert Glasper, D Smoke & Tiffany Gouche) â€œâ€˜Shineâ€™ came out of a jam session. I was playing drums and my drummer was playing keys and we came up with this riff that I then looped. I refined it on keys and added bass and then sent it to D Smoke to see what he thought. He sent me back a draft the next day. The song is all about self-love and knowing that youâ€™re enough. Thatâ€™s something I feel like a lot of hip-hop songs donâ€™t talk about, and especially during the pandemic, people needed to hear that.â€ â€œWhy We Speakâ€ (feat. Q-Tip & Esperanza Spalding) â€œA lot of my music starts off with jam sessions. I have my guys come over and we throw down some vibes and see what sticks. We came up with this joint and, immediately, I thought of Esperanza. I sent it to her and a few days later, she sent it back, and I thought something was wrong with the mic. She never told me she was writing it in French! I thought it was so dope, though, and I realised it sounded like something that would fit Q-Tip too. I used to play in his band, but Iâ€™ve never had him rock on an album, so it was perfect.â€ â€œOverâ€ (feat. Yebba) â€œYebba was part of the Fuck Yo Feelings sessions. Sheâ€™s become like a little sister to me since, and I knew I had to have her on the record. While we were at Electric Lady Studios, listening to her latest album, we jammed and came up with this pattern and the skeleton of the song. That was in early 2021, and a few months later, we got back to LA and finished up here at my studio. Her voice is so beautiful, and Iâ€™m so happy we got to make this one together.â€ â€œBetter Than I Imaginedâ€ (feat. H.E.R. + Meshell Ndegeocello) â€œI scored a film called The Photograph, which came out in February 2020. H.E.R. sang the ending song for the movie, and at the premiere, she told me she was so inspired by my score that she wanted to write something together. We literally went from the movie theatre to the studio and wrote â€˜Better Than I Imaginedâ€™. It wasnâ€™t planned for any project, but it did so well when I put it out, it planted the seed for the rest of Black Radio III.â€ â€œEverybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€ (feat. Lalah Hathaway & Common) â€œI have this thing with Lalah. On the first Black Radio, she did a cover of â€˜Cherish the Dayâ€™ and killed it. The next time, I was like, â€˜Letâ€™s do Stevie Wonderâ€™s â€œJesus Children of Americaâ€.â€™ She recorded it in one take, and it won a Grammy. So why not keep it going? Iâ€™ve always loved â€˜Everybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€™â€”I donâ€™t think I would trust a person who doesnâ€™t like that songâ€”but I donâ€™t know anyone who has made a version of it. I redid it in my own vibe, and Common loved it so much, he invited himself on it too!â€ â€œEverybody Loveâ€ (feat. Musiq Soulchild & Posdnous) â€œMy DJ, Jahi Sundance, and I wanted to make a house EP together, and this was the first song we wrote for it. I sent it to Musiq Soulchild, who I have known for a long time, and he came up with his joint in three days. Iâ€™ve never done a house song and neither has he, so it was new for both of us. It has a party vibe, and when it comes to party rappers, I always think of De La Soul and Posdnuos. I knew he would kill it, and he delivered.â€ â€œIt Donâ€™t Matterâ€ (feat. Gregory Porter & Ledisi) â€œI have wanted to produce an R&B album with Gregory for a while now, and when his tour with Ledisi got cancelled, I called them both up. I was luckily able to get them in the studio because the COVID restrictions had eased at that point, and they wrote it to fit their voices. Theyâ€™re both so powerful and definitely have their own sound, so this felt like a match made in heaven.â€ â€œHeavenâ€™s Hereâ€ (feat. Ant Clemons) â€œI went to Snoop Doggâ€™s birthday party and on my way out, Ant Clemons stopped me and introduced himself. Terrace Martin told me that heâ€™s high-level and that we should work together. Fast-forward to the next week and we started writing songs. We wrote four or five tracks since he was working with Justin Timberlake on his new album and Usher too. This was one we were going to give to Usher, but it didnâ€™t work out with the timing. I love it so much, I had to put it on Black Radio.â€ â€œOut of My Handsâ€ (feat. Jennifer Hudson) â€œJennifer came to one of my shows with my homegirl Kelly Rowland, who I know from Houston. They both sat in with me onstage, and I knew I had to get Jennifer on something. When I wrote this song, I heard her voice on it. It took us a little while to get together, but she performed it perfectly.â€ â€œForeverâ€ (feat. PJ Morton & India.Arie) â€œPJ worked with me on Black Radio 2 back in 2013, and he wrote the song â€˜Worriesâ€™, which Dwele sang. I love matching people up whoâ€™ve never recorded together, since it makes the song become more special. I knew PJ and India would sound perfect together, and we luckily managed to make this more of a back-and-forth process to make it feel like a duet where we were in the studio at the same time.â€ â€œBright Lightsâ€ (feat. Ty Dolla $ign)â€ â€œIâ€™ve jammed with Ty before. He is a legend who changed the game up, and I wanted to do something with a modern, pop-R&B vibe because thatâ€™s where Ty thrives. Itâ€™s different from any of the other Black Radio tracks that Iâ€™ve made, and so I wanted to end the album with this one because it has such a unique feel.â€

entries.notes: â€œIf I ever win a Grammy, Iâ€™m gonna thank him,â€ Queens-born vocalist, producer and multi-disciplinary artist Yaya Bey tells Apple Music about one of the many songs on Remember Your North Star inspired by an unnamed ex-lover. He was a music industry player and that relationship, which lasted some three years, revealed many things to Beyâ€”not just about the industry itself, but about who she is and what she values. â€œIt was like, â€˜Well, where am I going? Where am I headed and what should I remember?â€™ And I guess in trying to move towards loveâ€”love for self, love romantically, platonicallyâ€”Iâ€™m remembering that thatâ€™s where Iâ€™m going. Thatâ€™s my North Star.â€ While that relationship opened her eyes to some of the industryâ€™sâ€”and men at largeâ€™sâ€”more sordid practices, Bey managed to keep her joy intact, delivering a robust collection of music that spans Billie Holiday-inspired jazz crooning, lovers rock reggae and the bubbling form of South African house, amapiano. Within these spoonfuls of sugar, Bey supplies medicine aplenty, lambasting the intrinsically toxic systems that would, at one time, have her questioning her own self-worth. â€œTo be a woman in this male-dominated industry means you get judged and valued by things that really donâ€™t matter,â€ she says. â€œBut I canâ€™t have apprehension about what I do with my music because itâ€™s the only place I have a voice. Being a Black woman, an up-and-coming artist, and especially in my thirties, the only place I have a voice is in my music. I canâ€™t be silent there. Iâ€™ll just disappear.â€ Below, Bey takes us through some of the key tracks on Remember Your North Star, a project that casts her more visible than ever. â€œIntroâ€ â€œSo, [talk show host] Wendy Williams had said some shit about [vegan lifestyle influencer] Tabitha Brown on her show. And then Tabitha Brown retaliated in this way that insinuated Wendy Williams doesnâ€™t know love or doesnâ€™t have anyone to love her. And then someone on Black Twitter tweeted that even though Tabitha Brown didnâ€™t say very much, we all knew it was an insult because we all kind of know Black women have a wound around not being loved and not knowing love. And that got me to thinking about how Black women respond to that. Thereâ€™s the â€˜city girlâ€™ approach, which is like, â€˜Fuck love, just provide for me financiallyâ€™â€”and all of it is defense mechanismsâ€”because a lot of times weâ€™re afraid to ask for the things that we want, or we assume that we canâ€™t get the things that we want, emotionally. Iâ€™m saying, â€˜N****s going to n***a, so you might as well get paid.â€™ Thatâ€™s just my take on not feeling secure that men will show up in a way that is supportive of my emotional needs.â€ â€œbig daddy yaâ€ â€œI was having this realisation that most all of my problems can somehow be tied to either racism, patriarchy or capitalismâ€”literally everything in my life thatâ€™s going wrong. And as it pertains to patriarchy, misogyny and all that shit, itâ€™s always just fucking men at the root of my problems. Even when itâ€™s a woman, itâ€™s still some woman enacting patriarchy, enacting misogyny. What I learned about the male ego is just to laugh at it because itâ€™s utterly ridiculous. It isnâ€™t built on supporting the collective, uplifting the collective. Itâ€™s built on scarcity and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s so fragile. And so, â€˜big daddy yaâ€™ is just me mocking men.â€ â€œnobody knowsâ€ â€œI had just signed to Ninja Tune, and they sent me to D.C. to start the album. It was one of the first songs that I wrote. I had been going back and forth with this guy for three years, and we werenâ€™t in contact at the time. And he was bouncing back and forth between me and this other woman. I was really fucked up because I had lost my job. Like, the song starts off, â€˜I ainâ€™t paid my rent in three monthsâ€™â€”that was very true for me. And this guy, the last time I saw him, he was rubbing it in my face that [his other woman] is a doctor and Iâ€™m unemployed. I have to work so hard under the system of capitalism to be worthy. I canâ€™t just wake up in the morning and be worthy. I have to have all of these things to be worthy of love, to be worthy of a roof over my head. Me just being me is not enough for this worldâ€”I think itâ€™s a song that means the most to me on the album because I was at my lowest point, but I was still fighting for myself.â€ â€œalrightâ€ â€œI was listening to a lot of Frankie Beverly & Maze, and what I like about Frankie Beverly & Maze is that they make music to uplift the spirit. I knew I needed live musicians because a lot of the album was made on a 404 or from sliced samples. Itâ€™s all digital. [My friend] Temi introduced me to [co-producer] Aja Grant, and it was easy. It was a jam session sort of thing. I just hummed out the melody lines and they picked it up, and then added to it and extended it.â€ â€œmeet me in brooklynâ€ â€œMy family is from Barbados. I always say that Iâ€™m an African American of Western Indian descent. I grew up deeply in both cultures. So, I felt like I needed to put some of that on the album because itâ€™s part of who I am. And the album, overall, is about me dealing with and navigating misogyny externally and internally, and even internalised misogyny through my romantic dealings. And some of romance is about fun, like when you first meet someone at a partyâ€”like, the first time I ever danced with a boy was at a reggae party. So, itâ€™s in my DNA, and culturally and socially growing up in New York, and I wanted to include that sound.â€ â€œpour upâ€ (feat. DJ Nativesun) â€œMy friend Chris is an amazing DJ, and he plays a lot of house and dance, and I was working on a song with another artist at a session in D.C. at this big house that had all these little studio rooms. Chris comes into the session, and he has a track. At first, I was afraid because itâ€™s amapiano. But when I think about the music thatâ€™s coming out of Africa, thatâ€™s dancehall, thatâ€™s soca, itâ€™s house musicâ€”and I think, once we get past the whole diaspora wars thing, all of us fighting for the scraps, weâ€™re all Africans at the very bottom of this capitalist, imperialist food chain. Because you canâ€™t talk about Fela without talking about James Brown without talking about [Wizkidâ€™s] Made in Lagosâ€”that was an Afrobeats album because it was made by an African from Nigeria, but if we take that away, that was a dancehall record. At first, I was afraid that I would experience some backlash, but when I thought about it, Iâ€™m like amapiano is house music, and Iâ€™m allowed to be a part of the conversation.â€ â€œrepriseâ€ â€œSometimes relationships that you go through are a catalyst for you to get to know yourself more, or for you to really see where youâ€™re playing yourself, where youâ€™re doubting yourself, where you are not showing up for yourself. Itâ€™s really about how I had a lack of self-worth, and I was afraid to see myself as capable. And I had this other song where I was, like, tearing his ass a new one. But it was coming from a place that was more about bashing him than it was about uplifting me. And it isnâ€™t really my desire to bash anyone. So, I didnâ€™t put the song out and, instead, I wrote â€˜repriseâ€™, which is more reflecting on how I got to where I am, and the things that Iâ€™ve seen. It gave me a space to even have compassion for him because heâ€™s somebody with his own trauma and insecurities that are informing the way heâ€™s moving through the world.â€ â€œrolling stonerâ€ â€œI probably smoke the heaviest when Iâ€™m going through shit. Two months before the pandemic started, I was working 13-hour shifts in a homeless shelter, seeing crazy shit. Iâ€™m riddled with guilt because Iâ€™m working there, and I feel like Iâ€™m a part of the problem. Even though Iâ€™m just an art teacher there, itâ€™s still like I shouldnâ€™t be here because this is hella problematic. I come home, I smoke my life away, I make music, I go to sleep for two hours. I do it again. I mean, I had smoked before then, but that was my introduction to, â€˜Now Iâ€™m a pothead.â€™â€ â€œiâ€™m certain sheâ€™s thereâ€ â€œSo, my parents were teenage parents. My mom, she didnâ€™t raise me. She came from different circumstances. Her family was not as supportive. Her mom died. Her dad was just really disappointed that she had a baby so young. And my dad, on the other hand, he just had more support, more help raising me. Either people donâ€™t ever talk about my mom at all, like sheâ€™s this thing that never happened, or they have terrible things to say about her. Which, as a child, it fucked with my own self-image, to have this mom that is a pariah, I guess. So, as I got older, I realised that some of that is misogyny. And I just wanted to address that.â€ â€œstreet fighter bluesâ€œ â€œâ€˜Street fighter bluesâ€™ was the starting point of the album. I had someone else that I was supposed to work with, and the session was a nightmare. I ended up snatching my equipment out the wall and leaving. But then, I called my friend Nate Jarvis, who is a longtime collaborator, and once I got in the right environment, it was easy. I was listening to a lot of Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan, which is what informed the vocals. And then, I went on the 404 and sampled my voice, busted out a drum pattern and it was over with.â€ â€œmama loves her sonâ€ â€œA long, long time ago, I had this conversation with my friend, and she was like her motherâ€”always kind of taught her not to trust women. And weâ€™re taught not to trust women and not to trust ourselves because we see other women as competition for male validation. Itâ€™s not even just romantic male validation, itâ€™s just love from men, acknowledgement from menâ€”in the workplace, in friendships, in social settings, on social media, in relationships, in every power dynamic in marginalised groups. I needed a way to address the way that women act out misogyny.â€ â€œblessingsâ€ â€œI wrote â€˜blessingsâ€™ when I was in D.C. Itâ€™s one of the first songs I wrote. At the time, I was not talking to the same person Iâ€™ve been talking about. We were not on speaking terms. I guess I was going through breakup blues. I felt like I wasnâ€™t enough for that person, and I was figuring out how to be enough for myself. But at the same time, I was in D.C. A label had paid for me to go out there and make an album. I was too sad to get out of bed, but if I could just get out of this funk and realise thereâ€™s blessings around me, I could find a way to be present for them. And wherever you are, a person needs that. And life goes on, with time, you know?â€
entries.title: Remember Your North Star

entries.notes:
With an audience comes expectationsâ€”and Snail Mailâ€™s Lindsey Jordan became acutely aware of both following the warm response to her 2018 debut LP Lush, released when she was only 18. â€œI was 100% terrified,â€ she tells Apple Music. â€œItâ€™s so confusing to get any kind of reaction to your work. And I think it kept me from writing for at least a year, just because I was scared. I make music because I love it, so it was really all about connecting withâ€”for lack of a better analogyâ€”my child self.â€
Making that connection was that much easier when Jordan found herself living with her parents again in suburban Maryland for five months, after the pandemic took hold in 2020. Thatâ€™s where much of Valentine began to take shape, Jordan working alone in her childhood bedroom, free of distractions. Though bigger and bolder and more adventurous than its predecessor, the album is still deeply personalâ€”indie rock thatâ€™s laced with reflections on time spent in and out of love and rehab. â€œWhether the actual time there was for better or for worse, it got good art out of me,â€ she says of being back home. â€œI just felt like I was just doing it for fun again, like when I was working on Lush, coming home from high school every day and writing for a while. I guess just sitting on that same carpet was pretty liberating for me.â€ Here, she guides us through the entire album, track by track.
â€œValentineâ€ â€œI was shopping around ideas for the record long before there was one, just wanting to put a title to the thing to maybe give it a startâ€”like if there's just an overarching vibe, then I can start to make things. It's such a heartbreaking thing, referring to someone as your valentine in a love-lost type of way, because I just think there's nothing more tender and innocent. I just think the hurt there is pretty relatable, and when I came up with â€˜darling, valentineâ€™, it kicked me in the guts in a way that felt right for the entire thing. I just knew immediately that the record was going to be called Valentine.â€
â€œBen Franklinâ€ â€œI've always been extremely self-assured, confident and independentâ€”especially doing this job at such a young age. And rehab just kicks that out of you in a way. You kind of have to get in touch with values in a way that is shocking. Even just in the pandemic I was like, â€˜Okay, so now I need to be good at being a normal person, too.â€™ And that's different, and thatâ€™s not something I was so self-assured in. It was a big decision to want to just go and clean up, so that I could work again. I'm not cocky anymore. I'm dealing with what I left behind. Itâ€™s like, boom: real adulthood.â€
â€œHeadlockâ€ â€œâ€˜Headlockâ€™ isnâ€™t about losing someone so much as it is about really losing myself in a relationship. I worked on that one at my parents' houseâ€”all the synth lines I did in my room on my Minilogue, and I wrote all the lyrics sitting right there at my desk, just sort of dipping my toes into the deep darkness. With that line â€˜Thought I'd see her when I died,â€™ I'm saying that the end goal of dying in this case would be to be reunited with this lost love. It came from a real dark spot that I was in.â€
â€œLight Blueâ€ â€œI wrote it for a girlfriend. It feels like I was young at the timeâ€”I was 19â€”and even though it wasn't that long ago, in a way it was. I guess I meant it to be a gesture, but also kind of a declaration. I don't remember it being a particular communicative relationship but it was fiery and I think that was my way of communicating my feelings at the timeâ€”and I think that comes through.â€
â€œForever (Sailing)â€ â€œThat song was initially constructed from a sample of a song, â€˜You and Iâ€™ by Madleen Kane. I heard it forever ago and I was just really movedâ€”it has some magic that feels like I really feel. And I had never really dabbled in sampling, but I just couldn't stop thinking about being involved with the song somehow, selfishly. So I brought it to the studio in North Carolina and we isolated the sample and slowed it down. It's kind of a deep cut in a way, and random that I heard it. I don't know that much about disco at all.â€
â€œMadonnaâ€ â€œI was raised Catholic and went to Sunday school. I was in the church band. And the song is about putting someone on a pedestal and worshiping them and how that just doesn't translate into anything but resentment and anger once you kind of step away from it. Using religious metaphors and my knowledge from that time of my life felt exciting and genuine. I have a deep fear of being blasphemousâ€”I don't want to disappoint my mom.â€
â€œc. Et Al.â€ â€œI spent a lot of time writing it in the van, actually, on tour. I had a little portable amp that hooks up to headphones and I would just play it in there because I don't like to come up with lyrics around other people. It's complex, because Iâ€™d be sitting in the van for eight hours a day or something.â€
â€œGloryâ€ â€œVery angry and upset vibes. And it's similar thematically to â€˜Madonnaâ€™, goes within the same grieving process and theme of anger. It's disenchanted as fuck. Itâ€™s like no matter how angry I am and no matter how much I try to make this something where I'm in control and I'm the one making demands, at the end of the day I still would do anything for the subject of the song. No matter how in control I feel, I don't even feel like I belong to myself because I'm so entwined in this person's life.â€
â€œAutomateâ€ â€œI think that there comes a time whenâ€”through experience and through fucking up and learning about my needs and myselfâ€”love becomes less of a fantasy and less of a game. Thereâ€™s so much that needs to exist for love to be healthy, and once you realise that relationships are more than what you imagined them to be as a teenager and as a kid, it just becomes a lot more loaded. Like love, real love, is unconditional in a perfect world, and it's loving somebody beyond the good stuff. Being in love with someone is taking them where they're at and having them take you where you're at, and that's the brutal truth being uncovered in that song: Itâ€™s not all about passion and fire.â€
â€œMiaâ€ â€œâ€˜Miaâ€™ is the only song with a full orchestra on it and the whole shebang. Originally, we sent the song to an arranger and they sent back some ideas. I wasn't crazy about the arrangement, so I played some of the arrangement myself on a synth and sent it back and was like, â€˜Can I hear this?â€™ That synth line that got translated into an orchestral moment is one of my favourite parts of the songâ€”it was super collaborative.â€
entries.title: Valentine

entries.notes: A great deal obviously occurred in the five years between ASTROWORLD and UTOPIA, Travis Scottâ€™s third and fourth solo studio albums, respectively. Still, looking at hip-hop and rap music specifically, few could deny the extraordinary impact his music had on a young generation of emerging artists, their radical vocal and production style choices so overtly informed by his own vision. His commercial success at least partially hinged on the futuristic, otherworldly sound and image he cultivated, with listeners tuning in just to hear what fresh level of the game heâ€™d unlocked. Thus the collective anticipation for UTOPIA could not have been higher. Without fail, Scott delivers something only he could have delivered, a thoroughly riveting album that transmutes star power and experimental artistry into a marvellous musical monument. The opening boom-bap bombast of â€œHYAENAâ€, the funkadelic crunch of â€œMODERN JAMâ€ and the proggy thump of â€œCIRCUS MAXIMUSâ€ are just a few examples of how he has so lavishly expanded his sonic universe with this record. He now seems to enjoy a certain austerity, as on â€œI KNOW ?â€ and â€œLOST FOREVERâ€, but remains incapable of completely escaping the maximalist thrills of his past. The deliberately concealed guest list contains quite a few stars and superstars, and shrewd listeners may enjoy trying to identify them all without a cheat sheet. Drakeâ€™s unmistakable baritone leads the shape-shifting â€œMELTDOWNâ€, while Playboi Carti unspools his magnificent mumble over the buzzy â€œFE!Nâ€. But when BeyoncÃ© arrives for â€œDELRESTO (ECHOES)â€, its muted club contents echoing her own dance music renaissance, she provides a big diva energy that luxuriates amid Scottâ€™s cutting edge.

entries.notes: The nearly six-year period Kelela Mizanekristos took between 2017â€™s Take Me Apart and 2023â€™s Raven wasnâ€™t just a break; it was a reckoning. Like a lot of Black Americans, sheâ€™d watched the protests following George Floydâ€™s murder with outrage and cautious curiosity as to whether the winds of social change might actually shift. She read, she watched, she researched; she digested the pressures of creative perfectionism and tireless productivity not as correlatives of an artistic mind but of capitalism and white supremacy, whose consecration of the risk-free bottom line suddenly felt like the arbitrary and invasive force it is. And suddenly, she realised she wasnâ€™t alone. â€œInternally, Iâ€™ve always wished the world would change around me,â€ Kelela tells Apple Music. â€œI felt during the uprising and the [protests of the early 2020s] that thereâ€™s been an external shift. We all have more permission to say, â€˜I donâ€™t like that.â€™â€ Executive-produced by longtime collaborator Asmara (Asma Maroof of Nguzunguzu), 2023â€™s Raven is both an extension of her earlier work and an expansion of it. The hybrids of progressive dance and â€™90s-style R&B that made Take Me Apart and Cut 4 Me compelling are still there (â€œContactâ€, â€œMissed Callâ€, both co-produced by LSDXOXO and Bambii), as is her gift for making the ethereal feel embodied and deeply physical (â€œEnough for Loveâ€). And for all her respect for the modalities of Black American pop music, you can hear the musical curiosity and experiential outliersâ€”as someone who grew up singing jazz standards and played in a punk bandâ€”that led her to stretch the paradigms of it, too. But the albumâ€™s heart lies in songs like â€œHolierâ€ and â€œRavenâ€, whose narratives of redemption and self-sufficiency jump the track from personal reflections to metaphors for the struggle with patriarchy and racism more broadly. â€œIâ€™ve been pretty comfortable to talk about the nitty-gritty of relationships,â€ she says. â€œBut this album contains a few songs that are overtly political, that feel more literally like no, you will not.â€ Oppression comes in many forms, but they all work the same way; Raven imagines a flight out.

entries.notes: The caveat with mentioning the 30 years of history John McEntire and Sam Prekop shared before making Sons Of is that the album doesnâ€™t exactly sound like anything theyâ€™ve done before. McEntire is the drummer of the adventurous, anything-but-rock band Tortoise and the Prekop-fronted Sea and Cake; Prekop is a singer-songwriter who rebutted the harshness of â€™90s indie rock with music influenced by lounge jazz and bossa nova. Sons Of, by contrast, is made up of four lengthy synth improvisations combining early house, indie pop and the spacey, ruminative side of IDM. The connective tissue is in the approach, which is somehow adventurous but gentle, experimental but restrained. And while everything here has narrative momentum, their shared language is thick enough that they sound better the longer they go (the sunglasses-indoors sci-fi of â€œAscending by Nightâ€ and the 24-minute â€œA Yellow Robeâ€).
